 ****** Professor Longhair

b'{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}}
{{Infobox musical artist
|name = Professor Longhair
|image = 
|caption = 
|image_size =
|background = solo_singer
|birth_name = Henry Roeland Byrd
|alias = Fess
|birth_date = {{birth date|1918|12|19|mf=y}}
|birth_place =[[Bogalusa, Louisiana]]
|death_date = {{nowrap|{{death date and age|1980|1|30|1918|12|19|mf=y}}}}
|death_place =[[New Orleans]], Louisiana
|origin = [[New Orleans]], Louisiana
|instrument = Vocals, piano
|genre = [[New Orleans blues]], [[New Orleans R&B]], [[Louisiana blues]], [[boogie-woogie]] 
|occupation = Musician, songwriter
|years_active = 1948&ndash;1980
|label = 
|associated_acts = 
|current_members = 
|past_members = 
|notable_instruments =
}}
\'\'\'Henry Roeland "Roy" Byrd\'\'\' (December 19, 1918 \xe2\x80\x93 January 30, 1980), better known as \'\'\'Professor Longhair\'\'\', was a [[New Orleans blues]] singer and pianist. Professor Longhair is noteworthy for having been active in two distinct periods, both in the heyday of early [[rhythm and blues]], and in the resurgence of interest in [[traditional jazz]] after the founding of the [[New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival]].

The music journalist Tony Russell, in his book \'\'The Blues&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]\'\', stated "The vivacious [[rhumba]]-rhythmed piano blues and choked singing typical of Fess were too weird to sell millions of records; he had to be content with siring musical offspring who were simple enough to manage that, like [[Fats Domino]] or [[Huey "Piano" Smith]].  But he is also acknowledged as a father figure by subtler players like [[Allen Toussaint]] and [[Dr. John]]."<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x94 From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited
| location= Dubai
| page= 157
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref><ref>
{{cite web
|url=http://www.history-of-rock.com/indx.html
|title=Introduction
|publisher=www.history-of-rock.com
|accessdate=June 23, 2008
|last=
|first=
}}
</ref>

==Biography==
[[File:Professor Longhair\'s House 2010.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Professor Longhair\'s House 2010]]

Professor Longhair was born on December 19, 1918 in [[Bogalusa, Louisiana]].<ref name="russell"/> His distinctive style was the result of learning to play piano on an instrument that was missing some keys.<ref name="russell"/>

He began his career in New Orleans in 1948. Mike Tessitore, owner of the Caldonia Club, gave Longhair his stage name.<ref name="AMG"/> Longhair first recorded in a band called the Shuffling Hungarians in 1949, creating four songs (including the first version of his signature song, "Mardi Gras in New Orleans") for the Star Talent record label. Union problems curtailed their release, but Longhair\'s next effort for [[Mercury Records]] the same year was a winner.<ref name="AMG"/>  Throughout the 1950s, he recorded for [[Atlantic Records]], [[Federal Records]] and other, local, labels.  Professor Longhair had only one national commercial hit, "Bald Head" in 1950, under the name Roy Byrd and His Blues Jumpers.<ref name="AMG"/> He also recorded his favorites, "Tipitina" and "Go to the Mardi Gras".<ref name="russell"/> However, he lacked [[Crossover (music)|crossover]] appeal for white audiences.<ref name="russell"/>

After suffering a stroke, Professor Longhair recorded "No Buts - No Maybes" in 1957.<ref name="AMG"/> He re-recorded "Go to the Mardi Gras" in 1959.<ref name="AMG"/>

He first recorded "[[Big Chief]]" with its composer [[Earl King]] in 1964. In the 1960s, Professor Longhair\'s career faltered.<ref name="russell"/> He became a janitor to support himself, and fell into a gambling habit.<ref name=recordedblues>{{cite book| last = Oliver (ed.)| first = Paul| title = The Blackwell Guide to Recorded Blues| publisher = Blackwell Publisher| year = 1989| location = Cambridge, MA| pages = 280\xe2\x80\x93281| isbn =0-631-18301-9 }}</ref>

He appeared at the [[New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival]] in 1971 and at the [[Newport Jazz Festival]] and the [[Montreux Jazz Festival]] in 1973.<ref name="russell"/> His album \'\'The London Concert\'\' showcases work he did on a visit to the United Kingdom.

By the 1980s his albums, such as \'\'[[Crawfish Fiesta]]\'\' on [[Alligator Records|Alligator]] and \'\'[[New Orleans Piano]]\'\' for [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], had become readily available across America.<ref name="recordedblues"/> He appeared on the [[PBS]] series \'\'Soundstage\'\' (with Dr. John, Earl King, and [[The Meters]]) and co-starred in the film documentary \'\'Piano Players Rarely Ever Play Together\'\'.<ref name="AMG"/> Longhair died of a heart attack while filming was underway.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p99303/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Bill Dahl |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=May 28, 2009}}</ref><ref name=recordedblues>{{cite book| last = Oliver (ed.)| first = Paul| title = The Blackwell Guide to Recorded Blues| publisher = Blackwell Publisher
| year = 1989| location = Cambridge, MA| pages = 280\xe2\x80\x93281| isbn =0-631-18301-9 }}</ref>  Footage from his funeral was included.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1981, he was inducted into the [[Blues Hall of Fame]]. He was awarded a posthumous [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] for his early recordings released as \'\'House Party New Orleans Style,\'\' and in 1992 was inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=10450|title=All About Jazz|work=All About Jazz|accessdate=January 19, 2015}}</ref>

The B side of the 1985 Paul McCartney single \'Spies Like Us\', entitled \'My Carnival\', credited to [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Wings (band)|Wings]], was recorded in New Orleans and dedicated to Professor Longhair.

Fess\'s song "[[Tipitina]]" was covered by [[Hugh Laurie]] on the 2011 CD album "[[Let Them Talk]]". Laurie is a long-time fan, having used Fess\'s "Go to the Mardi Gras" as the theme for the pilot episode of [[A Bit of Fry & Laurie]].

==Afro-Cuban elements==
In the 1940s, Professor Longhair was playing with Caribbean musicians, listening a lot to [[Perez Prado]]\'s [[mambo (music)|mambo]] records, and absorbing and experimenting with it all.<ref>Palmer, Robert (1979: 14). \'\'A Tale of Two Cities: Memphis Rock and New Orleans Roll. Brooklyn.</ref> He was especially enamored with Cuban music. Longhair\'s style was known locally as \'\'rumba-boogie\'\'.<ref>Stewart, Alexander (2000: 298). "Funky Drummer: New Orleans, James Brown and the Rhythmic Transformation of American Popular Music." \'\'Popular Music\'\', v. 19, n. 3. Oct. 2000, p.&nbsp;293\xe2\x80\x93318.</ref> Alexander Stewart states that Longhair was a key figure bridging the worlds of boogie-woogie and the new style of rhythm and blues."<ref>Stewart (2000: 297).</ref> In his composition "Misery," Professor Longhair plays a [[habanera (music)|habanera]]-like figure in his left hand. The deft use of triplets in the right hand is a characteristic of Longhair\'s style.

[[File:Misery piano part professor longhair.jpg|thumb|center|430px|"Misery" by Professor Longhair (1957).]]

[[Tresillo (rhythm)|Tresillo]], the habanera, and related African-based single-[[cell (music)|celled]] figures have long been heard in the left hand part of piano compositions by New Orleans musicians, for example\xe2\x80\x94[[Louis Moreau Gottschalk]] ("Souvenirs From Havana" 1859), and [[Jelly Roll Morton]] ("The Crave" 1910). One of Longhair\'s great contributions was the adaptation of Afro-Cuban two-celled, [[clave (rhythm)|clave]]-based patterns in New Orleans blues. Michael Campbell states: "Rhythm and blues influenced by Afro-Cuban music first surfaced in New Orleans. Professor Longhair\'s influence was&nbsp;... far reaching. In several of his early recordings, Professor Longhair blended Afro-Cuban rhythms with rhythm and blues. The most explicit is \'Longhair\'s Blues Rhumba,\' where he overlays a straightforward blues with a clave rhythm."<ref>Campbell, Michael, and James Brody (2007: 83). \'\'Rock and Roll: An Introduction\'\'. Schirmer. ISBN  0-534-64295-0</ref>  The [[guajeo]]-like piano part for the rumba-boogie "Mardi Gras in New Orleans" (1949), employs the [[clave (rhythm)|2-3 clave]] onbeat/offbeat motif.<ref>Kevin Moore: "There are two common ways that the three-side [of clave] is expressed in Cuban popular music. The first to come into regular use, which David Pe\xc3\xb1alosa calls \'clave motif,\' is based on the decorated version of the three-side of the clave rhythm. By the 1940s [there was] a trend toward the use of what Pe\xc3\xb1alosa calls the \'offbeat/onbeat motif.\' Today, the offbeat/onbeat motif method is much more common." Moore (2011). \'\'Understanding Clave and Clave Changes\'\' p. 32. Santa Cruz, CA: Moore Music/Timba.com. ISBN\xe2\x80\x9010: 1466462302</ref> The 2-3 clave time-line is written above the piano excerpt for reference.

[[File:Mardi gras in new orleans.tif|thumb|center|420px|Piano excerpt from the rumba boogie "Mardi Gras in New Orleans" (1949) by Professor Longhair. 2-3 clave is written above for rhythmic reference.]]

According to [[Dr. John]] (Malcolm John "Mac" Rebennack, Jr.), the Professor "put funk into music&nbsp;... Longhair\'s thing had a direct bearing I\'d say on a large portion of the funk music that evolved in New Orleans."<ref>Dr. John quoted by Stewart (2000: 297).</ref> This is the syncopated, but straight subdivision feel of Cuban music (as opposed to [[Swing (jazz performance style)|swung]] subdivisions). Alexander Stewart states that the popular feel was passed along from "New Orleans\xe2\x80\x94through [[James Brown]]\'s music, to the popular music of the 1970s," adding: "The singular style of rhythm & blues that emerged from New Orleans in the years after World War II played an important role in the development of [[funk]]. In a related development, the underlying rhythms of American popular music underwent a basic, yet generally unacknowledged transition from triplet or shuffle feel to even or straight eighth notes.<ref>Stewart (2000: 293).</ref> Concerning funk motifs, Stewart states: "This model, it should be noted, is different from a [[bell pattern|time line]] (such as clave and tresillo) in that it is not an exact pattern, but more of a loose organizing principle."<ref>Stewart (2000: 306).</ref>

 ****** Billy Preston

b'{{refimprove|date=April 2010}}
{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name = Billy Preston
| image = Billy Preston.jpg
| caption = Billy Preston visiting the [[White House]] in 1974
| background = solo_singer
| birth_name = William Everett Preston
| alias =
| birth_date = {{birth date|1946|9|2|mf=y}}<ref name=nytobit />
| birth_place = [[Houston, Texas|Houston]], [[Texas]], [[United States]]
| death_date = {{death date and age|2006|6|6|1946|9|2}}
| death_place = [[Scottsdale, Arizona|Scottsdale]], [[Arizona]], [[United States]]
| instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]], keyboards
| genre = [[Rhythm and blues]], [[rock music|rock]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[funk]], [[gospel music|gospel]]
| occupation = Musician, songwriter, producer, actor
| years_active = 1956\xe2\x80\x932005
| label = [[Derby Records|Derby]], [[Vee-Jay Records|Vee-Jay]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Apple Records|Apple]], [[Buddah Records|Buddah]], [[A&M Records|A&M]], [[Motown Records|Motown]]
| associated_acts = [[Little Richard]], [[Syreeta]], [[Sam Cooke]], [[the Beatles]], [[Sly & the Family Stone]], [[Mahalia Jackson]], [[King Curtis]], [[the Rolling Stones]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Ringo Starr & His All-Starr Band]], [[Eric Clapton]]<!--and many many more too numerous to mention here-->
| website = {{url|billypreston.net}}
| notable_instruments = {{unbulleted list|[[Hammond organ|Hammond B3 organ]]|[[Baldwin Piano Company|Baldwin Piano]]|[[Rhodes piano|Fender Rhodes Electric Piano]]}}
}}
\'\'\'William Everett "Billy" Preston\'\'\' (September 2, 1946&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 June 6, 2006)<ref name=nytobit /> was an American musician whose work included 
[[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[funk]] and [[gospel music|gospel]]. A virtuoso keyboardist, particularly on [[Hammond organ]], Preston was recognized as a top session musician in the 1960s, during which he backed artists such as [[Little Richard]], [[Sam Cooke]], [[Ray Charles]] and [[the Beatles]].  He then went on to achieve fame as a solo artist, with hit pop singles including "[[That\'s the Way God Planned It (song)|That\'s the Way God Planned It]]", "[[Outa-Space]]", "[[Will It Go Round in Circles]]", "[[Space Race (instrumental)|Space Race]]", and "[[Nothing from Nothing (Billy Preston song)|Nothing from Nothing]]".  In addition, Preston co-wrote "[[You Are So Beautiful]]", which became a number 5 hit for [[Joe Cocker]].  Preston continued to record and perform with other artists, notably [[George Harrison]] after the Beatles\' break-up, and [[Eric Clapton]], and he played keyboards for [[the Rolling Stones]] on many of the group\'s albums and tours during the 1970s.

Alongside [[Tony Sheridan]], Preston was the only other musician to be credited on a Beatles recording:  the artists on the number-one hit "[[Get Back]]" are given as "The Beatles with Billy Preston".  Since Sheridan was labeled alongside "The Beat Brothers", Preston is, strictly speaking, the only artist to be labeled explicitly with "The Beatles".  [[Stephen Stills]] asked Preston if he could use his phrase "if you can\'t be with the one you love, [[Love the One You\'re With|love the one you\'re with]]" and created the hit song.<ref>{{cite news|title=Song Stories: Love The One You\'re With|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/song-stories/love-the-one-you-re-with-stephen-stills|accessdate=10 February 2014|newspaper=Rolling Stone}}</ref>

==Early life and career==
Preston was born on September 2, 1946, in [[Houston, Texas]].  When he was three, the family moved to [[Los Angeles]], where Preston began playing piano while sitting on his mother Robbie\'s lap.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}  Noted as a [[child prodigy]], by the age of ten, Preston was playing organ onstage backing several gospel singers such as [[Mahalia Jackson]], [[James Cleveland]] and [[Andra\xc3\xa9 Crouch]].{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} At age eleven, Preston appeared on Cole\'s national TV show singing the [[Fats Domino]] hit, "[[Blueberry Hill (song)|Blueberry Hill]]". At twelve, he appeared in the [[W.C. Handy]] biopic starring [[Nat King Cole]]: \'\'[[St. Louis Blues (1958 film)|St. Louis Blues]]\'\' (1958), playing W.C. Handy at a younger age.

In 1962, Preston joined [[Little Richard]]\'s band as an organist, and it was while performing in [[Hamburg]] that Preston met The Beatles. In 1963, he played the organ on [[Sam Cooke]]\'s \'\'[[Night Beat (album)|Night Beat]]\'\' album. that year, he also released his own debut album, \'\'16 Yr Old Soul\'\', for Cooke\'s [[SAR Records]] label.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news-releases.theurbanmusicscene.com/2011/02/11/billy-prestons-16-year-old-soul-to-be-re.aspx |work=The Urban Music Scene|title=Billy Preston\'s \'\'16-Year-Old Sould to be Digitally re-re-released on February 22, 2011}} "\'\'16 Year Old Soul\'\' is an album of percolating organ-infused instrumentals that offers insight into the roots of one of the music world\'s most innovative and genre-busting stars who died at the age of 59, in 2006. With songs covering a broad spectrum of styles from country (\'Born to Loose\') to R&B (\'Good News\') to jazz (\'God Bless The Child\') with pop and blues undertones aplenty, \'\'16 Year Old Soul\'\' is a preserved-in-amber glimpse of an artist whose musical maturity belied his years."</ref> In 1965, he released the album \'\'[[The Most Exciting Organ Ever]]\'\', and that same year performed on the rock and roll show \'\'[[Shindig!]]\'\' In 1967, he joined [[Ray Charles]]\' band. Following this exposure, several musicians began asking Preston to contribute to their sessions.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}}

==Relationship with the Beatles==
Preston first met [[the Beatles]] as a 16-year-old in 1962, while part of Little Richard\'s touring band, when their manager [[Brian Epstein]] organized a Liverpool show, at which the Beatles opened. The \'\'[[Washington Post]]\'\' explained their subsequent meeting:
{{cquote|They\'d hook up again in 1969, when the Beatles were about to break up while recording the last album they released, \'\'[[Let It Be]]\'\' (they would later record \'\'[[Abbey Road]]\'\', which was released prior to \'\'Let It Be\'\'). [[George Harrison]], a friend of Preston, had quit, walked out of the studio and gone to a Ray Charles concert in [[London]], where Preston was playing organ. Harrison brought Preston back to the studio, where his keen musicianship and gregarious personality temporarily calmed the tension.<ref name="WP Obit">{{cite news |first= Richard|last= Harrington|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=\'Fifth Beatle\' Billy Preston Made the Greats Even Greater |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/07/AR2006060702166.html |quote= |publisher=Washington Post |date=June 8, 2006 |accessdate=2008-10-02 }}</ref>}}

Preston is one of several people referred to by commentators as the "[[Fifth Beatle]]". At one point during the "[[Get Back]]" sessions, [[John Lennon]] proposed the idea of having him join the band (to which [[Paul McCartney]] countered that it was difficult enough reaching agreements with four).<ref>The Beatles - A/B Road: The Complete Get back Sessions, January 24th</ref> Preston played with the Beatles for several of the \'\'Get Back\'\' sessions, some of the material from which would later be culled to make the film \'\'[[Let It Be (film)|Let it Be]]\'\' and its companion album. Preston also accompanied the band for [[The Beatles\' rooftop concert|its rooftop concert]]; the group\'s final public appearance.<ref name="WP Obit"/> In April 1969, their single "Get Back" was credited to "The Beatles with Billy Preston", the only time such a joint credit had been given on an official Beatles-sanctioned release (as distinct from an unsanctioned reissue of some Hamburg-era recordings on which they were the backing group for [[Tony Sheridan]]). The credit was bestowed by the Beatles to reflect the extent of Preston\'s presence on the track; his electric piano is prominent throughout and he plays an extended solo. Preston also worked, in a more limited role, on the \'\'Abbey Road\'\' album, contributing to the tracks "[[I Want You (She\'s So Heavy)]]" and "[[Something (Beatles song)|Something]]."

In 1978, he appeared as Sgt. Pepper in [[Robert Stigwood]]\'s film \'\'[[Sgt. Pepper\'s Lonely Hearts Club Band (film)|Sgt. Pepper\'s Lonely Hearts Club Band]]\'\', which was very loosely based on the Beatles\' [[Sgt. Pepper\'s Lonely Hearts Club Band|album of the same name]], and sang "Get Back" as the penultimate song.

==Post-Beatles solo career==
[[File:Billy Preston perforning in 1971.jpg|thumb|275px|left|Preston singing at the piano in 1971]]
Signed to the Beatles\' [[Apple Records]] label, in 1969, Preston released the album \'\'[[That\'s the Way God Planned It]]\'\', produced by Harrison, the [[That\'s the Way God Planned It|title song from which]] was a hit single in Britain. His relationship with Harrison continued after the Beatles\' break-up in 1970; Preston was the first artist to record Harrison\'s subsequent international hit "[[My Sweet Lord]]", on his 1970 album \'\'[[Encouraging Words]]\'\', which Harrison co-produced with Preston. He appeared on several of Harrison\'s 1970s solo albums, starting with \'\'[[All Things Must Pass]]\'\'; made a notable contribution to [[the Concert for Bangladesh]], the Harrison-organized 1971 charity benefit; performed with the ex-Beatle on his 1974 tour of [[North America]]; and played at the 2002 [[Concert for George]] tribute, held at London\'s [[Royal Albert Hall]]. Preston also worked on solo releases by Lennon and [[Ringo Starr]].

In 1971, Preston left Apple and signed with [[Herb Alpert]]\'s [[A&M Records]]. The previous year, he contributed to another hit single when [[Stephen Stills]] asked to use Preston\'s phrase "if you can\'t be with the one you love, [[Love the One You\'re With|love the one you\'re with]]", a song on Stills\' [[Stephen Stills (album)|self-titled]] debut solo album.{{citation needed|date = December 2013}}

Following the release of \'\'[[I Wrote a Simple Song]]\'\' on A&M, Preston\'s solo career peaked at this time, beginning with 1972\'s "[[Outa-Space]]", an [[instrumental]] track that further popularized the sound of the [[clavinet]] in [[funk]] music. The song reached number 2 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]] and topped \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\'{{\'}}s [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] chart, before going on to win the [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Instrumental Performance]]. "Outa-Space" sold over 1 million copies in America, and was awarded a [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]] by the [[RIAA]] in June 1972.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs">{{cite book
| first= Joseph
| last= Murrells
| year= 1978
| title= The Book of Golden Discs
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins
| location= London
| pages= 319, 334 & 349
| isbn= 0-214-20512-6}}</ref>

Over the next two years, Preston followed up with the US chart-topping singles "[[Will It Go Round in Circles]]" and "[[Nothing from Nothing (Billy Preston song)|Nothing From Nothing]]", and the number 4 hit "Space Race". Each of the three singles sold in excess of 1 million copies.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs"/> \'\'[[American Bandstand]]\'\' host and executive producer [[Dick Clark]] enjoyed "Space Race" so much that he used the instrumental for the mid-show break for virtually the remainder of its run.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}

[[File:Rolling Stines 1975 Bily Preston Nicky Hopkins.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Preston supporting [[The Rolling Stones]] on their [[The Rolling Stones Tour of the Americas \'75|Tour of the Americas]], July 23, 1975]]
From 1970, Preston played keyboards (including piano, organ, clavinet and various synthesizers) for [[the Rolling Stones]], sometimes alongside pianists [[Nicky Hopkins]] and [[Ian Stewart (musician)|Ian Stewart]], on their albums \'\'[[Sticky Fingers]]\'\', \'\'[[Exile on Main Street]]\'\', \'\'[[Goats Head Soup]]\'\', \'\'[[It\'s Only Rock\'n Roll]]\'\' and \'\'[[Black and Blue]]\'\'. As the band\'s primary touring keyboardist from 1973 to 1977, he also performed as a support act with his own band (including [[Mick Taylor]] on guitar) on their [[The Rolling Stones 1973 European Tour|1973 European Tour]]. A [[Munich]] performance was documented in the live album \'\'[[Live European Tour 1973]]\'\'. In 1974, along with Beach Boy Dennis Wilson, he composed one of Joe Cocker\'s biggest hits, "You Are So Beautiful". On October 11, 1975, he was the first musical guest on \'\'[[Saturday Night Live]]\'\'{{\'}}s series premiere episode (along with [[Janis Ian]]). Preston\'s 1973 song "Do You Love Me" was the basis for the Rolling Stones\' track "Melody", released on \'\'Black and Blue\'\' in 1976.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} Although two of his songs ("Nothing from Nothing" and "Outa-Space") were included in the band\'s 1976 live sets, the Stones and Preston parted company in 1977, mainly due to a disagreement over money.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} He continued to play on solo records by Stones members and made appearances on the band\'s 1981 \'\'[[Tattoo You]]\'\' and 1997 \'\'[[Bridges to Babylon]]\'\' albums.

Preston\'s solo career began to decline after 1976. After five years with A&M, he signed with [[Motown Records]]. In 1980, he duetted with [[Syreeta Wright]] on the ballad "[[With You I\'m Born Again]]", which reached number 4 on the charts in the US. Failing thereafter to match its success, Preston left Motown in 1984 and focused on session work. He served as musical director for \'\'[[Nightlife (TV series)|Nightlife]]\'\', a late-night [[talk show]] hosted by [[David Brenner]] that lasted one season from 1986 &ndash; 1987.<ref name="Chase">
{{cite web
| date=September 7, 1986
| last=Chase
| first=Donald
| url=http://articles.philly.com/1986-09-07/entertainment/26074159_1_david-brenner-carson-s-tonight-show-joan-rivers
| title=He\'s On His Own In Late-night TV
| publisher=\'\'[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]\'\'
| accessdate=September 16, 2014}}</ref>

==Legal troubles==
In 1991, Preston was arrested and convicted for [[insurance fraud]] after setting fire to his own house in Los Angeles,<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/07/arts/07iht-web.0607preston.1906957.html?_r=0 Jon Pareles, "Obituary: Billy Preston, 59, renowned keyboardist - International Herald Tribune".]</ref> and he was treated for [[alcohol]] and [[cocaine]] addictions. He also was arrested in 1991 for sexually assaulting a 16-year-old Mexican boy, after picking him up at a gathering point for day laborers.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1991-08-19/local/me-736_1_singer-billy-preston Edward J. Boyer, "Singer Billy Preston Arrested in Sex Case"], \'\'Los Angeles Times\'\', August 19, 1991.</ref> After submitting to a drug test, he tested positive for cocaine. That year, he entered [[nolo contendre|no-contest pleas]] to the cocaine and [[sexual assault]] charges. He was sentenced to nine months at a [[drug rehabilitation]] center and three months of [[house arrest]].

Preston overcame his problems in the early 1990s, toured with [[Eric Clapton]], recorded with Gary Walker, one of the vocalists in his Los Angeles-based band, and worked with a wide range of other artists. He also toured with [[Ringo Starr]] and appeared on the 1990 live album \'\'[[Ringo Starr and His All-Starr Band]]\'\'. He was invited to become a member of [[The Band]] in 1991, after the death of piano player [[Stan Szelest]]. He performed on tour with the group, but the sentencing from his cocaine and sexual assault charges ended the collaboration.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}}

==Later work==
In 1997, Billy Preston recorded the album \'\'You and I\'\', in Italy, with Italian band [[Novecento (group)|Novecento]]. The album was produced by Vaughn De Spenza and Novecento members [[Nicolosi Productions|Lino and Pino Nicolosi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.tiscali.it/novecentomusic-wolit/collaboration/collaboration.htm |title=Collaborations - Novecento and Billy Preston |publisher=Web.tiscali.it |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref>

In 1998, Preston played organ during the choir numbers on the [[UPN]] comedy show \'\'[[Good News (TV series)|Good News]]\'\'. The same year he sang and played synthesizer in the film \'\'[[Blues Brothers 2000]]\'\', as part of the super group, [[The Louisiana Gator Boys]].

While touring and fighting his own health problems, Preston received the news that on November 29, 2001, [[George Harrison]] had died (having long suffered from [[Head and neck cancer|throat cancer]]). Preston, among many of Harrison\'s longtime friends, performed in the 2002 [[Concert for George]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in [[London, England|London]]. Preston\'s performance of "[[My Sweet Lord]]" received critical acclaim.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} Additionally, Preston sang "[[Isn\'t It a Pity]]", provided backing vocals on most of the other songs, and played the [[Hammond organ]] for the show. [[Ringo Starr]] called him one of the greatest Hammond players of all time (in the theatrical version of the concert).{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}

In 2002, Preston appeared on the [[Johnny Cash]] album \'\'[[American IV: The Man Comes Around]]\'\', playing piano on "[[Personal Jesus]]" and "[[Tear-Stained Letter]]".

In 2004, Preston toured with the [[Funk Brothers]] and [[Steve Winwood]] in Europe, and then with his friend [[Eric Clapton]] in Europe and North America. After he finished touring with Clapton, Preston went to France, where he was featured in one episode of the \'\'[[Legends Rock]] TV Show.\'\'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legends-rock.com/index.php/episodes/billy-preston |title=Guest Artist of the Legends Rock TV Show |publisher=Legends-rock.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> His performance included a duet with [[Samuel David Moore|Sam Moore]] singing "[[You Are So Beautiful]]"; this was Preston\'s last videotaped concert.

In 2004, Preston performed as a [[List of jazz organists|jazz organist]] on Ray Charles\' \'\'[[Genius Loves Company]]\'\', an album of duets, on the song "[[Here We Go Again (Ray Charles song)|Here We Go Again]]" with Charles and [[Norah Jones]].

In March 2005, Preston appeared on the \'\'[[American Idol]]\'\' [[American Idol (season 4)|fourth season]] finale. Playing piano, he performed "[[With You I\'m Born Again]]" with [[Vonzell Solomon]] (who finished the contest in third place). The same year, he recorded "Go Where No One\'s Gone Before", the main title song for the [[anime]] series \'\'[[L/R: Licensed by Royalty]]\'\'.

Preston played [[clavinet]] on the song "[[Warlocks (song)|Warlocks]]" for the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] album \'\'[[Stadium Arcadium]]\'\' (2006). Although very ill by this point, he jumped out of his bed after hearing a tape of the song given to him by the band, recorded his part, and went back to bed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/xmlfeed.nsf/mndwebpages/peppers%20get%20sick%20preston%20out%20of%20bed_14_03_2006 |title=Red Hot Chili Peppers - Peppers Get Sick Preston Out Of Bed |publisher=Contactmusic.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref>

Preston\'s final recorded contributions were the [[Gospel music|gospel]]-tinged organ on the [[Neil Diamond]] album \'\'[[12 Songs (Neil Diamond album)|12 Songs]]\'\' (2005), and his keyboard work on \'\'[[The Road to Escondido]]\'\' (2006) by [[Eric Clapton]] and [[J. J. Cale]].

In late 2005, Preston made his last public performance, in Los Angeles, to support the re-release of the \'\'[[Concert for Bangla Desh]]\'\' (1972) movie. Preston played a three song set of "[[Give Me Love]]", "[[My Sweet Lord]]", and "[[Isn\'t It a Pity]]", and was supported by [[Dhani Harrison]] on guitar and [[Ringo Starr]] on drums (for "Isn\'t It a Pity", only).

==Personal life==
Preston was [[openly gay]] but did not speak publicly about his sexuality.<ref>{{cite book|title=[[Life (book)|Life]]|author=Richards, Keith|authorlink=Keith Richards|publisher=[[Weidenfeld & Nicolson]]|year=2010|isbn=978-0-297-85439-5|quote=And he was gay at a time when nobody could be openly gay, which added difficulties to his life. Billy could be, most of time, a bundle of fun. but sometimes he would get on the rag. I had to stop him from beating up his boyfriend in an elevator once.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvone.tv/about-unsung/episodes/season-4/billy-preston/722-gay-singers|title=Gay Singers|work=[[Unsung (TV series)|Unsung]]|publisher=[[TV One (US TV network)|TV One]]|accessdate=2012-03-15}}{{Dead link |date=September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=[[Bruce Fisher|Fisher, Bruce]]|work=[[Unsung (TV series)|Unsung]]|title=Billy Preston|publisher= [[TV One (US TV network)|TV One]]|date=July 25, 2011}}</ref>

Jazz musician [[Miles Davis]] was heavily influenced by Preston\'s music during his [[funk rock]] period of the early 1970s.{{who|date=December 2013}}{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Davis\' album \'\'[[Get Up With It]]\'\' (1974) features a track called "Billy Preston" in his honor.

==Death==
{{Wikinews|Billy Preston dies at 59}}
Preston had battled [[kidney disease]] in his later years, brought on by his [[hypertension]]. He received a kidney transplant in 2002, but his health continued to deteriorate. He had voluntarily entered a drug rehabilitation clinic in [[Malibu, California]], at the suggestion of guitarist Is\'real Benton, and suffered [[pericarditis]] there, leading to respiratory failure that left him in a coma from November 21, 2005.<ref name=nytobit>{{cite news |first= Jon|last= Pareles|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Billy Preston, 59, Soul Musician, Is Dead; Renowned Keyboardist and Collaborator |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/07/arts/07preston.html?_r=1&oref=slogin&pagewanted=all |quote=Billy Preston, the splashy gospel-rooted keyboardist whose career included No. 1 solo hits and work with the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, died yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 59. |publisher=\'\'New York Times\'\' |date= June 7, 2006|accessdate=2008-06-28 }}</ref>  Preston died on June 6, 2006, in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]], of complications of [[malignant hypertension]] that resulted in kidney failure and other complications.  His funeral was held on June 20 at the Faithful Central Bible Church in [[Inglewood, California]], where his remains were interred at [[Inglewood Park Cemetery]].<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=14524361 "Billy Everett Preston"], Find A Grave.</ref>

 ****** Jennifer Lopez

b'{{Redirect|J.Lo|the album|J.Lo (album)|other uses|J.Lo (disambiguation)}}
{{for|the meteorologist|Jennifer Lopez (meteorologist)}}

\'\'\'Jennifer Lynn Lopez\'\'\'<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Zach|title=Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony Are Officially Divorced, Nearly 3 Years After Split|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/519856/jennifer-lopez-and-marc-anthony-are-officially-divorced-nearly-3-years-after-split|accessdate=16 August 2014|work=E!|date=June 18, 2014|quote=She also filed paperwork to have her legal name be changed from Jennifer Muniz (Anthony\'s real surname) back to Jennifer Lopez.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/06/jennifer-lopez-name-change_n_4398985.html |title=Jennifer Lopez Requests Name Change In Divorce Documents |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2014-01-25 |accessdate=2014-07-20}}</ref> (born July 24, 1969), also known as \'\'\'J. Lo\'\'\', is an American actress, author, fashion designer, dancer, producer, and singer. She became interested in pursuing a career in the entertainment industry following a minor role in the 1986 film \'\'[[My Little Girl]]\'\', to the dismay of her [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] parents, who believed that it was an unrealistic career route for a Hispanic. Lopez gained her first regular high-profile job as a [[Fly Girl]] dancer on \'\'[[In Living Color]]\'\' in 1991, where she remained a regular until she decided to pursue an acting career in 1993. She received her first leading role in the [[Selena]] biopic [[Selena (film)|of the same name]] in 1997. Lopez became the first Latina actress to earn over $1 million for a role the following year, with the film \'\'[[Out of Sight]]\'\'. She ventured into the music industry in 1999 with her debut studio album, \'\'[[On the 6]]\'\'.

With the simultaneous release of her second studio album \'\'[[J.Lo (album)|J.Lo]]\'\' and her film \'\'[[The Wedding Planner]]\'\' in 2001, Lopez became the first person to have a number one album and film in the same week. Her 2002 remix album, \'\'[[J to tha L\xe2\x80\x93O! The Remixes]]\'\', became the first in history to debut at number one on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], while her fifth studio album, \'\'[[Como Ama una Mujer]]\'\' (2007), received the highest first-week sales for a Spanish album in the United States. With past record sales of over 60 million and a cumulative film gross of over $2 billion, Lopez is regarded as the most influential Hispanic performer in the United States, as well as its highest paid Latin entertainer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Lopez|url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/jennifer-lopez/|website=\'\'[[MTV]]\'\'|publisher=[[Viacom]]|accessdate=January 24, 2015}}</ref><ref name="hhh" /> Along with [[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]] and [[Claudia Leitte]], she recorded "[[We Are One (Ole Ola)]]", which served as the [[FIFA World Cup official songs|official song]] of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Cantor-Navas|first=Judy|title=Pitbull\'s \'We Are One (Ole, Ola)\' Featuring Jennifer Lopez, Claudia Leitte Named FIFA\'S Official World Cup Song|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/global/5884960/pitbulls-we-are-one-ole-ola-featuring-jennifer-lopez-claudia-leitte|work=Billboard|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=April 6, 2014|date=January 23, 2014}}</ref>

Beyond entertainment, Lopez enjoyed a highly successful business career, consisting of various clothing lines, accessories, fragrances, [[Nuyorican Productions|a production company]], television shows and a [[Lopez Family Foundation|charitable foundation]] among other business interests. Lopez\'s personal relationships have attracted worldwide media attention; she has been married three times. Following the breakdown of her first marriage, Lopez dated rapper and entertainment mogul [[Sean Combs]]. Following the breakdown of her second marriage to husband [[Cris Judd]], she dated actor [[Ben Affleck]]. Their relationship was the subject of much media interest; their planned wedding was cancelled four days before the ceremony. Lopez then wed longtime friend [[Marc Anthony]]; they separated after seven years of marriage. Lopez gave birth to their twins, Emme and Maximilian, in 2008.

==Early life==
Jennifer Lynn Lopez was born on July 24, 1969, in the [[Castle Hill, Bronx|Castle Hill]] neighborhood of [[The Bronx]], [[New York]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.courttv.com/trials/puffy/docs/duty-caps_3.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080209202541/http://www.courttv.com/trials/puffy/docs/duty-caps_3.html|archivedate=February 9, 2008|title=Duty Captain\'s Report|accessdate=October 29, 2006|work=[[Court TV]]|publisher=[[Time Warner]]|date=January 17, 2001}}</ref> to [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] parents Guadalupe Rodriguez and David Lopez. She has an older sister, Leslie, and a younger sister, [[Lynda Lopez|Lynda]], a journalist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.terra.com/musica/fotos/mamas_y_mamacitas/64457 |title=Mam\xc3\xa1s y Mamacitas&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 M\xc3\xbasica |publisher=[[Terra Networks]] |accessdate=May 24, 2012|date=May 11, 2007}}</ref> David worked the night shift at the Guardian Insurance Company, before becoming a computer technician at the firm, while Guadalupe was a homemaker. When Lopez was born, the family was living in a small apartment. A few years later, her parents had saved up enough money to be able to purchase a two-story house, which was considered a big deal for the relatively poor family.<ref name="Gallick2003">{{harvnb|Gallick|2003}}</ref> At the age of five, Lopez began taking singing and dancing lessons. She toured New York with her school when she was seven years old. Her parents stressed the importance of work ethic and being able to speak English. They encouraged their three daughters to put on performances at home; singing and dancing in front of each other and their friends so that they would stay "out of trouble".<ref name="atriplethreat">{{cite web|url=http://www.evancarmichael.com/Famous-Entrepreneurs/619/The-Triple-Threat-Jennifer-Lopez-is-Born.html |title=The Triple Threat: Jennifer Lopez is Born |publisher=Evan Carmichael |accessdate=March 23, 2012}}</ref> Lopez spent her entire academic career in Catholic schools, finishing at [[Preston High School (New York City)|Preston High School]].<ref name=tca>Stated on \'\'[[Inside the Actors Studio]]\'\', 2004</ref> In school, Lopez did gymnastics, ran track on a national level and was a member of the school\'s softball team.<ref name=rantrack>{{cite book|last=Parish|first=James-Robert|title=Jennifer Lopez: Actor and Singer|page=14|url=http://books.google.com/?id=lh1Y2OK-VdsC&pg=PA129&dq=J-Lo:+The+Secret+Behind+Jennifer+Lopez\'s+Clib+to+the+Top#v=onepage&q=J-Lo%3A%20The%20Secret%20Behind%20Jennifer%20Lopez\'s%20Clib%20to%20the%20Top&f=false|isbn=978-0-8160-5832-7|date=November 30, 2005}}</ref> She excelled athletically rather than academically, competing in national track championships.<ref name=atriplethreat /> In 1984, at the age of fifteen, she began dating David Cruz, her first boyfriend.<ref name="Gallick2003"/>

While attending her final year of high school, Lopez learned about a film casting that was seeking several teenage girls for small roles. She auditioned and was cast in \'\'[[My Little Girl]]\'\' (1986), a low-budget film co-written and directed by Connie Kaiserman.<ref name="Rovi My Little Girl">{{cite web|first=Eleanor |last=Mannikka |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/my-little-girl-v34075|title=My Little Girl&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |work=[[AllRovi]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> Lopez acted as Myra, a young woman at a center for troubled girls. After she finished filming her role in the film, Lopez realized that she wanted to become a "famous movie star". To please her parents, though, she enrolled in [[Baruch College]], only to drop out after one semester. She told her parents her dream of becoming a movie star, but they insisted that it was a "really stupid" idea and that "no Latinos did that". The differences in opinions led Lopez to move out of their family home and into an apartment in [[Manhattan]]. During this period, Lopez performed in regional productions of the musicals: \'\'Jesus Christ Superstar\'\' and \'\'Oklahoma\'\'. From there, she was hired for the chorus in a \'\'Golden Musicals of Broadway\'\', which toured Europe for five months. She was unhappy with the role, as she was the only member of the chorus to not have a solo. She later got a job on the show \'\'Synchronicity\'\' in Japan, where she acted as a dancer, singer and a choreographer.<ref name="Gallick2003"/>

==Career==

===1991\xe2\x80\x9396: \'\'In Living Color\'\' and early film career===
Lopez was selected as a backup dancer for the [[New Kids on the Block]] in 1991 and performed with them during their performance of "[[Games (New Kids on the Block song)|Games]]" at the [[American Music Awards of 1991|18th Annual American Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Perricon|first=Kathleen|title=Jennifer Lopez dances with New Kids on the Block in 1991 video clip|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-05-10/entertainment/29547058_1_nkotb-music-video-new-kids|journal=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=June 22, 2012|date=May 10, 2011}}</ref> Shortly after, Lopez gained her first regular high-profile job as a [[Fly Girl]] dancer on the television program \'\'[[In Living Color]]\'\'. She applied for the job after one of the cast members was unavailable to continue with the show. Out of 2,000 applicants, Lopez made it to the finals. She was the runner-up, but eventually received the role when the winner was unable to accept the job. She moved with Cruz to Los Angeles to film the series and remained a regular cast member until 1993 when she decided to pursue a full-time acting career. Prior to leaving the show, Lopez briefly worked as a backup dancer for American recording artist [[Janet Jackson]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Morales|first=Ed|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/may/30/entertainment/ca-42339|title=It\'s Not La Vida Loca to Her|accessdate=January 30, 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|date=May 30, 1999}}</ref> Lopez was set to tour with Jackson on her [[Janet World Tour]] in late 1993, but backed out as she wanted to do her "own thing."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Living Single|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gCYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA100&dq=This+Is+Me...+Then+jennifer+lopez+million+copies&hl=en&sa=X&ei=s03xT_70N8z3rAG1hqG1Cg&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=This%20Is%20Me...%20Then%20jennifer%20lopez%20million%20copies&f=false|journal=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|publisher=[[InterMedia Partners]]|accessdate=July 6, 2012|page=100|date=May 2001}}</ref>

Lopez received her first professional acting gig in the [[direct-to-video]] drama film \'\'[[Lost in the Wild]]\'\' (1993), co-starring alongside [[Lindsay Wagner]] and [[Robert Loggia]].<ref name="Rovi Lost in the Wild">{{cite web|first=Sandra |last=Brennan |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/lost-in-the-wild-v160416 |title=Lost in the Wild&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |work=[[AllRovi]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> Later in 1993 Lopez signed a deal with [[CBS]] to co-star in the television series \'\'[[Second Chances (TV series)|Second Chances]]\'\'. The show was cancelled after airing only six episodes, due to its set being destroyed by the [[1994 Northridge earthquake]].<ref name="Became a superstar">{{cite web|url=http://www.canoe.ca/AllPop-LopezJennifer/010514_jen-sun.html |title=All Pop&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Artists |publisher=[[Qu\xc3\xa9becor M\xc3\xa9dia]] |work=\'\'[[Canoe.ca]]\'\' |date=May 14, 2001 |accessdate=July 13, 2012}}{{dead link|date=April 2013}}</ref> A spin-off of the series, titled \'\'[[Hotel Malibu]]\'\' was launched later that same year. It also ran for only a brief period of time and, like \'\'Second Chances\'\', received negative reviews.<ref name="Variety Second Chances">{{cite journal|first=Tony |last=Scott |title=Variety Reviews&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Second Chances&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Film Reviews |journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |date=December 5, 1993 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Ken |last= Tucker |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20219763,00.html |title=Hotel Malibu Review |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |date=August 5, 1994 |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> Lopez received her first major big-screen role in [[Gregory Nava]]\'s 1995 drama \'\'[[My Family (film)|My Family]]\'\', portraying Young Maria.<ref name="Rovi My Family">{{cite web|first=Matthew |last=Tobey |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/my-family-v133610|title=My Family&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |work=AllRovi |publisher=Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> The film, which stars [[Esai Morales]], [[Jimmy Smits]], and [[Edward James Olmos]], was critically acclaimed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/my_family|title=My Family (1995)|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]. [[Flixster]]}}</ref> Although her role was uncredited, Lopez received an [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Female]] nomination for her performance.<ref name="Rovi My Family"/> In November 1995, Lopez starred in \'\'[[Money Train (film)|Money Train]]\'\' alongside [[Wesley Snipes]] and [[Woody Harrelson]], as [[New York City Transit Police|New York City transit cops]]. The film faced negative reviews and is considered to be a [[box office bomb]]; with a budget of $68 million, the film grossed a total of $77 million worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/money_train |title=Money Train |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Flixster]] |accessdate=November 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1995/0MOTR.php |title=Money Train&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Box Office Data, Movie News, Cast Information |publisher=\'\'The Numbers\'\' |accessdate=January 22, 2012}}</ref> In August 1996, Lopez had a supporting role in the comedy \'\'[[Jack (1996 film)|Jack]]\'\'.<ref name="Rovi Jack">{{cite web|first=Clarke |last=Fountain |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/jack-v136486 |title=Jack&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |publisher=AllRovi. Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> With a budget of $45 million, the film grossed a total of $59 domestically.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=jack.htm |title=Jack (1996) |publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> The film received generally negative reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1072875-jack |title=Jack |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref>

===1997\xe2\x80\x9399: Breakthrough with \'\'Selena\'\' and \'\'On the 6\'\'===
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Jennifer Lopez as Selena.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Lopez earned widespread acclaim for her role as [[Selena]] in the 1997 biopic film [[Selena (film)|\'\'Selena\'\']].]] -->

In February 1997, Lopez starred alongside [[Jack Nicholson]] and [[Stephen Dorff]] in the [[neo-noir]] thriller \'\'[[Blood and Wine]]\'\'.<ref name="Rovi Blood and Wine">{{cite web|first=Sandra |last=Brennan |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/blood-and-wine-v136830 |title=Blood and Wine&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |publisher=AllRovi. Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> It was a commercial failure; the $26 million production budget was matched with a domestic gross of $1 million at the box office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1997/BLOOD.php |title=Blood and Wine&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Box Office Data, Movie News, Cast Information |publisher=\'\'The Numbers\'\' |accessdate=January 22, 2012}}</ref> Despite this, the film received generally positive reviews from critics.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/blood_and_wine |title=Blood and Wine |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |accessdate=November 29, 2011}}</ref> Lopez starred as the title role of the [[Selena]] biopic [[Selena (film)|of the same name]] in March.<ref name="Rovi Selena">{{cite web|first=Mark |last=Deming |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/selena-v154769 |title=Selena&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |publisher=AllRovi. Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> Despite having previously worked with the film\'s director on \'\'My Family\'\', Lopez was subjected to an intense auditioning process before she was cast in the film.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Associated Press|title=Lopez gets Selena role|journal=Dallas News|publisher=[[A. H. Belo Corporation]]|date=June 14, 1996}}</ref> With a production budget of $20 million, the film grossed a total of $35 million domestically.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1997/SELEN.php |title=Selena&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Box Office Data, News, Cast Information |publisher=\'\'The Numbers\'\' |accessdate=January 22, 2012}}</ref> [[Kenneth Turan]] of the \'\'[[Los Angeles Times]]\'\' stated that even in the "forgettable films" \'\'Money Train\'\', and \'\'Jack\'\', Lopez\'s "presence and ability made her seem just one role away from stardom" and with \'\'Selena\'\' she\'s "seized the opportunity and turned in an incandescent presentation that is especially strong during the film\'s numerous musical numbers". He concluded by calling the film not just a celebration of Selena\'s life, but also of the actress who portrayed her.<ref name="She\'s Seen in the Best Light">{{cite journal|author=Kenneth Turan  |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-03-21/entertainment/ca-40367_1_selena-quintanilla-perez |title=In the Authorized \'Selena,\' She\'s Seen in the Best Light|journal=[[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher=[[Tribune Company]] |date=October 10, 1995 |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref> After filming \'\'Selena\'\', Lopez was "really feeling [her] Latin roots" and cut a demo in Spanish.<ref>Mendible, M. (2007). "From bananas to buttocks: the Latina body in popular film and culture". Austin: [[University of Texas Press]]. Retrieved September 4, 2012.</ref> Lopez\'s manager then sent the song, titled "Vivir Sin Ti" (Living without You), to [[Sony Music Entertainment]]\'s [[Work Group]], who showed an interest in signing Lopez. [[Tommy Mottola]], the head of the label suggested to her that she sing in English instead.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=TxIEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA27&dq=jennifer+lopez+tommy+Mottola&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wQzwT9uPOJL0rAGXmJmSAg&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=jennifer%20lopez%20tommy%20Mottola&f=false |page=27 | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media]] | volume=119 | issn=0006-2510 | number=5 | title=On the Down Lo |date=February 3, 2007 |accessdate=July 1, 2012}}</ref>

In April, Lopez starred in the horror film \'\'[[Anaconda (film)|Anaconda]]\'\' alongside [[Ice Cube]] and [[Jon Voight]].<ref name="Rovi Anaconda">{{cite web|first=Mark |last=Deming |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/anaconda-v154826 |title=Anaconda&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |publisher=AllRovi. Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> With a production budget of $45 million, the film grossed a total of $137 million worldwide, becoming a commercial success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1997/ANACO.php |title=Anaconda&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Box Office Data, News, Cast Information |publisher=\'\'The Numbers\'\' |accessdate=January 22, 2012}}</ref> Lopez starred alongside [[Sean Penn]] and [[Billy Bob Thornton]] in the crime film \'\'[[U Turn (1997 film)|U Turn]]\'\' in October. The film, which is based on the novel \'\'Stray Dogs\'\' by [[John Ridley]], received generally positive reception from critics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/u-turn |title=U Turn |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref> In June, Lopez starred opposite [[George Clooney]] in \'\'[[Out of Sight (1998 film)|Out of Sight]]\'\', [[Steven Soderbergh]]\'s adaptation of [[Elmore Leonard]]\'s novel of the same name (1996).<ref name="Rovi Out of Sight">{{cite web|first=Bhob |last=Stewart |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/out-of-sight-v162749 |title=Out of Sight&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |publisher=AllRovi. Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> Cast as a deputy federal marshal who falls for a charming criminal, Lopez won rave reviews for her performance and became the first Latina actress to earn over $1 million for a role.<ref name="nydailynews1998">{{cite news|last=Kehr|first=Dave|title=Clooney & Lopez Are Lovable At First \'Sight\' George Plays A Bank Robber Who Steals Jennifer\'s Heart|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/nydn-features/clooney-lopez-lovable-sight-george-plays-bank-robber-steals-jennifer-heart-article-1.802614|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6HmBwDxi5 |archivedate=July 1, 2013|work=[[The New York Daily News]] | publisher=[[Mortimer Zuckerman]] |location=New York |accessdate=January 30, 2012|date=June 26, 1998}}</ref> With a production budget of $48 million, the film grossed a total of $78 million worldwide, becoming a moderate commercial success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1998/OUTOF.php |title=Out of Sight&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Box Office Data, Movie News, Cast Information |publisher=\'\'The Numbers\'\' |accessdate=January 22, 2012}}</ref> Lopez provided the voice of Azteca in the computer-animated film \'\'[[Antz]]\'\' in October.<ref name="Rovi Antz">{{cite web|first=Bhob |last=Stewart |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/antz-v173454 |title=Antz&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |publisher=AllRovi. Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> With a production budget of $105 million, the film grossed a total of $172 million worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=antz.htm |title=Antz (1998) |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]. Amazon|accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>

Lopez\'s debut single, "[[If You Had My Love]]", was released in May 1999, as she began to ready her first album.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Jennifer Lopez Readies First Album|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media]] | date=April 15, 1999 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=348&dat=20010130&id=0cYvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PzUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1737,9846654|title=Jennifer Lopez release proves to be a good Latin-soul album|author=Brian McCollum|journal=[[Rome News-Tribune]]|publisher=News Publishing Company|date=January 30, 2001|accessdate=January 15, 2010}}</ref> Lopez became the first artist to top the \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100 with their debut single since [[Britney Spears]] did so with her single, "[[...Baby One More Time]]", four months prior.<ref name="billboardno1issue">{{cite book|title=Billboard Magazine Vol. 111, No. 24|url=http://books.google.com.au/books?id=uw0EAAAAMBAJ&source=gbs_all_issues_r&cad=1|publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc.]]|accessdate=July 2, 2012|page=90|date=June 12, 1999}}</ref> During production of her debut album \'\'[[On the 6]]\'\', Lopez was aware that she received her recording contract on the premise of her looks and having an already established name in the entertainment industry, and wanted to prove she had musical talent.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1ZGMcUEvkyEC&pg=PA104 |title=Alicia Keys, Ashanti, Beyonc\xc3\xa9, Destiny\'s Child, Jennifer Lopez & Mya: Divas of the New Millennium |date=June 1, 2005 |accessdate=July 1, 2012|isbn=9780974977966|page=104|author=Stacy Deanne, Kelly Kenyatta, Natasha Lowery, Kwynn Sanders|publisher=Amber Books Publishing}}</ref> Prior to the debut of her music, critics wondered why she would take the risk of launching a music career. It was noted that: "If the album was a flop, not only would it embarrass Lopez, but it might even damage her career."<ref name="Latin Sensations">{{cite book|last=Marquez|first=Her\xc3\xb3n|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=q1BW88v0_zMC&pg=PA47 |title=Latin Sensations | page=47 |publisher=Twenty-First Century Books |date=January 1, 2001 |accessdate=July 3, 2012| isbn=9780822549932}}</ref> "[[Waiting for Tonight]]", the third single from \'\'On the 6\'\', is widely considered to be Lopez\'s best song.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stack|first=Tim|title=Jennifer Lopez: \'Waiting for Tonight\' was awesome...but it might be time to stop singing|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2009/11/23/jennifer-lopez-waiting-for-tonight-was-amazing-but-its-time-to-stop-singing/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=Time Inc.|accessdate=March 10, 2012|date=November 23, 2009}}</ref> Lopez\'s musical success came as a surprise to critics; its launch made the "popular actor even more popular". Both the music industry and the public became intrigued by "this woman who seemed to have so many different talents".<ref name="Latin Sensations"/> By the end of 1999, Lopez successfully converted herself from a film star to a pop star.<ref>{{cite news|title=Puff Daddy out on bail|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/579912.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=July 3, 2012|date=December 28, 1999}}</ref> She joined a select few in achieving this feat, becoming the first since [[Vanessa L. Williams|Vanessa Williams]] (1992) and [[Martika]] (1989).<ref name="billboardno1issue" />

===2000\xe2\x80\x9302: Continued film success, \'\'J.Lo\'\' and \'\'This Is Me... Then\'\'===
On February 23, 2000, Lopez, in the accompaniment of then-boyfriend [[Sean Combs]], wore a plunging exotic [[Green Versace dress of Jennifer Lopez|green Versace silk chiffon dress]] on the red carpet of the [[42nd Annual Grammy Awards]]. The dress "had a low-cut neck that extended several inches below her navel, where it was loosely fastened with a sparkly brooch and then opened out again," exposing her midriff and then as cut along the front of the legs like a bath robe.<ref name="PhillipsReay2002">{{cite book|editor1-last=Phillips|editor-first=Kim M.|editor2-last=Reay|editor2-first=Barry|title=Sexualities in history: a reader|chapter-url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Cz3bPMw_7h4C&pg=PA407|last=Barrera|first=Magdalena|chapter=Hottentot 2000: \'\'Jennifer Lopez and Her Butt\'\'|accessdate=May 16, 2011|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415929356|page=407}}</ref> The dress generated controversy and media attention, with images of Lopez in the dress being downloaded from the Grammy website over half a million times 24 hours after the event.<ref name="Lee2003">{{cite book|last=Lee|first=Michelle|title=Fashion victim: our love-hate relationship with dressing, shopping, and the cost of style|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=E3eBAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=May 16, 2011|date=February 11, 2003|publisher=Broadway Books|isbn=978-0-7679-1048-4|page=122}}</ref> Lopez was surprised by the enormous media coverage, declaring that she had no idea "it was going to become such a big deal".<ref name="OTD">{{cite web|url=http://onthisdayinfashion.com/?p=11475|title=J.Lo Helps Put Donatella\xe2\x80\x94and Herself\xe2\x80\x94on the Fashion Map in That Green Dress|publisher=On This Day in Fashion|date=February 23, 2001|last=Chambers|first=Rachel|accessdate=May 16, 2011}}</ref> Lopez returned to the big-screen in August, starring in the psychological thriller \'\'[[The Cell]]\'\' opposite [[Vincent D\'Onofrio]].<ref name="Rovi Cell">{{cite web|first=Mark |last=Deming |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/the-cell-v195764 |title=The Cell&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Cast, Reviews, Summary, and Awards |publisher=AllRovi. Rovi Corporation |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> With a production budget of $33 million, the film grossed a total of $104 million worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=cell.htm |title=The Cell (2000) |publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> The film received mixed reviews from critics, who stated that although it offers "disturbing, stunning eye candy", it is "undermined by a weak and shallow plotline that offers nothing new".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_cell_2000 |title=The Cell |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref>

During the process of creating her second album, Lopez decided to tweak her image as she began to develop into a [[sex symbol]]. She changed her stage name to J.Lo, a nickname she was given by her fans.<ref name="BookJLo">{{cite book|title=Divas of the new Millennium|year=2005|page=108|url=http://books.google.com/?id=1ZGMcUEvkyEC&pg=PA104&dq=Jennifer+Lopez+if+you+had+my+love#v=onepage&q&f=false|last1=Deanne|first1=Stacy|last2=Kenyatta|first2=Kelly|last3=Lowery|first3=Natasha|last4=Sanders|first4=Kwynn|isbn=9780974977966}}</ref> She subsequently named the album \'\'[[J.Lo (album)|J.Lo]]\'\', which was released on January 23, 2001. The record was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the United States [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]].<ref name=dethroned>{{cite web|title=Lopez Bows At No. 1; O-Town, Dream Debut High5|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/80647/lopez-bows-at-no-1-o-town-dream-debut-high5|work=Billboard|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=January 2001|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}</ref> This exact week, her romantic comedy film \'\'[[The Wedding Planner]]\'\' in which she starred opposite [[Matthew McConaughey]], opened atop the box office. This made her the first entertainer to have a number one film and album simultaneously.<ref name="timeTyrangiel">{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1093638,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090301064251/http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1093638,00.html |archivedate=March 1, 2009 |title=Jennifer Lopez |author=[[Josh Tyrangiel]] |accessdate=January 13, 2007 |work=Time |date=August 13, 2005}}</ref> The album initially spawned the hit singles "[[Love Don\'t Cost a Thing (song)|Love Don\'t Cost a Thing]]" and "[[Play (Jennifer Lopez song)|Play]]". April 2001 saw the public launch of [[J.Lo by Jennifer Lopez]], her own clothing and accessory company which specialized in clothing females of all shapes.<ref name="BookJLo" /> That May, Lopez starred in the romantic drama film \'\'[[Angel Eyes (film)|Angel Eyes]]\'\', which performed disappointingly at the box office and generated mixed reviews.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Lopez is simply out of sight in \'Angel Eyes\'|journal=[[The Detroit News]]|publisher=[[MediaNews Group]]|date=May 18, 2001}}</ref> In July, an urban oriented [[Murder, Inc.|"Murder]] remix" of the track "[[I\'m Real (Jennifer Lopez song)|I\'m Real]]" featuring [[Ja Rule]] was released. The remix reached number one on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100.<ref name=delivery>{{cite web|last=Reid |first=Shaheem |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1448513/ja-rule-helps-j-lo-deliver.jhtml |title=Ja Rule Helps J. Lo Deliver Hot Crossover Joints&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=[[MTV News]]. [[Viacom]] International, Inc. |date=August 29, 2001 |accessdate=May 4, 2012}}</ref> Following the [[September 11 attacks]], Lopez was heavily involved in charitable activities. Joining various other artists, she was featured on charitable singles such as "[[What\'s Going On (remix album)|What\'s Going On]]" and "[[El Ultimo Adios (The Last Goodbye)]]" which benefited people affected by the tragedy.<ref name=africa1>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1450237/ll-cool-j-u2s-edge-whats-going-on.jhtml |title=LL Cool J : LL Cool J, U2\'s Edge, More Join \'What\'s Going On\' Project&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Rhapsody Music Downloads |publisher=MTV News. Viacom International, Inc. |accessdate=March 23, 2012}}</ref><ref name="artistlist">{{cite news |url=http://www.discogs.com/Various-El-Ultimo-Adios-The-Last-Goodbye/release/2075383|title=Complete list of \'El Ultimo Adios\' artists |date=May 27, 2011 |publisher=Discogs |accessdate=February 17, 2010 | first=Stephanie | last=J Stone}}</ref>

To enhance Lopez\'s success in the urban market, promotion of \'\'J.Lo\'\' ended and a remix album titled \'\'[[J to tha L\xe2\x80\x93O! The Remixes]]\'\' was released on February 5, 2002.<ref name="Billboard Book of Number One Hits">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=PgGqNrqfrsoC&pg=PT931&lpg=PT931 |title=The Billboard Book of Number One Hits: Updated and Expanded 5Th Edition&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Fred Bronson&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Google Boeken |publisher=[[Google Books]] |accessdate=April 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lopez|first=Jennifer|title=J to Tha L-O!: The Remixes|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/j-to-tha-l-o!-the-remixes-mw0000658032|work=\'\'[[AllMusic]]\'\'. \'\'Allrovi Corporation\'\'|accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> Its lead single was "[[Ain\'t It Funny (Murder Remix)]]", which also featured Ja Rule, which reached number one in the United States. The remix album debuted at the summit of the \'\'Billboard\'\' 200, becoming the first to do so.<ref>{{cite web|last=Goodman|first=Abbey|title=Jennifer Lopez Kicks The Boys to the Curb On Next Week\'s Albums Chart Singer\'s remix album knocks Alan Jackson, Creed from top of Billboard 200|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1452273/jennifer-lopez-tops-albums-chart.jhtml|publisher=MTV News. Viacom International, Inc.|accessdate=January 29, 2012|date=February 13, 2002}}</ref> It is the third highest selling remix album in history, with sales of one and a half million in the United States.<ref name="album sales">{{cite web|last=Trust|first=Gary|title=Ask Billboard: Analyzing \'American Idol\'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/955571/ask-billboard-analyzing-american-idol|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=January 29, 2012|date=October 1, 2010}}</ref> \'\'J to tha L\xe2\x80\x93O! The Remixes\'\' spawned two other singles, "[[I\'m Gonna Be Alright]]" and "[[Alive (Jennifer Lopez song)|Alive]]", a ballad co-written by her husband at the time, Cris Judd. April 2002 saw Lopez open her restaurant, \'\'Madr\xc3\xa8\'s\'\'.<ref name="BookJLo" />

In May 2002, Lopez starred in the thriller film \'\'[[Enough (film)|Enough]]\'\' as a woman named Slim who flees her home after being abused by her husband. The film grossed a modest $52 million at the box office,<ref>{{cite web|title=Enough (2002)|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=enough.htm|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> though garnered lukewarm reviews, despite being dubbed a "kick-butt, female empowerment" movie.<ref>{{cite news|last=Schaefer|first=Stephen|title=Movies: Singer-actress Jennifer Lopez shows her strength in thriller `Enough\'|newspaper=[[Boston Herald]]|publisher=Herald Media, Inc.|date=May 19, 2002|location=Boston}}</ref> Filming \'\'Enough\'\' required an overworked Lopez to practice [[Krav Maga]], and despite being at the height of her fame at the time, she suffered a [[nervous breakdown]] while on set. Lopez recalled years later feeling "sick and weird", refusing therapeutic help or medication. She confessed, "I was like&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 I don\'t want to move, I don\'t want to talk, I don\'t want to do anything."<ref>{{cite news|last=Singh|first=Anita|title=Jennifer Lopez: I had a nervous breakdown|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/3152788/Jennifer-Lopez-I-had-a-nervous-breakdown.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=October 20, 2012|date=October 7, 2008}}</ref> In September, Lopez released her first fragrance, [[Glow by JLo]]. It performed strongly despite predictions that it would fail, and became America\'s top-selling fragrance.<ref name=HS>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qki6zZ4aWd0C&pg=PA6-IA135&dq=Glow+by+JLo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WAXxT9-fCYjPqgHO_ZDNDQ&ved=0CEUQ6AEwAjgU#v=onepage&q=Glow%20by%20JLo&f=false |title=Beauty Imagined:A History of the Global Beauty Industry|first=Geoffrey|last=Jones |publisher=Oxford University Press|date=February 25, 2010 |accessdate=October 22, 2012}}</ref>

The month of her engagement to actor Ben Affleck saw the release of her third studio album, \'\'[[This Is Me... Then]]\'\', which was dedicated to him. It spawned the internationally successful singles "[[Jenny from the Block]]" and "[[All I Have (song)|All I Have]]". The album itself, which featured multiple love songs,<ref name=dedication>{{cite news|title=J-Lo disc declares her love|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/11/27/1038274342213.html|newspaper=[[The Age]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=January 29, 2012|date=November 27, 2002|location=Melbourne, Australia}}</ref> performed strongly, having sold over two and a half million copies in the United States.<ref name="album sales" /> December 2002 saw Lopez star opposite [[Ralph Fiennes]] in the romantic comedy film \'\'[[Maid in Manhattan]]\'\'. She played Marisa Ventura, a struggling single mother who lives in the Bronx and makes her living cleaning rooms in a super-luxurious Manhattan hotel. Marisa gets mistaken for a socialite by a princely politician, who she falls in love with.<ref>Gary Susman (December 9, 2002). [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,396721_12,00.html "Keeping It Reel"]. \'\'[[Entertainment Weekly]]\'\'. Retrieved June 24, 2009.</ref> With a production budget of $55 million, the film grossed $155 million at the box office worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maid in Manhattan|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=maidinmanhattan.htm|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> \'\'[[The New York Times]]\'\' compared the film\'s storyline to her song "Jenny from the Block".<ref>A.O. Scott (December 13, 2002). [http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9A02E2D7133AF930A25751C1A9649C8B63 "Film Review; Puttin\' Down Mop, Puttin\' On the Ritz"]. \'\'[[The New York Times]]\'\'. ([[The New York Times Company]]). Retrieved June 24, 2009.</ref>

===2003\xe2\x80\x9305: Film disappointments and \'\'Rebirth\'\'===
In August 2003, Lopez starred opposite Affleck in the romantic comedy \'\'[[Gigli]]\'\'. With a production budget of $54 million, the film grossed a total of $7 million worldwide, becoming a [[box office bomb]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Gigli (2003)|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=gigli.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> The film received universally negative reviews from film critics, who deemed it to be "bizarre and clumsily plotted".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/gigli |title=Gigli |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |accessdate=January 12, 2013}}</ref> \'\'Gigli\'\' is often considered to be [[List of films considered the worst|one of the worst films of all time]].<ref name=flopgigli>{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Charles|title="Gligli" Jennifer Lopez|url=http://www.salon.com/2003/07/30/gigli/|publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]. Salon Media Group|accessdate=January 30, 2012|date=July 30, 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Reviews are sour, but \'Gigli\' fans like the eye candy|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2003-08-03-gigli-reax_x.htm|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]], Inc.|accessdate=January 30, 2012|author=Julie Gordon and Steven Snyder|date=August 3, 2003}}</ref>

[[File:JenniferLopez.jpg|thumb|upright|Lopez in 2004]]
In March 2004, Lopez had a minor role in the film \'\'[[Jersey Girl (2004 film)|Jersey Girl]]\'\', alongside Affleck. Her character, Gertrude Steiney, dies during childbirth within the first 15 minutes of the film. From the intense media scrutiny following the couple\'s break-up, it was noted that "they may need to put Lopez in a coffin on the poster if they want anyone to come".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/4580539/ns/today-entertainment/t/marketing-jersey-girl-post-gigli-world/#.UHM3v03A-So |title=Marketing \xe2\x80\x98Jersey Girl\xe2\x80\x99 in a post-\xe2\x80\x98Gigli\xe2\x80\x99 world |publisher=MSNBC |date=March 29, 2004 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> With a production budget of $35 million, the film was a commercial failure, earning a total of $36 million at the box office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=jerseygirl.htm |title=Jersey Girl (2004) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> The film, however, received generally positive reviews from critics, despite being "full of cloyingly sentimental cliches".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/jersey_girl |title=Jersey Girl |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> In October, Lopez co-starred alongside [[Richard Gere]] in the drama \'\'[[Shall We Dance? (2004 film)|Shall We Dance?]]\'\', a re-make of the [[Shall We Dance? (1996 film)|1996 Japanese film of the same title]]. With a production budget of $50 million, the film grossed a total of $170 million worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=shallwedance.htm |title=Shall We Dance (2004) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=February 24, 2005 |accessdate=October 7, 2009}}</ref> It received generally positive reviews from critics, although it was noted that it "loses the nuances of the original", with the loss of cultural context and the addition of high-profile celebrities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/shall_we_dance |title=Shall We Dance |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref>

In 2004, during low-key visits to the [[Children\'s Hospital Los Angeles]], which Lopez is an avid support of, she befriended eleven-year-old cancer patient Paige Patterson. Patterson attended the inaugural Noche de Ni\xc3\xb1os gala for the hospital in which Lopez was presented with an award, however the morning after became even more sick and died in November 2004. Lopez has stated that Patterson made her realize why her charity work is important.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news-article/lopez.s-cancer-hero-dies |title=Jennifer Lopez&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Lopez\'s Cancer Hero Dies&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Contactmusic News |publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]] |date=January 11, 2005 |accessdate=July 10, 2012}}</ref> Lopez dedicated \'\'[[Rebirth (Jennifer Lopez album)|Rebirth]]\'\', her fourth studio album, to Patterson.<ref name="Album Credits">{{cite AV media notes |title=Rebirth |others=Jennifer Lopez |year=2005 |type=Booklet |publisher=[[Epic Records]], a division of [[Sony Music Entertainment]] |location=New York City}}</ref> According to Lopez, \'\'Rebirth\'\' "came about because I was on such a roller-coaster ride, that was my career from my first album to my last album, and I did a bunch of movie projects in between. I finally took some time just for myself, and [when] I came back, this was the first project I did. I felt like it was a new beginning for me, like I was, in a way, reborn. I was where I was when I made my first album".<ref name=virgin>{{cite web|last=Goodman |first=Abbey |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1497737/jennifer-lopez-on-rebirth-new-beginning.jhtml |title=Jennifer Lopez Calls Rebirth \'A New Beginning\'&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93 Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=MTV News. Viacom International, Inc.|date=March 3, 2005 |accessdate=April 29, 2012}}</ref> Tracy Hopkins of NBC\'s [[NBC|Today Music]] noted that after "fawning" over Affleck on \'\'This Is Me... Then\'\'", Lopez "wisely keeps her love life out of the spotlight" on \'\'Rebirth\'\' and only references her relationship with Anthony on a few tracks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msnbc.msn.com/id/7047411/site/todayshow/ns/today-entertainment/t/rebirth-its-best-when-j-lo-keeps-it-dance-floor/#.T52Zv6sV3js |title=\xe2\x80\x98Rebirth\xe2\x80\x99 at its best on dance floor |publisher=MSNBC |date=February 3, 2005 |accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref>

In May, Lopez starred alongside [[Jane Fonda]] in the romantic comedy \'\'[[Monster-in-Law]]\'\'. She received $15&nbsp;million for her role as Charlie, an artist who is pitted against her fiance\'s mother when she does not accept her as being the right woman for her son.<ref name=fonda>{{cite news|last=Lumenick|first=Lou|title=So Fonda The Fight|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|date=March 13, 2005|page=48}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lowe|first=Kinsey R.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/may/16/entertainment/et-boxoffice16|title=\'Monster-in-Law\' gets a cheery reception; The comedy with Jane Fonda and Jennifer Lopez debuts at No.1 on another weekend off the pace set in 2004.|accessdate=January 30, 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|date=May 16, 2005|location=Los Angeles, California}}</ref> With a production budget of $43 million, the film grossed a total of $155 million worldwide.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=monsterinlaw.htm | title = Monster-in-Law (2005) | publisher = Box Office Mojo}}</ref> The film received generally negative reviews from film critics, who stated although Fonda "steals the show" in her "return to the screen", the "tired" script and "flimsy performances" make \'\'Monster-in-Law\'\' fall "flat".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/monsterinlaw |title=Monster-in-Law |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes. Flixster |date=June 23, 2011 |accessdate=August 8, 2012}}</ref> In August, Lopez starred alongside [[Robert Redford]] and [[Morgan Freeman]] in \'\'[[An Unfinished Life]]\'\', a drama film based on the novel of the same name. The film was a commercial failure, only grossing $18 million worldwide with its production budget of $30 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=unfinishedlife.htm |title=An Unfinished Life (2005) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=July 10, 2012}}</ref>

===2006\xe2\x80\x9309: \'\'Como Ama una Mujer\'\' and \'\'Brave\'\'===
\'\'[[Bordertown (2006 film)|Bordertown]]\'\', a film based on the [[Female homicides in Ciudad Ju\xc3\xa1rez]], made its premiere at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] on May 18, 2006.
