 ****** Dynasty (band)

b'{{For|the British singer named Linda Carriere|Loose Ends (band)}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name = Dynasty
| image  = 
| background = group_or_band
| alias = 
| origin = [[Los Angeles, California]]
| genre = [[soul music|Soul]], [[funk]]
| years_active = 1978\xe2\x80\x931989
| label = [[SOLAR Records]]
| associated_acts = [[The Whispers]], [[Shalamar]], [[Loose Ends (band)|Loose Ends]], [[The Sylvers]]
| past_members = [[Leon Sylvers III]]<br>Nidra Beard<br>Linda Carriere<br>Kevin Spencer<br>William Shelby<br>Richard Randolph
}}

\'\'\'Dynasty\'\'\' was an [[United States|American]] [[musical ensemble|band]], based in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], created by [[record producer|producer]] and [[SOLAR Records]] [[record label|label]] head [[Dick Griffey]], and record producer [[Leon Sylvers III]]. The band was known for their [[dance music|dance]]/[[pop music|pop]] numbers during the late 1970s and 1980s. Keyboardist Kevin Spencer and [[singer|vocalists]] Nidra Beard and Linda Carriere originally comprised the group.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco">{{cite web|title=SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco|url=http://www.disco-disco.com/labels/solar.shtml|website=disco-disco.com|publisher=Disco-Disco|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref>

==History==
Dynasty was essentially the brainchild of Griffey and producer Sylvers- a former member of the [[The Sylvers|Sylvers]] family group- who had achieved much popularity in the early to mid-1970s. A principal architect of the [[SOLAR Records|SOLAR]] sound, Sylvers had become the in-house producer in 1978 for the label (whose name stood for "Sound Of Los Angeles Records\') and it was in this capacity that he brought the members of Dynasty together. The group consisted of three young performers; vocalists Nidra Beard, Linda Carriere and keyboardist Kevin Spencer.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/>

Beard and Carriere first became friends during the winter of 1972, when Carriere moved from [[New Orleans]] for college.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> Both were frequent visitors to \'Maverick\'s Flat\', a popular soul/pop [[nightclub]] in Los Angeles. The owner of Maverick\'s Flat, [[John Daniels (actor)|John Daniels]], was in the process of putting together a new group \'DeBlanc\' and both young singers became members.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> For two years, they toured with the DeBlanc, throughout the major cities of Europe, Japan, Canada, and United States. When DeBlanc broke up in 1975, some of the original members (including Beard and Carriere) formed a new group called Starfire.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> For one successful year, Starfire performed essentially in the United States, with a few key dates in Finland and Iran. After the tour, the group decided to disband. Around this time Beard developed a strong relationship with Sylvers. She was, at that time, performing with [[Capitol records|Capitol]] recording artists, [[The Sylvers]] as a fill-in on live dates for the female Sylvers who were minors.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> This new association proved beneficial to both Beard and Carriere, as Sylvers introduced each to Griffey.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> Spencer first met Sylvers when he appeared at the Sylvers\' [[Palos Verdes]] home, unannounced, to audition as bass player for the Sylvers. It was that introduction coupled with Spencer\'s performance dates with the Sylvers that cemented what both Sylvers and Griffey needed for their new group.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> Work then began on Dynasty\'s first album.

The band\'s debut album \'\'[[Your Piece of the Rock]]\'\', released in 1979, yielded the band\'s first R&B hit, "I Don\'t Want to Be a Freak (But I Can\'t Help Myself)". The track peaked at #20 in the [[UK Singles Chart]] in late 1979.<ref name="British Hit Singles & Albums"/>

During the late 1970s to mid-1980s, recordings by SOLAR groups such as [[The Whispers]], [[Shalamar]], [[Midnight Star]], and Dynasty, would become hits, and although Dynasty was not as successful as The Whispers or Shalamar, they did enjoy a few chart entries.

\'\'[[Adventures in the Land of Music]]\'\', released in 1980, was Dynasty\'s second album. The set contained their biggest hit, "I\'ve Just Begun to Love You" (which peaked at #6 on the [[United States|US]] \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]]; #87 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]]; and #51 in the [[United Kingdom|UK]]),<ref name="British Hit Singles & Albums"/><ref>{{cite book |title= Top R&B/Hip-Hop Singles: 1942-2004|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=178}}</ref> as well as the songs, "Do Me Right" and "Groove Control." The three songs combined to reach number five on the US [[Hot Dance Club Songs|Dance]] chart.<ref>{{cite book |title= Hot Dance/Disco: 1974-2003|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=85}}</ref> The title track would provide the key [[sampling (music)|samples]] for [[Camp Lo]]\'s "Luchini AKA This Is It", [[Angie Stone]]\'s "Lovers\' Ghetto", [[Terri Walker]]\'s "This Is My Time", [[Tha\' Rayne]]\'s "Kiss Me", [[Brooke Valentine]]\'s "Long As You Come Home", Rashad\'s "Sweet Misery", [[Antiloop]]\'s "Catch Me", [[Jadakiss]]\'s "How I Feel", HaLo\'s "Follow Me", [[Rushden & Diamonds (music group)]]\' "Lil\' Bits", DSP\'s "Tisztelet a Kiv\xc3\xa9telnek", and [[Wiz Khalifa]]\'s "Won\'t Land."

Sylvers joined the group in 1981, but his presence did not elevate their success. That year they released their third album, \'\'[[The Second Adventure]]\'\'.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> Although it did produce two top forty R&B hits, "Here I Am" and "Love in the Fast Lane", the album was largely overlooked. Sylvers and Beard were briefly married during the early 1980s.

Three more albums followed, 1982\'s \'\'[[Right Back at Cha!]]\'\', 1986\'s \'\'[[Daydreamin\' (Dynasty album)|Daydreamin\']]\'\', 1988\'s \'\'Out of Control\'\'.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> \'\'Right Back at Cha!\'\' had two US singles released; "Check It Out" and "Strokin\'". Only "Check It Out" saw chart action and the album reached in the middle of the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]].  In the UK the label went for two other singles; "The Only One" and "Does That Ring A Bell", where the latter entered the UK Singles Chart peaking at #53.<ref name="British Hit Singles & Albums">{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Roberts
| year= 2006
| title= British Hit Singles & Albums
| edition= 19th
| publisher= Guinness World Records Limited 
| location= London
| isbn= 1-904994-10-5
| page= 174}}</ref> The band returned again in 1986 with the album \'\'Daydreamin\' \'\', but by this time Carriere was no longer part of the group and Nidra Beard was using her Sylvers surname. Their final studio release was 1988\'s \'\'Out of Control\'\', but hit singles had dried up.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/> Curiously, the \'\'Out of Control\'\' album had exactly the same cover as the preceding album (\'\'Daydreamin\' \'\') and also included several of the same tracks.  The singles "Don\'t Waste My Time" and "Tell Me (Do You Want My Love)?" were taken off the album. Even though new SOLAR producers, [[L.A. Reid]] and  [[Babyface (musician)|Babyface]], were brought in to produce the album, the group could not revive their earlier glory and disbanded soon afterwards.<ref name="SOLAR Records @ Disco-Disco"/>  Although the group had disbanded, they would later appear as backing vocalists on [[gospel music|gospel]] artist and label-mate Juanita G. Hines\' 1994 album \'\'Jesus, My Wonderful Friend\'\'.

Beard, who had written much of Dynasty\'s material, continued as a songwriter. Her songs appeared on albums by Shalamar, The Whispers, [[7th Wonder]], [[911 (band)|911]], and LaRue. Carriere continued as a background vocalist. Keyboardist-singer Spencer returned to studio work and can be heard on recordings by [[Carrie Lucas]], Shalamar, The Whispers, Tin Harris, and [[Gladys Knight & the Pips]]. Sylvers went on to have a successful career as the producer and songwriter of such artists as [[Howard Hewett]], [[Ahmad Jamal]], [[The Brothers Johnson]], [[Glenn Jones]] and [[Blackstreet]].

The band has recently reissued most of their albums on [[Compact disc|CD]], through Canadian [[independent record label]], [[Unidisc Music Inc.]].

==Band members==
* [[Leon Sylvers III]]  - bass
* Kevin Spencer - Keyboard Synths/ Vocal
* William Shelby - keyboards/vocals
* Nidra Beard - vocals
* Linda Carriere - vocals
* Richard Randolph - Guitar

==Discography==
* \'\'[[Your Piece of the Rock]]\'\' (1979)
* \'\'[[Adventures in the Land of Music]]\'\' (1980)
* \'\'[[The Second Adventure]]\'\' (1981)
* \'\'[[Right Back at Cha!]]\'\' (1982)
* \'\'[[Daydreamin\' (Dynasty album)|Daydreamin\']]\'\' (1986)
* \'\'Out of Control\'\' (1988)

 ****** Earth, Wind %26 Fire

b'\'\'Not to be confused with [[Earth and Fire]]\'\'
{{For|the elements|classical element}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name                = Earth, Wind & Fire
| image               = Earth, Wind & Fire (2).jpg
| caption             = Earth, Wind & Fire performing in 2009
| landscape           = Yes
| background          = group_or_band
| origin              = [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S.
| genre               = [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[funk]], [[jazz]], [[disco]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[Gospel music|gospel]], [[psychedelic soul]]
| years_active        = 1969\xe2\x80\x93present
|associated_acts      =  [[Ramsey Lewis]], [[The Pharaohs]], [[Charles Stepney]], [[Phenix Horns]], [[The Emotions]], [[Caldera (band)|Caldera]], [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]], [[Deniece Williams]], [[Toto (band)|Toto]]
| label               = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], [[American Recording Company|ARC]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Legacy Recordings|Legacy]], [[Sanctuary Records|Sanctuary]]
| website             = {{URL|http://www.earthwindandfire.com}}
| current_members     = [[Maurice White]]<br />[[Verdine White]]<br />[[Philip Bailey]]<br />[[Ralph Johnson (musician)|Ralph Johnson]]<br />Reggie Young<br />Gary Bias<br />B. David Whitworth<br />Myron McKinley<br />[[John Paris]]<br />Bobby Burns. Jr<br />Greg "G-Mo" Moore<br />[[Kim Johnson]]<br />Morris O\' Connor<br />[[Philip Bailey|Philip Bailey Jr.]]
| past_members        = Albert Wongdin Sundinberg (pianist  <Br /> Kevin Hejsak mackberg <Br /> Becky Avilla<br /> [[JS (Johnson Sisters)|Krystal Bailey]]<br />Michael Beal<br />Yackov Ben Israel<br />[[Roland Bautista]] (deceased)<br />Jeff Bowen<br />[[Robert Brookins]]<br />[[Raymond Lee Brown]]<br />Lily Brown<br />Gordon Campbell<br />[[Jessica Cleaves]] (deceased)<br />Jenarth Davaberg<br />Rahmlee Michael Davis<br />[[Daniel de los Reyes]]<br />Derek Dickson<br /> Leslie Drayton<br /> [[Larry Dunn]]<br />[[Sonny Emory]]<br />[[Wade Flemons]] (deceased)<br />Johnny Graham<br />Bobby Gonzales<br />Cory Grover<br />Michael Harris<br />Richard Howell<br />John Johnson<br />[[Ronnie Laws]]<br />Samuel Lyday<br />Evan Marzouk<br />[[Al McKay]]<br />Eamon Magdoubi<br />Mike McKnight<br />Gary L. Morgan<br />[[Don Myrick]] (deceased)<br />Bill Parnell<br />[[Morris Pleasure]]<br />Fred Ravel<br />[[Sheldon Reynolds (guitarist)|Sheldon Reynolds]]<br />David Romero<br />[[Louis Satterfield]] (deceased)<br />Gary Scheatzle<br />Sherry Scott<br />Dick Smith<br />Beloyd Taylor<br />Vance Taylor<br />Alexander Thomas<br />Chris Turner<br />Elisia Ware<br />Chester Washington<br />[[Drake_(rapper)|Drake Waterston]]<br [[Donny Hathaway]] (deceased)/>Don Whitehead<br />Fred White<br />[[Andrew Woolfolk]]<br />George Duke (deceased)
}}

\'\'\'Earth, Wind & Fire\'\'\' is an American band that has spanned the musical genres of [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[funk]], [[jazz]], [[disco]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Latin music|Latin]], [[African popular music|African]] and [[Gospel music|gospel]].  They are one of the most successful and critically acclaimed bands of the twentieth century.<ref name="ALLMUSIC" /><ref name="Maurice White Biography">{{cite web|url={{Songwriters Hall of Fame|class=exhibits|id=c6033|pure_url=yes}}|title= Maurice White Biography|publisher=http://www.songwritershalloffame.org}}</ref>\'\'  [[Rolling Stone]]\'\' has described them as "innovative, precise yet sensual, calculated yet galvanizing" and has also declared that the band "changed the sound of black pop".<ref name=rolling>{{cite web | url = http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/earthwindfire/biography | title = Earth, Wind & Fire: Biography: Rolling Stone |work=Rolling Stone |accessdate =April 18, 2009}}</ref> 
 
Also known as \'\'\'EWF\'\'\', the band was founded in Chicago by [[Maurice White]] in 1969.  Other members have included [[Philip Bailey]], [[Verdine White]], [[Ralph Johnson (musician)|Ralph Johnson]], [[Larry Dunn]], [[Al McKay]] and [[Andrew Woolfolk]].  The band has received 20 [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nominations; they won six as a group and two of its members, Maurice White and Bailey, won separate individual awards.<ref name="Maurice White Biography"/>  Earth, Wind & Fire have 12 [[American Music Award]]s nominations and four awards.<ref name="Maurice White Biography"/>  They have been inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]], the [[Vocal Group Hall of Fame]], received a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]], and sold over 100 million records, making them one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|world\'s best-selling bands of all time]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aspentimes.com/entertainment/12776964-113/fire-wind-band-funk|title=Shining Stars: Earth Wind & Fire at Labor Day Experience|publisher=[[The Aspen Times]]|first=Andrew|last=Travers|date=August 29, 2014|accessdate=October 3, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p2199|pure_url=yes}}|title= Philip Bailey Biography|publisher= allmusic.com|first=Ed|last=Hogan}}</ref><ref name=allmusic>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p5818|pure_url=yes}}|title= Maurice White Biography |publisher= allmusic.com|first=Ed|last=Hogan}}</ref><ref name=ROCKHALL>
{{cite web|url=http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/earth-wind-fire|title= Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductee Earth, Wind & Fire|publisher=rockhall.com}}</ref><ref name="Maurice White Biography"/><ref name=VOCALGROUP>{{cite web|url=http://www.vocalgroup.org/inductees/earth_wind_fire.html|title= Vocal Group Hall of Fame Inductee Earth, Wind & Fire|publisher= vocalgroup.org}}
</ref>  Five members of Earth, Wind & Fire were also inducted into the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]]: Maurice White, Philip Bailey, Verdine White, Larry Dunn and Al McKay.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Songwriters Hall of Fame|class=exhibits|id=c6029|pure_url=yes}}|title= Earth, Wind & Fire Biography|publisher=http://www.songwritershalloffame.org}}</ref>  The music industry and fans have bestowed Lifetime Achievement honors from the [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers]] (Rhythm & Soul Heritage Award \xe2\x80\x93 2002), [[NAACP]] (Hall of Fame \xe2\x80\x93 1994) and the [[BET Awards]] (Lifetime Achievement Award \xe2\x80\x93 2002).<ref name="Maurice White Biography"/>

Earth, Wind & Fire is known for the dynamic sound of their [[horn section]], their energetic and elaborate stage shows, and the interplay between the contrasting vocals of Philip Bailey\'s [[falsetto]] and Maurice White\'s [[tenor]].<ref name=ALLMUSIC>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p4156|pure_url=yes}}|title= Earth, Wind & Fire Biography|publisher= allmusic.com|first=Steve|last=Huey}}</ref> The [[thumb piano|kalimba]] (African thumb piano) is played on all of the band\'s albums.<ref name = "Light-1993">[[The Eternal Dance (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|\'\'The Eternal Dance\'\']], 1993, THE KALIMBA STORY By Alan Light \xe2\x80\x93 Rolling Stone from "The Eternal Dance" box-set.</ref>  In the 1970s and early 1980s, the band had many hits, including "[[Shining Star (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Shining Star]]", "[[That\'s the Way of the World (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|That\'s the Way of the World]]", "[[Devotion (song)|Devotion]]", "[[Reasons (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Reasons]]", "[[Sing a Song (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Sing a Song]]", "[[Can\'t Hide Love]]", "[[Getaway (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Getaway]]", "[[Fantasy (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Fantasy]]", "Love\'s Holiday", "[[September (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|September]]", "[[Boogie Wonderland]]", "[[After the Love Has Gone]]", and "[[Let\'s Groove]]".  Two Earth, Wind & Fire classic songs have been inducted into the [[Grammy Hall of Fame Award|Grammy Hall of Fame]]: "That\xe2\x80\x99s the Way of the World" (2004) and "Shining Star" (2007).<ref name="Maurice White Biography"/>

The band is also known as having been the first African-American act to sell out [[Madison Square Garden]] and to receive the MSG Gold Ticket Award.<ref name="Maurice White Biography"/>  President [[Barack Obama]] invited Earth, Wind & Fire to perform at the [[White House]] for the first social event of the new administration.<ref name="Maurice White Biography"/>

==History==

===Beginnings (1969\xe2\x80\x931971)===
In 1969, [[Maurice White]], a former session drummer for [[Chess Records]] and former member of the [[Ramsey Lewis Trio]], joined two friends in Chicago, [[Wade Flemons]] and Don Whitehead, as a songwriting team composing songs and commercials in the Chicago area. The three friends got a recording contract with [[Capitol Records|Capitol]]; they called themselves the "Salty Peppers" and had a marginal hit in the Midwestern area called "La La La".<ref name=salty>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p199633|pure_url=yes}}|title=The Salty Peppers \xe2\x80\x93 Overview|publisher=allmusic.com|accessdate=May 18, 2009}}</ref>

The Salty Peppers\' second single, "Uh Huh Yeah", did not fare as well, and Maurice moved from Chicago to Los Angeles. He then added to the band singer Sherry Scott<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myspace.com/sherryscottjazz|title=Sherry Scott|publisher=myspace.com|accessdate=May 18, 2009}}</ref> and percussionist Yackov Ben Israel, both from Chicago, and then asked his younger brother [[Verdine White|Verdine]] how he would feel about heading out to the West Coast. On June 6, 1970, Verdine left Chicago to join the band as their new bassist. Maurice began shopping demo tapes of the band, featuring [[Donny Hathaway]], around to different record labels and the band was thus signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]].<ref name=salty /><ref name = "Nathan-1993">[[The Eternal Dance (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|\'\'The Eternal Dance\'\']], 1993, Liner notes & text by [[David Nathan (music critic)|David Nathan]].</ref>

===Formation and early years (1971\xe2\x80\x931973)===
[[File:Lastdaysandtimealbum.jpg|thumb|left|The cover of 1972 album [[Last Days and Time]]]]
Maurice\'s [[astrological sign]], [[Sagittarius (astrology)|Sagittarius]], has a primary [[Classical element|elemental]] quality of [[Fire (classical element)|Fire]] and seasonal qualities of [[Earth (classical element)|Earth]] and [[Air (classical element)|Air]], according to [[Astrology and the classical elements#Triplicities by season|classical triplicities]]. (Sagittarius in the northern hemisphere occurs in the autumn, whose element is earth, and in the southern hemisphere, it is spring, whose element is air. Hence the omission of [[Water (classical element)|Water]], the fourth [[classical element]].) Based on this, he changed the band\'s name, to "Earth, Wind & Fire". Maurice ([[mbira]]) held further auditions in L.A. adding Michael Beale on guitar, Chester Washington on [[Reed (instrument)|reeds]], and Leslie Drayton on trumpet; Drayton also served as the group\'s musical arranger. Trombonist Alex Thomas and electric pianist/vocalist Wade Flemons completed the then ten-man EWF lineup.<ref name="ALLMUSIC" /><ref name=chuck>{{cite web|url=http://www.chuckthewriter.com/ewf.html|title=Earth Wind and Fire I\'ll Write a Song for You|publisher=Goldmine Magazine|first= Miller|last=Chuck|accessdate=May 6, 2009}}</ref>

The band\'s self-titled debut album, \'\'[[Earth, Wind & Fire (album)|Earth, Wind, & Fire]],\'\' was released in February 1971 to critical acclaim, as was November 1971\'s \'\'[[The Need of Love]]\'\'. Both albums were produced by [[Joe Wissert]] and a single, from \'\'The Need of Love\'\' called "I Think About Lovin\' You", with Sherry Scott on lead vocals, provided EWF with their first Top 40 R&B hit. In 1971, the group also recorded the [[Sweet Sweetback\'s Baadasssss Song (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] of the [[Melvin Van Peebles]] film \'\'[[Sweet Sweetback\'s Baadasssss Song]]\'\'.<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

The soundtrack was recorded at Paramount Recording Studios on [[Santa Monica Boulevard]] and released on [[Stax Records]]. The band developed a growing popularity on college campuses but, in spite of this, some members of EWF started to become restless and the band broke up after having been together less than six months. With only Verdine left, Maurice decided to re-form the group.

In 1972, Maurice added vocalist [[Jessica Cleaves]], a former member of the [[R&B]] group [[The Friends of Distinction]], [[Ronnie Laws]] on the [[flute]] and saxophone, rhythm guitarist [[Roland Bautista]], keyboardist [[Larry Dunn]], percussionist [[Ralph Johnson (musician)|Ralph Johnson]], and vocalist and Denver native [[Philip Bailey]] to the group. Warner Brothers didn\'t know how to promote this new combo as the only other funk band on their label was [[Charles Wright & the Watts 103rd Street Rhythm Band]].<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

The band successfully auditioned for managers Bob Cavallo and Joe Ruffalo. Cavallo\'s management of [[John Sebastian]] led to a series of gigs as the opening act for the pop/folk singer and [[The Lovin\' Spoonful]] founder. A performance at New York\'s [[Rockefeller Center]] introduced EWF to [[Clive Davis]], then the President of [[Columbia Records]]. Davis was very impressed with the band\'s performance and bought their contract from Warner Bros. Their debut album on CBS/Columbia Records, \'\'[[Last Days and Time]]\'\', featured mostly original material, but Bailey had recommended that the band cover the [[Pete Seeger]] song "[[Where Have All the Flowers Gone?]]", and the elements also remade the [[Bread (band)|Bread]] hit "[[Make It with You]]".<ref name = "Nathan-1993" /><ref name=chuck /> The album also includes the original (Maurice-penned) composition "Power", an uptempo eight-minute instrumental. In stark contrast to the ballads, "Power" features extended fuzz guitar and soprano saxophone solos set against a driving funk beat.

===Classic period (1973\xe2\x80\x931980)===
[[Image:Earth Wind and Fire Symbol.jpg|thumb|right| Portrayed on the cover of the album, \'\'[[The Best of Earth, Wind & Fire, Vol. 1]]\'\' is Earth, Wind & Fire\'s official symbol.]]

The album \'\'[[Head to the Sky]]\'\' was released in the spring of 1973 and gave the group their first two legitimate hit singles, "[[Evil (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Evil]]", co-written by Maurice and Philip, and "[[Keep Your Head to the Sky]]", both of which reached the top 30 and the top 60 on the R&B and pop charts, respectively. After this album\'s release some personnel changes took place as Ronnie Laws, Roland Bautista, and Jessica Cleaves left the band to pursue new musical opportunities; the album was also their last to be produced by Joe Wissert. Philip Bailey had recommended his former Denver [[East High School (Denver)|East High School]] classmate, saxophonist [[Andrew Woolfolk]], to the band. Woolfolk had been busy in New York studying sax with sax maestro [[Joe Henderson]] and was about to start a career in banking when Bailey called. To fill the void created by Bautista\'s departure, rhythm guitarists [[Al McKay]] (who had performed with the [[Ike and Tina Turner|Ike and Tina Turner Revue]] and The Watts 103rd St. Rhythm Band) and Johnny Graham from R&B group [[New Birth (band)|New Birth]] were added to round out the new lineup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almckay.com/bio.php|title=BIO Al McKay|publisher=almckay.com}}</ref> As some of the band\'s songs required lower register vocals than Bailey\'s, and due to the success of "Evil", Maurice altered his role in the group to incorporate that of lead vocalist.

Recorded at [[Colorado]]\'s [[Caribou Ranch|Caribou Ranch Studio]] and released in 1974, \'\'[[Open Our Eyes]]\'\' was a commercially successful LP, selling over a million copies in the US and thus was certified Platinum. At Maurice\'s request, \'\'Open Our Eyes\'\' was co-produced by [[Charles Stepney]] with White. Stepney had previously worked with [[The Dells]], [[The Rotary Connection]], [[Terry Callier]], [[Minnie Riperton]], and the [[Ramsey Lewis Trio]], to name a few.<ref name=allmusic>
{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p128469|pure_url=yes}}|title= Charles Stepney Biography|publisher= allmusic.com}}
</ref> Released in May 1974, the single "[[Mighty Mighty (song)|Mighty Mighty]]" became Earth, Wind & Fire\'s first top 30 hit on the pop charts, peaking at No. 29. Another single, "[[Devotion (song)|Devotion]]", was a song with a strong spiritual message. This album also saw the inclusion of Maurice\'s younger brother, [[Fred White (musician)|Fred White]], into the band. Fred had played in Chicago clubs as a drummer with [[Donny Hathaway]] and [[Little Feat]].<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

On April 6, 1974, Earth, Wind & Fire performed at the [[California Jam]], a West Coast rock festival that attracted an audience of 200,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://californiajam.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3&Itemid=42/|title=California Jam brought 200,000 rock enthusiasts to the region 28 years ago, making Ontario the rock capital of the nation| publisher=californiajam.com|first=David| last=Allen|date=April 4, 2002}}</ref> Also in 1974, the band collaborated with Ramsey Lewis on his album \'\'[[Sun Goddess (album)|Sun Goddess]]\'\', which reached number one on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Jazz and Black Album charts and was certified Gold in the US by the RIAA.

In 1975, Earth, Wind & Fire was approached by [[Sig Shore]], producer of the motion picture \'\'[[Super Fly (film)|Super Fly]]\'\', to record the soundtrack to new film about the dark side of the recording industry called \'\'[[That\'s the Way of the World (film)|That\'s The Way Of The World]]\'\'. The film also starred EWF as a new recording act known as "The Group"; they performed songs in the film and Maurice had a small speaking part, as leader of "The Group". In the film [[Harvey Keitel]]\'s character hears "The Group" performing and produces their first album. The film\'s title is repeated throughout the film as a shrug of the shoulders to the music world.<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

When the band saw the film, they were convinced that the motion picture would be a [[box office bomb|bomb]], which it eventually was.<ref name=chuck /> To avoid being connected with the movie they released the album\'s soundtrack, also entitled \'\'[[That\'s the Way of the World]]\'\', before its premiere. Recorded at the Caribou Ranch Studio and co-produced by Maurice White and Charles Stepney [[That\'s the Way of the World]] became Earth, Wind & Fire\'s breakthrough album, spending three weeks at number one on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Pop Albums Charts, five nonconsecutive weeks atop the Soul Albums chart.<ref name=mixonline>{{cite web|url=http://mixonline.com/mag/audio_earth_wind_fires/| title=Classic Tracks: Earth, Wind & Fire\'s "Shining Star"|publisher=mixonline.com|first=Robyn |last=Flans|date=December 1, 2004|accessdate=May 7, 2009}}</ref> \'\'That\'s the Way of the World\'\' was also warmly received critically. For instance, [[AllMusic]]\'s Alex Henderson described the album as "one of the strongest albums of the 70\'s" and "EWF\'s crowning achievement", and \'\'[[Billboard Magazine]]\'\' called it "a very tightly produced and performed package". The album made EWF the first black act to top both the \'\'Billboard\'\' album and singles charts and was certified triple platinum in the US by the RIAA.<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

Included on the album were the hit singles "[[Shining Star (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Shining Star]]" \xe2\x80\x93 which rose to number one on the R&B Singles and \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100 and won the band a [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]] \xe2\x80\x93 and "[[That\'s the Way of the World (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|That\'s the Way of the World]]", which went to number five and number 12 on the R&B Singles and \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100, respectively. Because of the album\'s tremendous commercial success, the band was able to hire a full [[horn section]], which was dubbed the [[Phenix Horns]]. The Phenix Horns, who became an integral part of the band\'s sound, were composed of saxophonist [[Don Myrick]], [[trombonist]] [[Louis Satterfield]], and trumpeters Rahmlee Davis and [[Michael Harris (trumpeter)|Michael Harris]]. Myrick and Satterfield both worked with Maurice during his days as a session drummer at Chess Records.

Subsequent to EWF\'s first tour of Europe, where they opened for the rock band [[Santana (band)|Santana]], Columbia Records wanted another album released as soon as possible. As a result EWF returned to the studio in June 1975 and from these recording sessions two singles - "[[Sing a Song (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Sing a Song]]" and "[[Can\'t Hide Love]]", the latter written by Clarence "Skip" Scarborough - were spawned.<ref name="Nathan-1993" /> These and other studio recordings were included, along with mostly live concert material from their 1974 and 1975 tours, on the double album \'\'[[Gratitude (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|Gratitude]]\'\', released in late 1975. \'\'Gratitude\'\' rose to and stayed at number one on the pop and R&B charts for three weeks and six weeks respectively; it was also the second bestselling R&B album of 1976 and is certified triple Platinum for sales of over 3,000,000 copies in the US by the RIAA.<ref name=billboard>[http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/charts/yearend_chart_display.jsp?f=Top+R%26B%2FHip-Hop+Albums&g=Year-end+Albums&year=1976 Billboard. com \xe2\x80\x93 Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums of 1976]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.downbeat.com/default.asp?sect=stories&subsect=story_detail&sid=783|title=1975 Down Beat Readers Poll|publisher=downbeat.com|date = December 31, 1975}}
</ref>

The band was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]] for the title track, "Gratitude". "[[Can\'t Hide Love]]" was also Grammy-nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Vocal Arrangement for Two or More Voices|Best Arrangement For Voices]]. Earth, Wind & Fire also won a [[Rock Music Awards|Rock Music Award]] in the category of Best Soul Album for \'\'Gratitude\'\' and \'\'[[Down Beat]]\'\' magazine\'s Readers Poll for favorite Rock/Blues Group in 1975.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l5kuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tqEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=834,1365003&dq=earth+wind+%26+fire+gratitude&hl=en|title=Mccartney, Ronstadt top in annual rock awards|publisher=Montreal Gazette|year=1976|accessdate=December 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name=EARTHWINDANDFIRE>[http://www.earthwindandfire.com/bio_awards.html earthwindandfire.com/bio_awards]</ref>

Additionally, in 1975 Maurice established a production company called Kalimba Productions to which he signed artists such as  his former bandleader Ramsey Lewis, singer [[Deniece Williams]] (a former member of [[Stevie Wonder]]\'s Wonderlove backup group) and [[girl group]] [[The Emotions]], who had a run of hits with Stax Records from 1969 to 1974. Maurice loaned the band\'s signature Phenix Horns and most of the other band members and put on tour with Earth, Wind & Fire these artists and others who were signed to Kalimba Productions.

After helping co-produce and arrange Earth, Wind & Fire\'s new album, Deniece Williams\'s debut album, \'\'[[This Is Niecy]]\'\', Ramsey Lewis\'s \'\'[[Salongo]]\'\', and The Emotion\'s first [[Columbia Records]] album \'\'[[Flowers (The Emotions album)|Flowers]]\'\', Charles Stepney died of a heart attack on May 17, 1976 in Chicago at the age of 43. He was survived by his wife Rubie, his three daughters, Eibur, Charlene and Chante, his parents and his brother.<ref>[http://www.charlesstepney.org/the_man.html ]{{dead link|date=October 2011}}</ref>
With Stepney\'s passing Maurice took over and completed the production of the band\'s new album, \'\'[[Spirit (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|Spirit]]\'\', which was released October 1976. EWF paid tribute to Stepney in the form of the album\'s title and that of its title track.
The album reached number 2 on the Billboard Pop and R&B Albums Chart and was certified double Platinum in the US by the [[RIAA]]; additionally, \'\'Spirit\'\' spawned the hit singles "[[Getaway (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Getaway]]" and "[[Saturday Nite (song)|Saturday Nite]].<ref name="ALLMUSIC" /><ref>[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r6508|pure_url=yes}} Spirit \xe2\x80\x93 Charts on Allmuisc.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Earth%20Wind&format=ALBUM&go=Search&perPage=50 RIAA Certification for Spirit]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wholecircleround.co.uk/discovision/spins/stepney7.htm|title=Charles Stepney \xe2\x80\x93 A Shining Star Eclipsed|publisher=wholecircleround.co.uk|accessdate=May 8, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=song|id=t825284|pure_url=yes}}|title=Getaway \xe2\x80\x93 song review|publisher=allmusic.com|first=Ed|last=Hogan|accessdate=May 10, 2009}}</ref>

During this period EWF concerts started to become loaded with pyrotechnics, magic, laser lights, flying pyramids, levitating guitarists and elaborate production tricks, that included the entire group ascending in a pyramid and a disappearing act, which saw EWF literally vanishing from sight. Magician [[Doug Henning]] directed many of their tours throughout the 1970s with his young assistant, [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]]. The band also began to be choreographed by [[George Faison]].<ref name="ALLMUSIC" /><ref name=icsolihull>{{cite web|url=http://icsolihull.icnetwork.co.uk/whatson/entertainment/2004/03/22/back-in-boogie-wonderland-50003-14077035|title= Back in Boogie Wonderland|publisher=The Birmingham Post|first=Charlie|last=Melvin|date=March 22, 2004}}</ref>

In November 1977, the group released another studio LP, \'\'[[All \'N All]]\'\'. With an Egyptian/post modernistic themed album cover, \'\'All \'N All\'\' featured the hit singles "[[Serpentine Fire]]" and "[[Fantasy (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Fantasy]]", and achieved triple Platinum status. This album was the first of several to feature striking [[album cover|cover]] art by the Japanese artist [[Shusei Nagaoka]].<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.shusei-nagaoka.com/english/index.html|title= The art of Shusei Nagaoka|publisher= shusei-nagaoka.com}}
</ref>

In 1978, EWF picked up three Grammy Awards, the third for their rendition of [[The Beatles]]\' "[[Got to Get You into My Life]]". EWF\'s performance of the song was included on the self-titled soundtrack of the movie, \'\'[[Sgt. Pepper\'s Lonely Hearts Club Band (film)|Sgt. Pepper\'s Lonely Heart\'s Club Band]]\'\'. The film was a commercial failure; however, "Got to Get You into My Life" was the biggest hit from the movie\'s soundtrack, reaching numbers one and nine on the R&B and Pop singles charts, respectively.

1978 was also the year that Maurice and EWF\'s managers Cavallo and Ruffalo worked out a deal for the launch of a new record label called The American Recording Company (ARC), to be distributed through CBS, and the creation of a recording studio, [[George Massenburg]]/ARC, also called "The Complex", in West Los Angeles. The year ended with the release of another hit single, entitled "[[September (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|September]]", which was added to the quintuple [[Music recording sales certification|Platinum]] compilation album, \'\'[[The Best of Earth, Wind & Fire, Vol. 1]]\'\', which came out on November 23, 1978, four days before Thanksgiving. At this time, Bobby Harris of the [[Dazz Band]] requested and got Philip Bailey to produce the group\'s first album, \'\'Kinsman Dazz\'\'. Bailey had a major input into the group\'s vocal arrangements and would also co-produce the band\'s second album, \'\'Dazz\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p39851|pure_url=yes}}|title=(((Kinsman Dazz > Biography)))|publisher=allmusic.com|first= Andrew|last=Hamilton|accessdate=May 7, 2009}}</ref>

January 1979 saw the band performing "September" and "That\'s The Way Of The World" at the [[Music for UNICEF Concert]], which was broadcast worldwide from the [[United Nations General Assembly]] by [[NBC]]. Other artists performing at the event were [[ABBA]], the [[Bee Gees]], [[Olivia Newton-John]], [[Donna Summer]] and [[Rod Stewart]]. Subsequent to this performance the band donated the royalties from one of their songs to [[UNICEF]] and began a tour of Europe and Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Various-Music-For-Unicef-Concert-A-Gift-Of-Song/release/1308466| title=Various \xe2\x80\x93 Music For Unicef Concert: A Gift Of Song|publisher=discogs|accessdate=May 7, 2009}}</ref>

The group\'s ninth album overall, seventh for Columbia Records, and second released on the ARC label was \'\'[[I Am (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|I Am]]\'\'. It was another smash hit, going double Platinum and reaching numbers 3 and 1 on the R&B and Pop charts, respectively. Singles spawned from this album included "[[In The Stone]]", "Can\'t Let Go", and the sad [[David Foster]]/[[Bill Champlin]]-written ballad "[[After the Love Has Gone]]", which rose to the number 2 spot on the \'\'[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]\'\' Pop and [[R&B]] charts and won a Grammy for the [[Best R&B Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group]] at the [[Grammy Awards of 1980]]. Though the band had previously overlooked disco, the summer of 1979 saw EWF topping the dance music charts with their most disco-inspired single "[[Boogie Wonderland]]", which was produced by Maurice and Al McKay and featured [[The Emotions]]. Even with the song\'s success, Verdine White claims that the band is not a disco band, saying: "I guess you could say we were at the party but didn\xe2\x80\x99t get on the dance floor."<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r6512|pure_url=yes}}| title= I Am \xe2\x80\x93 Review|author=Henderson, Alex|publisher=allmusic.com|accessdate=June 20, 2009}}</ref><ref name=contactmusic.com>
{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/home.nsf/webpages/earthwindandfirex21x09x05|title= Earth Wind & Fire \xe2\x80\x93 Interview |publisher=contactmusic.com|year=2005|accessdate=June 20, 2009}}
</ref>

In October 1980, the double-album \'\'[[Faces (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|Faces]]\'\' was released, and rose to number 2 and number 10 and the R&B and Pop charts respectively; it earned Gold status in the US. In a 2007 interview, when asked which EWF album was his favorite, Maurice White replied: "Probably \'\'Faces\'\' because we were really in tune, playing together and it gave us the opportunity to explore new areas."<ref name=bluesandsoul>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesandsoul.com/feature/195/maurice_white/|title= Maurice white: still burning bright|publisher=bluesandsoul.com|first=David|last=Nathan|year=2007}}</ref> After the release of this album, longtime rhythm guitarist Al McKay left the band for personal as well as professional reasons. He was replaced by returning rhythm guitarist [[Roland Bautista]], who gave the band a bit of a hard rock sound with his style of playing.

===Electronic period (1981\xe2\x80\x931990)===
White decided that, given the changing musical landscape, the band needed to incorporate into their work more of the digital sound which was popular at the time. As a result, EWF\'s eleventh album titled \'\'Raise!\'\' - was influenced with this new electronic sound and released in the fall of 1981 - sold over a million copies in the US and was certified Platinum by the [[RIAA]]. \'\'Raise!\'\' featured the hit single "[[Let\'s Groove]]", which also went Platinum, and another single "[[Wanna Be With You]]", which won EWF a Grammy for Best R&B Vocal Performance By A Duo Or Group. Earth, Wind & Fire appeared at [[American Bandstand]]\'s 30th Anniversary Special, where they performed "Let\'s Groove" on October 30, 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/american-bandstand/american-bandstands-30th-anniversary-special/episode/216607/summary.html| title=American Bandstand\'s 30th Anniversary Special|publisher=tv.com}}</ref>
[[File:White and Baiiley Earth Wind and Fire.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Earth, Wind, and Fire\'s Maurice White and Philip Bailey performing in 1982 at the Ahoy Rotterdam, The Netherlands]]

Two years after the release of \'\'Raise!\'\' came \'\'[[Powerlight]]\'\', which included the singles "[[Fall In Love With Me]]", a number 17 pop hit, and "Side By Side". "Powerlight" went Gold. Also in 1983, the song "Dance, Dance, Dance" was contributed to the soundtrack of the animated film \'\'[[Rock & Rule]]\'\'. After the fully synthesized album \'\'[[Electric Universe (album)|Electric Universe]]\'\' was released in late 1983 to a poor critical and commercial reception, Maurice believed the band needed a break so he put EWF on hiatus.

During their hiatus, Philip Bailey released his second and most commercially successful solo project, the Gold album \'\'[[Chinese Wall (album)|Chinese Wall]]\'\', featuring the [[Phenix Horns]] and produced by [[Phil Collins]]. The first single from that album, a duet with Collins called "[[Easy Lover]]", sold over a million copies, rose to number 2 on the US \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100 and number 1 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] respectively, and was [[Grammy]]-nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals|Best Pop Vocal Performance By A Duo or Group]]. The music video of Bailey and Collins rehearsing their collaboration went to the top of MTV\'s video playlist and won an [[MTV Video Music Award]] for Best Overall Performance in 1985. Bailey released four [[gospel music|gospel]] albums in this period, and one of them, titled \'\'[[Triumph (Philip Bailey album)|Triumph]]\'\', won him a [[Grammy Award for Best Gospel Vocal Performance, Male]].

Maurice White, during this time, produced for [[Barbra Streisand]] on her Platinum album \'\'[[Emotion (Barbra Streisand album)|Emotion]]\'\' and worked with [[Neil Diamond]] on his Gold album \'\'[[Headed for the Future]]\'\' and [[Cher]] on her 1987 Platinum album \'\'[[Cher (1987 album)|Cher]]\'\'. He also released the self-titled solo album \'\'[[Maurice White (album)|Maurice White]]\'\' in 1985, which included a cover of "[[Stand by Me (song)|Stand by Me]]" that went to number six on the R&B charts and number eleven on the Adult Contemporary charts. The album also featured an appearance by saxophonist [[Gerald Albright]]. Also, during the hiatus, Verdine White worked behind the scenes, writing and directing videos. He produced \'\'[[Standing in the Light]]\'\', by the English pop rock and jazz-funk band [[Level 42]], with Larry Dunn, and promoted go-go bands like [[Trouble Funk]] and [[Experience Unlimited|E.U.]]<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

The compilation album \'\'[[The Collection (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|The Collection]]\'\' was released May 1986, stayed at number 5 on the UK singles charts for two weeks, and was certified Gold in the UK by the [[British Phonographic Industry]].

[[Phil Collins]] saw EWF on one of their European tours and became a fan of the band. He came in contact with the [[Phenix Horns]] and they eventually worked with his band [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]] on songs including "[[No Reply At All]]" and "[[Paperlate]]", and with him on such solo hits as "[[I Missed Again]]" and "[[Sussudio]]".

In 1987, CBS Records convinced both Philip Bailey and Maurice White that a reunion of Earth, Wind & Fire would be fruitful. As a result, original members Verdine White, Ralph Johnson and Andrew Woofolk returned to the band with new members guitarist/vocalist [[Sheldon Reynolds (guitarist)|Sheldon Reynolds]], lead guitarist [[Dick Smith (musician)|Dick Smith]], and drummer [[Sonny Emory]]. A new horn section dubbed the Earth, Wind & Fire Horns was also created, made up of Gary Bias on the saxophone, [[Raymond Lee Brown]] on the trumpet, and Reggie Young on the flugelhorn and trombone.

The band\'s reformation fostered the 1987 Gold album \'\'[[Touch the World]]\'\', which was nominated for a [[Soul Train Award]] in the category of [[Soul Train Music Award for Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year|Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year]] and rose to number three on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart and number 33 on The \'\'Billboard\'\' 200.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WHwlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Z_UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1824,1006825&dq=earth+wind+%26+fire+soul+train+awards&hl=en|title=Soul Train Music Awards\' To Honor Gladys Knight And The Pips With A Trophy|publisher=Google }}</ref> Featured on the album was a song penned by an unknown songwriter by the name of Skylark, titled "[[System of Survival]]". Released as a single, the song became a hit, going to number one on the \'\'Billboard\'\' R&B charts and Dance charts. Another single titled "[[Thinking of You (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Thinking Of You]]" peaked at number one and number three on the R&B and Dance charts as well. In 1988, the band released the compilation album \'\'[[The Best of Earth, Wind & Fire, Vol. 2]]\'\', which went Gold in the US. The group\'s final album released by Columbia Records was 1990\'s \'\'[[Heritage (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|Heritage]]\'\', which featured a collaboration with [[Sly Stone]] of [[Sly & the Family Stone]]. In 1992, the band released a 55-track anthology of their career up to that point entitled \'\'The Eternal Dance\'\'.

===Neo classic period (1993\xe2\x80\x93present)===
EWF signed once again with Warner Brothers and following this came the release in 1993 of their 16th studio album, \'\'[[Millennium (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|Millennium]]\'\'. Included on this album was the single "[[Sunday Morning (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Sunday Morning]]", which earned the band a Grammy nomination for Best R&B Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group, and a track written by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] called "Super Hero". Tragedy unfortunately befell the band in 1993; on July 30 former band member and Phenix Horns saxophonist [[Don Myrick]] was fatally shot by the Los Angeles Police Department in a case of mistaken identity. Then on October 13, former lead vocalist [[Wade Flemons]] died from cancer in [[Battle Creek, Michigan]]. In 1994, Earth, Wind & Fire were inducted into the [[NAACP Image Award - Hall of Fame Award|NAACP Hall Of Fame]].

[[File:Earth Wind and Fire Walk of Fame 4-20-06.jpg|thumb|190px|right|Earth, Wind & Fire star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]]]
[[File:EarthWindAndFire M\xc3\xbcnchen.jpg|thumb|190px|right|Earth, Wind & Fire tribute, Munich Olympic Walk of Stars on 9 April 2011]]
The band received another tribute in the following year in the form of a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]].<ref name=earthwindandfire /> All the original members of the group attended the inauguration ceremony, and in his speech Maurice White attributed EWF\'s success to the support of all of their fans. In 1994 Maurice White decided to retire from touring with the band. At the time, he explained that he wanted to take a rest from the rigors of the road. Philip Bailey was given the role of onstage leader of the band.

The studio album \'\'[[In the Name of Love (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|In the Name of Love]]\'\' was released on Pyramid Records in 1997 to a favorable critical reception. EWF performed at the 1997 [[Montreux Jazz Festival]] and gave an encore performance the following year. In 2004, a DVD of their 1997 performance was released, entitled \'\'[[Earth, Wind & Fire: Live At Montreux 1997]]\'\'. In 1999, the group performed on the [[A&E Network]] show \'\'[[Live by Request]]\'\',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg&sql=1:259411 |title=Movies and Films Database \xe2\x80\x93 Movie Search, Guide, Recommendations, and Reviews \xe2\x80\x93 AllRovi |publisher=Allmovie.com |date=September 8, 2011 |accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref> and in that same year Maurice announced that the real reason for his ending his touring days in 1995 was because he had contracted [[Parkinson\'s disease]] in the late 1980s, which made it increasingly difficult for him over the years to handle comfortably the rigors of touring. A website entitled www.Startalk.org was set up in 1999 to offer Maurice support with his health struggles and on it, messages of encouragement from celebrities such as [[Steven Tyler]] of [[Aerosmith]], [[Boyz II Men]], [[Smokey Robinson]], [[Isaac Hayes]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[Eric Clapton]] and [[Tom Morello]] of [[Rage Against the Machine]] were published.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startalk.org/celeb_messages/|title=Celebrity Messages to Maurice|publisher=startalk.org|accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref> Maurice, however, has the disease under control, so much so that he occasionally makes appearances at Earth, Wind & Fire performances, and continues to write, record, produce and develop new recordings for Earth, Wind & Fire and other artists.

On the March 6, 2000, Earth, Wind & Fire were inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] to a [[standing ovation]] during the 15th annual induction dinner held at New York\'s [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel]]. All of the band\'s original members from the 1973\xe2\x80\x9480 "classic period", namely Maurice White, Philip Bailey, Verdine White, Ralph Johnson, Al McKay, Larry Dunn, Andrew Woofolk, Fred White and Johnny Graham, attended the ceremony, at which the nine of them played together for the first time in 20 years, performing "Shining Star" and "That\'s The Way Of the World". After their induction into the Hall of Fame an effort was made by the original band members to fully reunite, but it ultimately proved unfruitful.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/read/news/12041144 |title=Lil\' Kim News \xe2\x80\x93 Yahoo! Music |publisher=Music.yahoo.com |date=March 7, 2000 |accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/no%20full%20reunion%20for%20earth%20wind%20+%20fire_1002066 |title=Fire &#124; No Full Reunion For Earth, Wind + Fire |publisher=Contactmusic |date=July 10, 2006 |accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref>

Earth, Wind & Fire were the specially invited music guests at the June 20, 2000 [[White House]] [[state dinner]] hosted by President [[Bill Clinton]] on the [[South Lawn (White House)|South Lawn]] of the [[White House]], in honor of His Majesty [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|Mohammed VI, King of Morocco]], and Her Royal Highness Princess Lalla Meryem.<ref name=earthwindandfire>{{cite web|url=http://www.earthwindandfire.com/bio_timeline.html |title=The Official Earth, Wind & Fire Website bio_timeline |publisher=Earthwindandfire.com |accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/read/news/12051020| title= Earth, Wind & Fire To Rock The White House Tonight|author= Simon, Bruce|publisher=new.music.yahoo.com|date= June 20, 2000}}
</ref> So impressed was the King by the band\'s performance that he made a successful personal request for EWF to perform in Morocco for his 37th birthday celebration, on August 21, 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/read/news/12051020|title= Earth, Wind & Fire To Play For King Of Morocco Again |author= Simon, Bruce & Dougatz, Chad|publisher=new.music.yahoo.com|date= June 20, 2000|accessdate=June 20, 2009}}
</ref>

In 2001, a biographical documentary of the band entitled \'\'[[Shining Stars: The Official Story Of Earth, Wind & Fire]]\'\' was released, directed by Kathryn Arnold. Following the [[September 11 attacks]] of that year, the band members donated $25,000 to the [[American Red Cross]] at a September 13 show at Virginia\'s [[Farm Bureau Live at Virginia Beach|Verizon Wireless Virginia Beach Amphitheater]], the band\'s first concert since those events took place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/earth-wind-fire/news/artist-nameewf-id1008048-donates-25000-to-american-red-cross--12049881|title=Donates $25,000 To American Red Cross|publisher=new.music.yahoo.com|author=Simon, Bruce|date=September 13, 2001|accessdate=June 2, 2009}}</ref> February 24, 2002 saw Earth, Wind & Fire performing at the closing ceremonies of the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] held in Salt Lake City, Utah.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/olympics/2002/news/2002/02/24/closing_ceremony_ap/|title= So long, Salt Lake \xe2\x80\x93 America rocks, rolls and exhales at Closing Ceremonies|agency= Associated Press|date= February 24, 2002 | accessdate=May 1, 2010|work=CNN}}</ref>

A live album from the band\'s 1980 performance in [[Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil, entitled \'\'[[Live in Rio (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|Live In Rio]]\'\', was released on Maurice White\'s Kalimba Records label in 2002, and that same year EWF was honored with the Rhythm & Soul Heritage Award from the [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers]] at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in [[Beverly Hills, California]]. The award was presented to EWF by ASCAP President and Chairman Marilyn Bergman, [[Stevie Wonder]], and [[Jimmy Jam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/press/2002/rsawards_061702.html|title= Ashanti & DJ Quik Host ASCAP 15th Annual Rhythm & Soul Music Celebration in Los Angeles|publisher=ascap.com|date= November 4, 2002}}</ref> In addition, the band was inducted into the [[Vocal Group Hall of Fame]] and Hollywood\'s RockWalk in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/playback/2003/fall/action/earthwindfire.html|title=Legendary R&B Group Earth, Wind & Fire Inducted Into Hollywood\'s Rockwalk|publisher=ascap.com}}</ref>

In 2003, Kalimba Records released \'\'[[The Promise (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|The Promise]]\'\' \xe2\x80\x93 the band\'s first studio album in six years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blender.com/guide/new/52937/promise.html|title= The Promise album review|publisher=blender.com| first=Chairman|last=Mao| accessdate=April 27, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20140120,00.html|title= Picks and Pans Main: Song|work=People |accessdate=April 27, 2009}}</ref> \'\'The Promise\'\' rose to number 19 on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums charts and received critical acclaim upon its release, with \'\'[[People Magazine]]\'\' and \'\'[[Blender Magazine]]\'\' describing the album as "musically rich" and "a classy collection", respectively. The track "Hold Me" was Grammy-nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional R&B Vocal Performance|Best Traditional R&B Vocal Performance]]. The album spawned a kalimba-laden track reminiscent of the classic EW&F sound, titled "[[All in the Way]]", which reunited EWF with The Emotions. Featured on the album were two previously unreleased songs from the "I Am" recording sessions: "Where Do We Go From Here" and "Dirty".

On February 8, 2004, Earth, Wind & Fire performed in a tribute to [[Funk music|funk]] at the [[46th Grammy Awards|46th annual Grammy Awards]] held at the [[Staples Center]], Los Angeles, California. Other artists performing at this tribute were [[Parliament Funkadelic]], [[OutKast]], and [[Robert Randolph and the Family Band]]. EWF sang "Shining Star" and then at Outkast\'s request crooned "[[The Way You Move]]" with them. Robert Randolph and the Family Band performed their single "[[Unclassified (album)|I Need More Love]]" and then all of the bands teamed up to sing Parliament Funkadelic\'s classic "[[Give Up the Funk (Tear the Roof off the Sucker)]]".<ref name=icsolihull /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1484889/20040208/knowles_beyonce.jhtml|title=Beyonce Sings Twice, Christina Plays Nice, Outkast Cool As Ice On Grammy Stage|publisher=cmt.com| first = Jon | last = Wiederhorn| date = February 9, 2004|accessdate =April 18, 2009}}</ref> Earth, Wind & Fire contributed to the [[Jimi Hendrix]] tribute album \'\'[[Power of Soul: A Tribute to Jimi Hendrix]], released in May 4, 2004, with their cover of "[[Voodoo Child (Slight Return)]]".
 
In the summer of 2004 Earth, Wind & Fire signed a record deal with [[Sanctuary Urban Records Group|Sanctuary Urban Records]], owned by [[Mathew Knowles]] (father and manager of r&b/pop singer [[Beyonc\xc3\xa9 Knowles|Beyonc\xc3\xa9]]). Gary Bias and Bob Burns, Jr. of the Earth, Wind & Fire Horns were featured on [[Queen Latifah]]\'s \'\'[[The Dana Owens Album]]\'\', which was released on September 28, 2004, and reached 16 and 11 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' 200 and Top R&B/Hip-Hop Album charts, respectively, and was certified Gold.

[[Kenny G]]\'s cover of "[[The Way You Move]]", which was released in November 2004 and charted at number 12 on the Adult Contemporary singles chart, featured the band with Maurice and Philip on lead vocals. EWF and Kenny G performed "The Way You Move" on \'\'[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]\'\' in January 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvnotify.com/shows/1858| title=The Tonight Show with Jay Leno|publisher=tvnotify.com| accessdate=May 2, 2009}}</ref>

On December 11, 2004, Earth, Wind & Fire were honored at the first annual Grammy Jam held at Los Angeles\'s [[Wiltern Theater]], where several artists such as [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Yolanda Adams]], [[Sheila E.]], [[Miri Ben-Ari]], [[George Duke]], [[Kanye West]], and [[Randy Jackson]] paid tribute to the band in the form of performances. Other celebrities who attended the event were [[Pamela Anderson]], [[Tim Allen]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis|Jimmy Jam, Terry Lewis]], [[Nick Cannon]], and [[Suzanne de Passe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurweb.com/story/eur17808.cfm|title=EW&F HONORED AT FIRST ANNUAL GRAMMY JAM: Usher, Stevie Wonder, Jill Scott, Kanye West & Lots More Show Love|publisher=eurweb.com|date= December 13, 2004}}</ref> EWF performed on \'\'[[Dick Clark\'s New Year\'s Rockin\' Eve]]\'\' on December 31, 2004.<ref>
{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/tv/205753_newyearstv.html|title=With Dick Clark laid low, who\'ll host the party?|agency=Associated Press|first=David|last=Bauder|date=December 31, 2004|accessdate=May 2, 2009|work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer}}
</ref>

EWF released a single entitled "[[Show Me The Way (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Show Me The Way]]", on which they paired up with [[neo soul]] artist [[Raphael Saadiq]] on [[Sanctuary Records Group|Sanctuary Records]] in the fall of 2005. The single garnered a Grammy nomination and was featured on \'\'[[Illumination (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|Illumination]]\'\', their 19th studio album, which was released on September 20, 2005. For this album EWF collaborated with artists such as [[will.i.am]], [[Kelly Rowland]], Outkast\'s [[Big Boi]], and [[Brian McKnight]]. \'\'Illumination\'\' reached number eight on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Album Chart and number 32 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100. Another single spawned from the album, dubbed "[[Pure Gold (song)|Pure Gold]]", reached number 23 on the Adult Contemporary Charts.

The album garnered the admiration of critics, with [[AllMusic]]\'s Rob Theakston referring to the album as an "outstanding record" and  Steve Jones of \'\'[[USA Today]]\'\'\' remarking that on the album EWF are as "vibrant as ever".<ref>
{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r712969|pure_url=yes}}|title=Illumination album review|publisher=allmusic.com|first=Rob|last=Theakston|accessdate=27, April 2009}}
</ref><ref>
{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/reviews/2005-10-17-listen-up_x.htm|title=\'Angel\': Synth-pop \xc3\xa0 la Mode|work=USA Today |first=Steve|last=Jones|date= October 17, 2005|accessdate=April 27, 2009}}
</ref> Illumination received a Grammy nomination for Best R&B Album and a \'\'[[Soul Train]]\'\' Music Award in the category R&B-soul album. EWF also received a [[NAACP Image Award]] nomination for Best Duo or Group.<ref>
{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_/ai_n16108619|title=The timeless appeal of Earth Wind & Fire|publisher=Jet Magazine|author=Parham, Marti|date= March 13, 2006}}
</ref>

The February 6, 2005 [[Super Bowl XXXIX]] pregame show in [[Jacksonville, Florida]] saw the band teaming up with [[The Black Eyed Peas]] to sing "[[Where Is the Love?]]" and "Shining Star".<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/6924979/|title=McCartney plays it safe in halftime show|publisher=nbcsports.msnbc.com|first= Bauder|last=David|date=February 7, 2005}}
</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/superbowl/history/entertainment|title= History of Entertainment at the Super Bowl|publisher=NFL }}</ref> In March 2005 EWF performed in Russia for the first time.<ref name=earthwindandfire />

In 2004, Earth, Wind & Fire and [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]] embarked upon a joint national tour, which gave rise to a DVD of a concert that took place at Los Angeles\' [[Greek Theatre (Los Angeles)|Greek Theater]] entitled \'\'[[Chicago & Earth, Wind & Fire \xe2\x80\x93 Live at the Greek Theatre]]\'\'. This DVD was released on June 28, 2005 and was [[music recording sales certification|certified Platinum]] two months afterward. Chicago and EWF once again toured together in 2005 and collaborated for a new recording of Chicago\'s ballad "[[If You Leave Me Now]]", that was included on Chicago\'s 2005 compilation album \'\'[[Love Songs (Chicago album)|Love Songs]]\'\'. As part of an opening act for the [[57th Primetime Emmy Awards]] held on September 18, 2005 at the [[Shrine Auditorium]], Los Angeles the band once more collaborated up with the [[The Black Eyed Peas]] and this was first time a musical artist had opened at the annual awards show.<ref name=earthwindandfire /> On September 27, 2005, former Earth, Wind & Fire member and the Phenix Horns trombonist [[Louis Satterfield]] died. He was 67 years old.

In 2005, EWF released their first Christmas-themed track entitled "Gather Round", produced and arranged by Foster and written by Maurice White, David Foster and Philip Bailey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Various-Sounds-Of-The-Season-The-NBC-Holiday-Collection/release/1065793 |title=Various \xe2\x80\x93 Sounds Of The Season: The NBC Holiday Collection (CD) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref>  In 2006, Maurice worked with [[Maurice Hines]] (the brother of famed entertainer [[Gregory Hines]]) to release the Broadway play \'\'[[Hot Feet]]\'\', which was a [[jukebox musical]] whose theme was the music of Earth, Wind & Fire. Maurice wrote along with [[Allee Willis]] \xe2\x80\x93 who wrote "September", "Boogie Wonderland", "In the Stone" and "Sunday Morning" for the band \xe2\x80\x93 several new songs for the play. EWF performed alongside [[Mary J. Blige]] and [[Ludacris]] "[[Runaway Love (Ludacris song)|Runaway Love]]" at the [[49th Grammy Awards]] held at Los Angeles\'s Staples Center .<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/Recording_Academy/News/Default.aspx?newsID=2381&newsCategoryID=1|title= Dixie Chicks Make Nice With Five GRAMMYs|publisher= grammy.com|author=Micallef, Ken|date= February 11, 2007}}
</ref>

[[File:Earth, Wind & Fire at 2008 US Open.jpg|thumb|240px|Earth, Wind & Fire performing at the opening ceremony of the 2008 U.S. Open August 25, 2008]]

\'\'[[Interpretations: Celebrating the Music of Earth, Wind & Fire]]\'\', which is a cover album of EWF\'s material, was released on Stax Records on March 27, 2007. Executively produced by Maurice, the album featured artists such as [[Chaka Khan]], [[Kirk Franklin]], [[Lalah Hathaway]], [[Mint Condition]], [[Dwele]], [[Meshell Ndegeocello]], and [[Angie Stone]]. [[Dwele]] and [[Meshell Ndegeocello]]\'s renditions of "That\xe2\x80\x99s The Way Of The World" and "Fantasy", respectively, were each nominated for the [[Grammy Award for Best Urban/Alternative Performance]].

the band was the opening act at a special edition of \'\'[[American Idol]]\'\' entitled "[[American Idol gives back|Idol Gives Back]]" (which aired April 25, 2007), and performed a medley of "Boogie Wonderland", "Shining Star" and "September".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117933449.html?categoryid=34&cs=1|title=American Idol: Idol Gives Back|work=Variety |author= Gallo, Phil|date= April 25, 2007}}</ref> At the [[Nobel Peace Prize Concert]] in [[Oslo]], Norway, on December 11, 2007, Earth, Wind & Fire performed "[[Fantasy (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Fantasy]]" and "[[September (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|September]]". Hosted by [[Kevin Spacey]] and [[Uma Thurman]], the Nobel Peace Prize Concert was broadcast to over 100 countries. Other artists who performed included [[Melissa Etheridge]], [[Alicia Keys]], [[Annie Lennox]], and [[Kylie Minogue]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelpeaceprize.org/concert/history/2007.php|title=Nobel Peace Prize Concert 2007|accessdate=December 11, 2007|publisher=nobelpeaceprize.org}}</ref>

Earth, Wind & Fire performed on the opening night of one of the largest musical events in Latin America, [[Chile]]\'s [[Vi\xc3\xb1a del Mar International Song Festival|Vi\xc3\xb1a del Mar Festival]]. The band so impressed the audience with their performance that the band was bestowed with the \'\'Gaviota de Plata\'\' (English translation: the Silver Seagull), the highest award that can presented to an artist performing at the Vi\xc3\xb1a del Mar Festival. Ironically, the intro to EWF\'s song "In the Stone" has been used for several years as the introductory theme for the event\'s broadcasts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/photos/2008/feb/21/|title=Photo archive for February 21, 2008|accessdate=Photo archive for February 21, 2008|publisher=commercialappeal.com}}
</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://festival2009.canal13.cl/2009/html/Eng/Noticias/361924.html|title=Relive the best moments of Vi\xc3\xb1a 2008|accessdate=October 18, 2008|publisher=festival2009.canal13.cl}}
</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=http://www.lasnoticiasmexico.com/115304.html&ei=gNu4So6gDZWEtgfttdD1Dg&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=8&ct=result&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dearth,%2Bwind%2B%2526%2Bfire%2BGaviota%2Bde%2BPlata%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dopera%26rls%3Den%26sa%3DN%26start%3D20|title=Start Festival of Vi\xc3\xb1a del Mar with the new seven wonders|accessdate=October 18, 2008|publisher=lasnoticiasmexico.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espanol.upi.com/Entretenimiento/2008/02/21/Earth-Wind-Fire-el-gran-ganador-del-Festival-de-Via-del-Mar/UPI-37761203597840/|title=Earth, Wind & Fire el gran ganador del Festival de Vi\xc3\xb1a del Mar|accessdate=12/10/2010|publisher=UPI.com}}</ref>

Maurice White, Ralph Johnson, Philip Bailey, and Verdine White each received an honorary degree from the Arts and Media College at [[Columbia College Chicago]] during the college\'s 2008 commencement exercises. Verdine White and Bailey both gave brief speeches during the ceremony, followed by all four honorees\' giving an impromptu performance of "Shining Star".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS246141+20 May 2008+PRN20080520|title=Only at Columbia: No Pomp and Circumstance for These Grads \xe2\x80\x93 They Rock the House..|agency=Reuters |date= May 20, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> EWF performed at the opening ceremony of the [[2008 US Open (tennis)|2008 US Open]], which was hosted by [[Forest Whitaker]] and served to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the founding of tennis\xe2\x80\x99s Open Era with a parade of more than 25 former US Open singles champions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usopen.org/en_US/news/articles/2008-08-25/200808251219714457687.html=rss|title=US Open Honors Champions Past in 2008 Opening Ceremony|publisher=usopen.org}}</ref>

Earth, Wind & Fire performed at the [[White House]] on February 22, 2009, for the Governors\' Dinner; they were the first musical artists to perform there since [[Barack Obama]] took office.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/sleuth/2009/02/by_all_accounts_the_first.html?hpid=news-col-blog|title=Obamas Woo Governors With Spinach and Soul|work=The Washington Post |author=Akers, Mary Ann|date=February 23, 2009}}</ref> The band toured once more with Chicago in 2009 for a tour of thirty US cities.{{update after|2009|12|31}}<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/05/23/ent.bands.reunite/?iref=t2test_entsat|title=Classic pop bands unite to tour, create hits|publisher=CNN |author= Payne, Ed|date=May 23, 2009|accessdate=May 23, 2009}}</ref> On April 26, 2009, EWF performed at the 39th [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]].<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/jazzfest/index.ssf/2009/04/post_5.html|title=Decisions, decisions: Etta James, Earth, Wind and Fire or Dave Matthews Band?|publisher=nola.com|first=Maria|last=Montoya|date= April 26, 2009|accessdate=April 27, 2009}}</ref>

In 2010, EWF made a repeat performance at the 40th [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]]. In that same year bandmembers Philip Bailey, Verdine White and Ralph Johnson participated in the recording of the "[[We Are the World 25 for Haiti]]" single.<ref name="wearetheworldfoundation">{{cite web|url=http://wearetheworldfoundation.org/the-song/|title=The Song|publisher=wearetheworldfoundation.org|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> 2010 was also the year that saw Earth, Wind & Fire\'s original members Maurice White, Phillip Bailey, Verdine White, Al McKay and Larry Dunn all inducted into the Songwriter\'s Hall of Fame.{{citation needed|date=February 2012}}

In November 2011, the band was given the Legend Award at the [[Soul Train Awards]] at Atlanta, Georgia\'s [[Fox Theatre (Atlanta, Georgia)|Fox Theatre]].<ref>[http://twitter.com/earthwindfire Earth, Wind & Fire on Twitter]</ref> In 2012, EWF were bestowed with a Lifetime Achievement Award at the 20th Annual Trumpet Awards, held at [[Cobb Energy Performing Arts Centre]] in Atlanta.<ref>[http://www.accessatlanta.com/atlanta-events/trumpet-awards-to-honor-1292222.html Trumpet Awards 2012]</ref>

On April 30, 2013, Earth Wind & Fire were featured vocalists on \'Something About You\' taken from LL Cool J\'s new album "[[Authentic (LL Cool J album)]]", along with former Pussycat Doll Melody Thornton and Charlie Wilson.

\'\'[[Now, Then & Forever]]\'\', the group\'s first album in eight years, was released September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=EARTH, WIND AND FIRE DROPPING NEW ALBUM SEPT. 10|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/earth-wind-and-fire-dropping-new-album-sept-10|publisher=AP|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref>

On September 13, 2014, Earth, Wind & Fire performed at Proms in the Park at Hyde Park with the BBC Concert Orchestra <ref>{{cite url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/events/ep8j5v}}</ref>

On October 21, 2014, Earth, Wind & Fire released their first ever holiday album entitled Holiday. <ref>{{cite url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6266751/earth-wind-fire-holiday-album-release-date}}</ref>

On December 8, 2014, Earth, Wind & Fire performed at the Kennedy Center Honors, honoring Al Green. <ref>{{cite url=http://news.yahoo.com/sting-feted-kennedy-center-honors-022234678.html}}</ref>

On December 14, 2014, Earth, Wind & Fire performed at the Christmas in Washington event. <ref>{{cite url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/first-family-first-class-performers-spread-joy-at-museums-christmas-in-washington/2014/12/14/fe145b9a-8400-11e4-b9b7-b8632ae73d25_story.html}}</ref>

==Influence==
Earth, Wind & Fire\'s songs have been covered by artists such as [[Nokaut]], [[Point of Grace]], [[D\'Angelo]], [[CDB (band)|CDB]], [[Dionne Warwick]], [[The 5th Dimension]], [[Pomplamoose]]<ref name=coverinfo.de>
{{cite web|url=http://www.coverinfo.de/start.php4?wert=12&lang=&suchbegriff=Earth%2C+Wind+%26+Fire&sort=2&suchenach=Komplett&tabelle=1&suchebemerkung=&xpert=0&suchoption=search&seite=1|title=Earth, Wind and Fire|publisher=coverinfo.de|accessdate=January 18, 2009}}
</ref> [[Lenny White]],<ref name=coverinfo.de /> [[Patti LaBelle]],<ref name=secondhandsongs>
{{cite web|url=http://www.secondhandsongs.com/artist/1720|title=Artist: Earth, Wind & Fire|publisher= secondhandsongs.com|accessdate=January 18, 2009}}
</ref> [[The Manhattans]], [[Wynonna Judd]], [[Yolanda Adams]], [[New York Voices]], [[Donny Osmond]], [[Chaka Khan]], [[112 (band)|112]],<ref name=secondhandsongs /> [[Vienna Boys\' Choir|the Vienna Boys\' Choir]],<ref name=coverinfo.de /> [[Herb Alpert]],<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Herb-Alpert-Beyond/release/826476|title=Herb Alpert|publisher=discogs.com}}
</ref> [[Musiq Soulchild]],<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.homdrum.net/ewf/cover_versions.html|title=Cover Versions & Samples|publisher=Surfer\'s Guide to Earth, Wind & Fire}}
</ref> and [[Tito Puente]].<ref name=secondhandsongs />

Earth, Wind & Fire\'s songs have been sampled by numerous artists, including [[UGK]], [[A Tribe Called Quest]], [[Wyclef Jean]], [[Missy Elliott]], [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Nas]]<ref name=samplespot>
{{cite web|url=http://samplespot.com/index.php5?sp=12&artID=4004|title=Earth, Wind and Fire|publisher=samplespot.com|accessdate=January 18, 2009}}
</ref> [[Jay-Z]],<ref name=whosampled>
{{cite web|url=http://www.whosampled.com/artist/Earth,%20Wind%20%26%20Fire/|title=Earth, Wind and Fire|publisher=whosampled.com|accessdate=January 18, 2009}}
</ref> [[Amerie]], [[The Fugees]], [[LL Cool J]], [[De La Soul]], [[Common (rapper)|Common]], [[Frank Zappa]], [[Naughty by Nature]], [[P Diddy]], [[The Roots]], [[Will Smith]],<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/big-willie-style|title=Will Smith|publisher=discogs.com}}
</ref> [[Cee-Lo Green]],<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Cee-Lo?anv=Cee-Lo+Green|title=Cee-Lo|publisher=discogs.com}}
</ref> [[Lisa Lopes|Lisa "Left Eye" Lopes]]<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Lisa-Left-Eye-Lopes-Supernova/release/309595|title=Lisa Left Eye Lopes|publisher=discogs.com}}
</ref> of [[TLC (band)|TLC]], [[Public Enemy (group)|Public Enemy]], [[EPMD]], [[Lupe Fiasco]], [[Bone Thugs-N-Harmony]], [[Tupac Shakur]] and [[MC Lyte]].<ref name=coverinfo.de /><ref name=secondhandsongs /><ref name=samplespot /><ref name=whosampled />

Earth, Wind & Fire have influenced artists such as [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]],<ref name=cnn>
