\'\'\'Beverly Grace Jones\'\'\' (born 19 May 1948) is a [[Jamaica]]n singer, songwriter, model, record producer, and actress. She was born in [[Spanish Town]], Jamaica and raised by her grandparents. At 13 she moved with her siblings to their parents\' home in [[Syracuse, New York]]. Jones started out as a model, initially in New York state, then in [[Paris]], working for [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves St. Laurent]], [[Claude Montana]], and [[Kenzo Takada]], and appearing on the covers of \'\'[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]\'\', \'\'[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]\'\', and \'\'[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]\'\' working with [[Helmut Newton]], [[Guy Bourdin]], and Hans Feurer.

In 1977 Jones secured a record deal with [[Island Records]]; with the aid of [[Compass Point All Stars]] she moved into [[New wave music|new wave]] in 1980. She scored Top 40 entries on the [[UK Singles Chart]] with "[[Pull Up to the Bumper]]", "[[I\'ve Seen That Face Before (Libertango)|I\'ve Seen That Face Before]]", "[[Private Life]]", "[[Slave to the Rhythm (Grace Jones song)|Slave to the Rhythm]]" and "[[I\'m Not Perfect (But I\'m Perfect for You)|I\'m Not Perfect]]". Her albums include \'\'[[Warm Leatherette (album)|Warm Leatherette]]\'\' (1980), \'\'[[Nightclubbing (Grace Jones album)|Nightclubbing]]\'\' (1981), and \'\'[[Slave to the Rhythm (album)|Slave to the Rhythm]]\'\' (1985).

She appeared in some low-budget films in the U.S. during the 1970s and early 1980s. Her first mainstream film was the 1984 fantasy-action film \'\'[[Conan the Destroyer]]\'\' alongside [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], and the 1985 [[James Bond]] movie \'\'[[A View to a Kill]]\'\'. In 1986 she played a vampire in \'\'[[Vamp (film)|Vamp]]\'\', and acted in and contributed a song to the 1992 [[Eddie Murphy]] film \'\'[[Boomerang (1992 film)|Boomerang]]\'\'. She appeared alongside [[Tim Curry]] in the 2001 film \'\'[[Wolf Girl]]\'\'.

In 1983, Jones\'s \'\'[[A One Man Show|One Man Show]]\'\' was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] for Best Long-Form Music Video. For her work in \'\'Conan the Destroyer\'\', \'\'A View to a Kill\'\', and \'\'Vamp\'\', she was nominated [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actress|Saturn Awards for Best Supporting Actress]]. In 1999, Jones ranked 82nd on [[VH1]]\'s \'\'100 Greatest Women of Rock and Roll\'\', and in 2008, she was honored with a [[Q Awards|Q Idol Award]]. Jones influenced the [[cross-dressing]] movement of the 1980s and has been an inspiration for artists including [[Annie Lennox]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Rihanna]], [[Brazilian Girls]], [[Nile Rodgers]], [[Santigold]], and [[Basement Jaxx]].

==Biography and career==

===1948\xe2\x80\x9373: Early life, and modelling career===
Grace Jones was born in 1948<ref Name=Biog>{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/grace-jones |title=Grace Jones biography|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> in [[Spanish Town]], [[Jamaica]], the daughter of Marjorie (n\xc3\xa9e Williams) and Robert W. Jones, who was a local politician and [[Apostolic Church (denomination)|Apostolic]] clergyman.<ref>Henley, Patricia. The Hummingbird House. Denver: MacMurray, 1999. Print.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Winston Jones Obituary|url=http://obits.syracuse.com/obituaries/syracuse/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=109731509#fbLoggedOut|publisher=syracuse.com|accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=City of Refuge Church \xe2\x80\x93 Los Angeles Bishop Noel Jones|url=http://www.noeljonesministries.org/senior_pastor.shtml|accessdate=10 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/oct/12/grace-jones-hurricane|title=State of Grace|author=Miranda Sawyer|work=the Guardian}}</ref> Jones and her siblings were raised by grandparents, as her parents were working in the United States. Jones had a strict upbringing under the influence of Jamaica\'s [[Pentecostal]] church and went to church three times a week. Both sides of her family were religious; there were many bishops in her family, including her grandfather, stepfather, and [[Noel Jones (Pentecostal bishop)|Noel]], her brother.

As a child,  shy Jones had only one schoolfriend and was teased by classmates for her "skinny frame", but she excelled at sports and found solace in the nature of Jamaica.<ref name="Sawyer">{{cite news|last=Sawyer|first=Miranda|title=State of Grace: Miranda Sawyer Meets Grace Jones|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2008/oct/12/grace-jones-hurricane|publisher=The Observer|accessdate=24 May 2013|location=London|date=11 October 2008}}</ref>

When she was 13, she and her siblings moved to [[Syracuse, New York]] to join her parents.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Helen|title=Grace Jones at 60|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandjazzmusic/3562845/Grace-Jones-at-60.html|publisher=The Telepgraph|accessdate=3 June 2013|date=4 November 2008|location=London}}</ref> Jones continued her schooling and after she graduated, enrolled at [[Onondaga Community College]] majoring in Spanish.<ref name="exotic">{{cite web|title=Jones the Exotic May Day|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2211&dat=19850608&id=DjAmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=W_4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1014,2000938|publisher=The Afro-American|accessdate=26 May 2013|date=8 June 1985}}</ref> Halfway through college, Jones was approached by a drama professor who proposed that she work with him in a play he was putting on in [[Philadelphia]]; Jones left with him.<ref name="exotic" /> She moved back to New York at 18 and signed on as a model with [[Wilhelmina Models|Wilhelmina Modelling agency]]. She moved to Paris in 1970.<ref name="exotic" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Lopez|first=Antonio|title=Antonio Lopez: Fashion, Art, Sex, and Disco|year=2012|publisher=Rizzoli|isbn=0847837920}}</ref> The Parisian fashion scene was receptive to Jones\' unusual androgynous, bold, dark-skinned appearance. [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves St. Laurent]], [[Claude Montana]], and [[Kenzo Takada]] hired her for runway modelling, and she appeared on the covers of \'\'[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]\'\', \'\'[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]\'\', and \'\'[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]\'\' working with [[Helmut Newton]], [[Guy Bourdin]], and Hans Feurer.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kershaw|first=Miriam|title=Performance Art|journal=Art Journal|year=1997|volume=56|issue=Performance Art|pages=19\xe2\x80\x9325|doi=10.2307/777716}}</ref> Jones also modelled for [[Azzedine Alaia]], and was frequently photographed promoting their line. While modelling in Paris, she shared an apartment with [[Jerry Hall]] and [[Jessica Lange]]. Hall and Jones frequented [[Guy Cuevas|Club Sept]], one of Paris\'s most popular gay clubs of the 1970s and \'80s, and socialised with [[Giorgio Armani]] and [[Karl Lagerfeld]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Grace Jones|url=http://www.thefashioninsider.com/supermodels/38.html?lang=FR|publisher=Fashion Insider: Supermodels Encyclopedia|accessdate=5 May 2013}}</ref>

===1974\xe2\x80\x9379: Transition to music, and early releases===
Jones was signed by [[Island Records]], who put her in the studio with disco record producer, [[Tom Moulton]]. Moulton worked at [[Sigma Sound Studios]] in [[Philadelphia]], and \'\'[[Portfolio (Grace Jones album)|Portfolio]]\'\', was released in 1977. The album featured three songs from Broadway musicals, "[[Send in the Clowns]]" by [[Stephen Sondheim]] from \'\'[[A Little Night Music]]\'\', "What I Did for Love" from \'\'[[A Chorus Line]]\'\' and "[[Tomorrow (1977 song)|Tomorrow]]" from \'\'[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]\'\'. The second side of the album opens up with a seven-minute reinterpretation of [[\xc3\x89dith Piaf]]\'s "[[La Vie en rose]]" followed by three new recordings, two of which were co-written by Jones, "Sorry", and "That\'s the Trouble", The album finished with "[[I Need a Man (Grace Jones song)|I Need a Man]]", Jones\' first club hit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Grace-Jones-Portfolio/release/1717094 |title=Grace Jones \xe2\x80\x93 Portfolio (Vinyl, LP, Album) at Discogs |work=discogs.com |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> The artwork to the album was designed by Richard Bernstein, an artist for \'\'[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]\'\'.

In 1978, Jones and Moulton made \'\'[[Fame (album)|Fame]]\'\', an immediate follow-up to \'\'Portfolio\'\', also recorded at Sigma Sound Studios. The album featured another reinterpretation of a French classic, "[[Autumn Leaves (song)|Autumn Leaves]]" by [[Jacques Pr\xc3\xa9vert]]. The Canadian edition of the vinyl album included another French language track, "Comme un oiseau qui s\'envole", which replaced "All on a Summers Night"; in most locations this song served as the B-side of the single "[[Do or Die (Grace Jones song)|Do or Die]]".

In the North American club scene, \'\'Fame\'\' was a hit album and the "Do or Die"/"Pride"/"Fame" side reached top 10 on both the US [[Hot Dance Club Songs|Hot Dance Club Play]] and Canadian Dance/Urban charts. The album was released on compact disc in the early 1990s, but soon went [[out of print]]. In 2011, it was released and remastered by Gold Legion, a record company that specialises in reissuing classic disco albums on CD.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shop.goldlegion.com/Grace-Jones-Fame-GLDN56226.htm |title=Grace Jones Fame |accessdate=21 August 2012 |publisher=shop.goldlegion.com}}</ref>

\'\'[[Muse (Grace Jones album)|Muse]]\'\' was the last of Jones\' disco albums. The album features a re-recorded version "I\'ll Find My Way to You", which Jones released three years prior to \'\'Muse\'\'. Originally appearing on the 1976 Italian film, \'\'[[Colt 38 Special Squad]]\'\') in which Jones had a role as a club singer, Jones also recorded a song called "Again and Again" which was featured on the film. Both songs were produced by composer [[Stelvio Cipriani]]. Icelandic keyboardist Thor Baldursson who arranged most of the album and also sang duet with Jones on the track "Suffer" had previously worked in Munich, with disco stars such as [[Silver Convention]], [[Boney M.]], [[Donna Summer]], [[Amanda Lear]] and [[Giorgio Moroder]]. Like the last two albums, the cover art is by Richard Bernstein. Like \'\'Fame\'\', \'\'Muse\'\' was later released by Gold Legion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shop.goldlegion.com/Grace-Jones-Muse-GLGN-56227.htm |title=Grace Jones Fame |accessdate=21 August 2012 |publisher=shop.goldlegion.com}}</ref>

===1980\xe2\x80\x9385: International breakthrough, \'\'Nightclubbing\'\', and movie career ===
With anti-disco sentiment spreading, and with the aid of the [[Compass Point All Stars]], Jones transitioned into [[new wave music]] with the 1980 release of \'\'[[Warm Leatherette (album)|Warm Leatherette]]\'\'. The album included covers of songs by [[The Normal]] ("[[Warm Leatherette (song)|Warm Leatherette]]"), [[The Pretenders]] ("[[Private Life]]"), [[Roxy Music]] ("[[Love is the Drug]]"), [[Smokey Robinson]] ("[[The Hunter Gets Captured by the Game]]"), [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]] ("Breakdown") and [[Jacques Higelin]] ("Pars"). Sly Dunbar revealed that the title track was also the first to be recorded with Jones.<ref name="41b">{{cite web |url=http://www.theworldofgracejones.com/41b.html |title=The World of Grace Jones |accessdate=26 May 2012 |publisher=theworldofgracejones.com}}{{dead link|date=October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theworldofgracejones.com/46b.html |title=The World of Grace Jones |accessdate=26 May 2012 |publisher=theworldofgracejones.com}}{{dead link|date=October 2013}}</ref> Tom Petty wrote the lyrics to "Breakdown", and he also wrote the third verse of Jones\' reinterpretation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sadclownrep.com/7538/3349-breakdown-by-grace-jones/ |title=3349. "Breakdown" by Grace Jones |author=Joey Michaels |work=sadclownrep.com |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> The album included one song co-written by Jones, "A Rolling Stone". Originally, "Pull Up to the Bumper" was to be included on the album, but its R&B sound did not fit with the rest of the material.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=13898 |title=Pull Up to the Bumper by Grace Jones Songfacts |work=songfacts.com |accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref>

The 1981 release of \'\'[[Nightclubbing (Grace Jones album)|Nightclubbing]]\'\' included Jones\' covers of songs by [[Flash and the Pan]] ("[[Walking in the Rain (Flash and the Pan song)|Walking in the Rain]]"), [[Bill Withers]] ("[[Use Me (Bill Withers song)|Use Me]]"), [[Iggy Pop]]/[[David Bowie]] ("[[Nightclubbing (song)|Nightclubbing]]") and [[\xc3\x81stor Piazzolla]] ("[[I\'ve Seen That Face Before (Libertango)|I\'ve Seen That Face Before]]"). Three songs were co-written by Jones: "Feel Up", "Art Groupie" and "[[Pull Up to the Bumper]]". [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] wrote "[[Demolition Man (song)|Demolition Man]]"; he later recorded it with [[The Police]] on the album \'\'[[Ghost in the Machine (The Police album)|Ghost in the Machine]]\'\'. "I\'ve Done It Again" was written by [[Marianne Faithfull]]. The strong rhythm featured on \'\'Nightclubbing\'\' was produced by Compass Point All Stars, including [[Sly and Robbie]], [[Wally Badarou]], [[Mikey Chung]], [[Uziah Thompson|Uziah "Sticky" Thompson]] and [[Barry Reynolds]]. The album entered in the Top 5 in four countries, and became Jones\' highest-ranking record on the US [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] mainstream albums and R&B charts.

\'\'Nightclubbing\'\' claimed the #1 slot on NME\'s Album of the Year list.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rocklistmusic.co.uk/1981.html |title=Rocklist.net...NME End of Year Lists 1981... |accessdate=28 May 2012 |publisher=rocklistmusic.co.uk}}</ref> Slant Magazine listed the album at No. 40 on its list of Best Albums of the 1980s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/feature/best-albums-of-the-1980s/308/page_7 |title=Best Albums of the 1980s |accessdate=18 March 2012 |publisher=slantmagazine.com}}</ref> \'\'Nightclubbing\'\' is now widely considered Jones\' best studio album.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sadclownrep.com/7479/3333-walking-in-the-rain-by-grace-jones/ |title=3333. "Walking in the Rain" by Grace Jones |accessdate=19 August 2012 |publisher=sadclownrep.com}}</ref> The album\'s cover art is a painting of Jones by [[Jean-Paul Goude]]. Jones is presented as a man wearing an [[Giorgio Armani|Armani]] suit jacket, with a cigarette in her mouth and a [[flattop]] haircut. To promote the album, Jones appeared alongside psychotherapist Sonja Vetter, and slapped chat-show host [[Russell Harty]] live on air after he had turned to interview other guests, making Jones feel she was being ignored.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jones slap tops TV chat show poll|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_pictures/4637648.stm|accessdate=3 May 2013 | work=BBC News|date=22 January 2006}}</ref>

Having already recorded two reggae-oriented albums under the production of Compass Point All Stars, Jones went to [[Nassau, Bahamas]] in 1982 and recorded \'\'[[Living My Life (album)]]\'\'; the album resulted in Jones\' final contribution to the Compass Point trilogy, with only one cover, [[Melvin Van Peebles]]\'s "[[The Apple Stretching]]". The rest were original songs; "[[Nipple to the Bottle]]" was co-written with [[Sly Dunbar]], and, apart from "[[My Jamaican Guy]]", the other tracks were collaborations with [[Barry Reynolds]]. Despite receiving a limited single release, the [[Living My Life (song)|title track]] was left off the album. Further session outtakes included "Man Around the House" (Jones, Reynolds) and a cover of [[Johnny Cash]]\'s "[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]", both of which were included in the 1998 compilation \'\'[[Private Life: The Compass Point Sessions]]\'\'. The album\'s cover art resulted from another Jones/[[Jean-Paul Goude|Goude]] collaboration; the artwork has been described as being as famous as the music on the record.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dummymag.com/reviews/2007/06/06/the-best-record-about-new-york-/ |title=The Apple Stretching Dummy \xc2\xbb Reviews |author=Paul Flynn |accessdate=24 May 2012 |publisher=dummymag.com}}</ref> It features Jones\' disembodied head cut out from a photograph and pasted onto a white background. Jones\' head is sharpened, giving her head and face an angular shape.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wnew.radio.com/2011/11/25/awesome-album-covers-grace-jones-living-my-life/ |title=Awesome Album Covers: Grace Jones\xe2\x80\x99 "Living My Life" |author=Michael Verity |accessdate=24 May 2012 |publisher=wnew.radio.com}}</ref> A piece of plaster is pasted over her left eyebrow, and her forehead is covered with drops of sweat.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pinterest.com/pin/168181367304933195/ |title=volume 2 / Some inspiration. Grace Jones Living my life. Art direction by Jean Paul Goude. 1982 |author=John Paul Thurlow |accessdate=24 May 2012 |publisher=pinterest.com}}</ref>

Jones\' three albums under the production of the Compass Point All Stars resulted in Jones\' \'\'[[A One Man Show|One Man Show]]\'\', a [[performance art]]/pop theatre presentation devised by Goude and Jones in which she also performed tracks from the albums \'\'[[Portfolio (Grace Jones album)|Portfolio]]\'\' ("[[La Vie en rose#Grace Jones version|La Vie en rose]]"), \'\'[[Warm Leatherette (album)|Warm Leatherette]]\'\', ("[[Private Life]]", "[[Warm Leatherette]]"), \'\'[[Nightclubbing (Grace Jones album)|Nightclubbing]]\'\' ("Walking in the Rain", "Feel Up", "Demolition Man", "Pull Up to the Bumper" and "I\'ve Seen That Face Before (Libertango))" and from \'\'Living My Life\'\', "My Jamaican Guy" and the album\'s [[Living My Life|title track]]. Jones dressed in elaborate costumes and masks (in the opening sequence as a gorilla) and alongside a series of Grace Jones [[lookalike]]s. A video version, filmed live in London and New York City and completed with some studio footage, was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] for Best Long-Form Music Video next year.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Grace|title=Grammy Awards (1984)|url=http://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000301/1984|publisher=imdb.com}}</ref>

After the release of \'\'Living My Life\'\', Jones took on the role of Zula the [[Amazons|Amazonian]] in \'\'[[Conan the Destroyer]]\'\' (1984) and  was nominated for a [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. In 1985, Jones starred as May Day, henchman to main antagonist [[Max Zorin]] in the 14th [[James Bond]] film \'\'[[A View to a Kill]]\'\'; Jones was also nominated for a [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. That same year, she was featured on the [[Arcadia (band)|Arcadia]] song "[[Election Day (song)|Election Day]]". Jones was among the many stars to promote the [[Honda]] Scooter; other artists included [[Lou Reed]], [[Adam Ant]], and [[Miles Davis]].<ref>{{cite web|title=LOU REED, MILES DAVIS AND GRACE JONES SELLING HONDA SCOOTERS AND TDK TAPE IN THE 1980S|url=http://dangerousminds.net/comments/lou_reed_miles_davis_and_grace_jones_selling_honda_scooters_and_tdk_ta|publisher=Dangerousminds.net|accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref> Jones also, with her boyfriend [[Dolph Lundgren]] posed nude for \'\'[[Playboy]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amazing Grace: she battles bond, rocks with "rocky iv" hunk dolph lundgren-- have you met miss jones?|url=http://www.dolph-ultimate.com/articles/playboy.html|publisher=Dolph: The Ultimate Guide|accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref>

After Jones\' success as a mainstream actress, she returned to the studio to work on \'\'[[Slave to the Rhythm (album)|Slave to the Rhythm]]\'\', the last of her recordings for [[Island records|Island]]. [[Bruce Woolley]], Simon Darlow, [[Stephen Lipson]] and [[Trevor Horn]] wrote the material, and it was produced by Horn and Lipson. It was a concept album that featured several interpretations of the title track. The project was originally intended for [[Frankie Goes to Hollywood]] as a follow-up to "[[Relax (song)|Relax]]", but was given to Jones.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.perfectsongs.com/artists_writers/trevor_horn.html| title = Perfect Songs artists/writers Trevor Horn| accessdate = 12 February 2012| work = perfectsongs.com}}</ref> All eight tracks on the album featured excerpts from a conversation with Jones, speaking about many aspects of her life. The interview was conducted by journalist [[Paul Morley]]. The album features [[voice-over]]s from actor [[Ian McShane]] reciting passages from [[Jean-Paul Goude]]\'s biography \'\'Jungle Fever\'\'. \'\'Slave to the Rhythm\'\' was successful in [[German language in Europe|German-speaking countries]] and in the Netherlands, where it secured Top 10 placings. It reached #12 on the [[UK Albums Chart]] in November 1985 and became the second-highest-ranking album released by Jones.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9SQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA2&dq=billboard+grace+jones+inside+story&hl=pt-BR&ei=xhGRTeH3A8TqgQea5qgZ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Billboard \xe2\x80\x93 Google Livros |publisher=[[Google Books]] |date=22 November 1986 |accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com.br/books?id=ICUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA74&dq=grace+jones+million&hl=pt-br&ei=OmqRTbeCGsLegQfghoUZ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CEoQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=grace%20jones%20million&f=false |title=Billboard \xe2\x80\x93 Google Livros |publisher=Google Books |date=13 December 1986 |accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref> Jones earned an [[MTV Video Music Award]] nomination for the title track\'s music video.

After her success with \'\'Slave to the Rhythm\'\', Island released \'\'[[Island Life]]\'\', Jones\' first best-of compilation, which featured songs from most of her releases with Island (\'\'Portfolio\'\', \'\'Fame\'\', \'\'Warm Leatherette\'\', \'\'Nightclubbing\'\', \'\'Living My Life\'\' and \'\'Slave to the Rhythm\'\'). American writer and journalist [[Glenn O\'Brien]] wrote the essay for the inlay booklet. The compilation charted in the UK, New Zealand and the United States.<ref>{{cite web|title=Li: Island Life|url=http://www.libraryofinspiration.com/music_1980s_islandlife.htm|publisher=Library of Inspiration}}</ref> The artwork on the cover of the compilation was of another (Jones/[[Jean-Paul Goude|Goude]]) collaboration; it featured Jones\' celestial body in a montage of separate images, following Goude\'s ideas on creating credible illusions with his cut-and-paint technique. The body position is anatomically impossible.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/image/0,,1672997,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080615063938/http://arts.guardian.co.uk/image/0,,1672997,00.html |archivedate=2008-06-15 |title=Snapshot: Grace Jones |author=Will Hodgkinson |accessdate=1 August 2009 |publisher=web.archive.org |work=arts.guardian.co.uk |location=London}}</ref>

The artwork, a piece called "Nigger Arabesque" was originally published in the \'\'[[New York (magazine)|New York]]\'\' magazine in 1978, and was used as a backdrop for the music video of Jones\' hit single "[[La Vie en rose#Grace Jones version|La Vie en rose]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Fake a Grace Jones Cover|url=http://flavorwire.com/73088/how-to-fake-a-grace-jones-cover|publisher=Flavorwire|accessdate=10 June 2013}}</ref> The artwork has been described as "one of pop culture\'s most famous photographs".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://afirstclassriot.com/2011/06/01/images-grace-jones-by-jean-paul-goude/ |title=Images: Grace Jones by Jean-Paul Goude |accessdate=15 August 2012 |publisher=afirstclassriot.com}}</ref> The image was also parodied in [[Nicki Minaj]]\'s 2011 music video for "[[Stupid Hoe]]", in which Minaj mimicked the pose.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenynthlife.com/nicki-minaj-channels-beyonce-grace-jones-and-gaga-in-stupid-hoe/ |title=Nicki Minaj Channels Beyonc\xc3\xa9, Grace Jones, and Gaga in "Stupid Hoe" |accessdate=14 May 2012 |publisher=thenynthlife.com}}</ref>

===1986\xe2\x80\x9389: \'\'Slave to the Rhythm\'\', \'\'Island Life\'\', and continued acting roles ===
After \'\'[[Slave to the Rhythm (album)|Slave to the Rhythm]]\'\' and \'\'[[Island Life]]\'\', Jones started to record again under a new contract with [[Manhattan Records]], which resulted in \'\'[[Inside Story (Grace Jones album)|Inside Story]]\'\', Jones teamed up with music producer [[Nile Rodgers]] of [[Chic (band)|Chic]], who Jones had previously tried to work with during the disco era.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.disco-disco.com/tributes/chic.shtml |title=Nile & Bernard - Chic - Tribute @ Disco-Disco.com |accessdate=19 April 2012 |publisher=disco-disco.com}}</ref> The album was recorded at Skyline Studios in New York and post-produced at Atlantic Studios and Sterling Sound. \'\'Inside Story\'\' was the first album Jones produced, which resulted in heated disputes with Rodgers. Musically, the album was more accessible than her previous albums with the Compass Point All Stars, and explored different styles of pop music, with undertones of jazz, gospel, and Caribbean sounds. All songs on the album were written by Jones and [[Bruce Woolley]]. Richard Bernstein teamed up with Jones again to provide the album\'s artwork. \'\'Inside Story\'\' made the top 40 in several European countries. The album was Jones\' last entry to date on US [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]] albums chart. The same year, Jones starred as Katrina, an Egyptian queen vampire in the [[vampire film]] \'\'[[Vamp (film)|Vamp]]\'\'. For her work in the film, Jones was awarded a [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. The following year, Jones appeared in two films, \'\'[[Straight to Hell (film)|Straight to Hell]]\'\', and [[Mary Lambert]]\'s \'\'[[Siesta (film)|Siesta]]\'\', for which Jones was nominated for [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actress]].
\'\'[[Bulletproof Heart]]\'\' was released in 1989, produced by Chris Stanley, who co-wrote, and co-produced the majority of the songs, and was featured as a guest vocalist on "Don\'t Cry Freedom". [[Robert Clivill\xc3\xa9s]] and [[David Cole (producer)|David Cole]] of [[C+C Music Factory]] produced some tracks on the album.

===1990\xe2\x80\x932004: \'\'Boomerang\'\', movie soundtrack recordings, and artist collaborations===
In 1990, Jones appeared as herself in the documentary, \'\'Superstar: The Life and Times of Andy Warhol\'\'. 1992 saw Jones starring as Helen Strang\xc3\xa9, in the [[Eddie Murphy]] film \'\'[[Boomerang (1992 film)|Boomerang]]\'\', for which she also contributed the song "[[7 Day Weekend (song)|7 Day Weekend]]" to [[Boomerang (soundtrack)|its soundtrack]]. Jones released two more soundtrack songs in 1992; "[[Evilmainya]]", recorded for the film \'\'[[Freddie as F.R.O.7]]\'\', and "Let Joy and Innocence Prevail" for the film \'\'[[Toys (film)|Toys]]\'\'. In 1994, she was due to release an [[electronic music|electro]] album titled \'\'Black Marilyn\'\' with artwork featuring the singer as [[Marilyn Monroe]]. "[[Sex Drive (song)|Sex Drive]]" was released as the first single in September 1993, but due to unknown reasons the record was eventually shelved. The track "Volunteer", recorded during the same sessions, leaked in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qt6s3NNVrQ4 |title=Grace Jones - Volunteer (Rare demo) |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-09-13 |accessdate=2014-07-11}}</ref>

1996 Saw Jones releasing "[[Love Bites (Grace Jones song)|Love Bites]]", an up-tempo electronic track to promote the [[Syfy|Sci-Fi Channel\'s]] \'\'Vampire Week\'\', which consisted of a series of vampire-themed films aired on the channel in early November 1996. The track features Jones singing from the perspective of a vampire. The track was released as a non-label promo-only single. To this day, it has not been made commercially available.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/cgi/news/release?id=16145 |title=SCI-FI CHANNEL LAUNCH VAMPIRE FILM SEASON WITH WORLDWIDE EXCLUSIVE \xe2\x80\x93 A NEW SONG FROM GRACE JONES |work=prnewswire.co.uk |accessdate=6 February 2012}}</ref>
In June 1998, she was scheduled to release an album entitled \'\'Force of Nature\'\', on which she worked with [[trip hop]] musician [[Tricky (musician)|Tricky]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/1997/110697/cover.html |title=Grace Jones |work=montrealmirror.com |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> The release of \'\'Force of Nature\'\' was cancelled due to a disagreement between the two, and only a [[white label]] 12" single featuring two dance mixes of "[[Hurricane (Cradle to the Grave)|Hurricane]]" was issued at the time;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/release/215220 |title=Grace Jones \xe2\x80\x93 Hurricane (Vinyl) at Discogs |work=discogs.com |accessdate=30 August 2008}}</ref> a slowed-down version of this song became the title track of her comeback album released ten years later while another unreleased track from the album, "Clandestine Affair" (recycling the chorus from her unreleased 1993 track "Volunteer"), appeared on a bootleg 12" in 1004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Grace-Jones-Tricky-Clandestine-Affair/master/203097 |title=Grace Jones & Tricky - Clandestine Affair at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-11}}</ref> Jones recorded the track "Storm" in 1998 for the movie \'\'[[The Avengers (1998 film)|The Avengers]]\'\', and in 1999, appeared in an episode of the \'\'[[BeastMaster (TV series)|Beastmaster]]\'\' television series as the Umpatra Warrior.

The same year, Jones recorded "The Perfect Crime", an up-tempo song for Danish TV written by the composer duo Floppy M. aka Jacob Duus and K\xc3\xa5re Jacobsen. Jones was also ranked 82nd place on [[VH1]]\'s "100 Greatest Women of Rock & Roll". In 2000, Jones collaborated with rapper [[Lil\' Kim]], appearing on the song "Revolution" from her album \'\'[[The Notorious K.I.M.]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/store/artist/album/0,,1023051,00.html |title=The Notorious K I M by Lil Kim @ ARTISTdirect.com \xe2\x80\x93 Shop, Listen, Download |publisher=Artistdirect.com |date=27 June 2000 |accessdate=13 April 2012}}</ref> In 2001, Jones starred in the made-for-television film, \'\'[[Wolf Girl]]\'\' (also known as \'\'Blood Moon\'\'), as an [[intersex]] circus performer named Christoph/Christine.  In 2002, Jones joined [[Luciano Pavarotti]] on stage for his annual [[Pavarotti and Friends]] fundraiser concert to support the United Nations refugee agency\'s programs for Angolan refugees in [[Zambia]]. In November 2004, Jones sang "[[Slave to the Rhythm (Grace Jones song)|Slave to the Rhythm]]" at a tribute concert for record producer [[Trevor Horn]] at London\'s [[Wembley Arena]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2004/nov/13/popandrock |title=Produced by Trevor Horn, Wembley Arena, London \xe2\x80\x93 Music \xe2\x80\x93 The Guardian |author=[[Alexis Petridis]] |date=13 November 2004 |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=29 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/collective/A3308645 |title=BBC \xe2\x80\x93 collective \xe2\x80\x93 Produced by Trevor Horn |date=21 November 2004 |work=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=29 September 2010}}</ref>

===2008\xe2\x80\x93present: \'\'Hurricane\'\', recent endeavours, and \'\'Nightclubbing\'\' deluxe===
Despite several comeback attempts throughout the 1990s, Jones\' next full length record was released almost twenty years later, after Jones decided "never to do an album again",<ref>{{cite news |author=Michael Osborn |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7747522.stm |title=An audience with Grace Jones |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=26 November 2008 |accessdate=11 January 2012}}</ref> changing her mind after meeting music producer [[Ivor Guest, 4th Viscount Wimborne|Ivor Guest]] through a mutual friend, [[milliner]] [[Philip Treacy]]. After the two became acquainted, Guest let Jones listen to a track he had been working on, which became "Devil in My Life", once Jones set the lyrics to the song. The lyrics to the song were written after a party in Venice.<ref name="guardian2010">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2010/apr/17/grace-jones-interview |title=Grace Jones: \'God I\'m scary. I\'m scaring myself\' \xe2\x80\x93 Music \xe2\x80\x93 The Guardian |author=Simon Hattenstone |date=17 April 2010 |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref>
The two ended up with 23 tracks. The album included autobiographical songs, such as "This Is", "[[Williams\' Blood]]" and "I\'m Crying (Mother\'s Tears)", an ode to her mother Marjorie. "[[Love You to Life]]" was another track based on real events and "[[Corporate Cannibal]]" referred to [[corporate capitalism]]. "Well Well Well" was recorded in memory of [[Alex Sadkin]], member of [[Compass Point All Stars]] who had died in a motor accident 1987. "Sunset Sunrise" was written by Jones\' son, Paulo; the song ponders the relationship between mankind and mother nature. Four songs were removed from the album, "The Key to Funky", "Body Phenomenon", "Sister Sister" and "Misery". For the production of the album, Jones teamed up with [[Sly and Robbie]], [[Wally Badarou]], [[Barry Reynolds]], [[Mikey Chung]], and [[Uziah Thompson|Uziah "Sticky" Thompson]], of the [[Compass Point All Stars]], with contributions from trip-hop artist [[Tricky (musician)|Tricky]], and [[Brian Eno]].<ref>{{cite web|title=aulo Goude Son of a Hurricane|url=http://missgracejones.com/paulo/|publisher=missgracejones.com|author=Frank Veldkamp|year=2009}}</ref>

The album was released on [[Wall of Sound]] on 3 November 2008 in the United Kingdom. [[PIAS Recordings|PIAS]], the umbrella company of Wall of Sound, distributed \'\'Hurricane\'\' worldwide excluding North America.<ref>{{cite news |author=Lars Brandle |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/news/e3i5b79f51055d2eac91f4ee12074050f1a |title=\'Hurricane\' Jones Blows Through This October |publisher=billboard.biz |accessdate=30 June 2008}}</ref> The album scored 72 out of 100 on review aggregator [[Metacritic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/hurricane |title=Hurricane Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More |publisher=Metacritic.com |accessdate=11 January 2012}}</ref>
Prior to the album\'s release, Jones performed at [[Massive Attack]]\'s [[Meltdown (festival)|Meltdown festival]] in London on 19 June 2008, Jones performed four new songs from the album and premiered the music video which Jones and artist Nick Hooker collaborated on, which resulted in "[[Corporate Cannibal]]".<ref>{{cite news |author=Colin Paterson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7465083.stm |title=Grace Jones performs at Meltdown |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=20 June 2008 |accessdate=13 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Sam Jones |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2008/apr/21/festivals |title=Meltdown moves from trip-hop to sci-fi with style |publisher=guardian.co.uk |accessdate=25 June 2008 |location=London |date=21 April 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nickhooker.com/news.html |title=nick hooker |work=nickhooker.com |accessdate=29 September 2010}}</ref> Jones promoted the album even further by appearing on talk show \'\'[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]\'\', performed at several awards galas, and embarked on \'\'The Hurricane Tour\'\'. The same year, Jones was honoured with [[Q Awards|Q Idol Award]]. In 2009, [[Chris Cunningham]] produced a fashion shoot for \'\'[[Dazed & Confused (magazine)|Dazed & Confused]]\'\' using Jones as a model to create "Nubian versions" of Rubber Johnny.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/ArtsAndCulture/article/1273/1/Chris_Cunningham_Photographs_Grace_Jones_for_DC |title=Grace Jones photoshoot for Dazed and Confused |publisher=Dazeddigital.com |date= |accessdate=30 August 2009}}</ref> In an interview for BBC\'s \'\'The Culture Show\'\', it was suggested that the collaboration may expand into a video project. Jones also worked with the avant-garde poet [[Brigitte Fontaine]] on a duet named "Soufi" from Fontaine\'s album \'\'Prohibition\'\' released in 2009, and produced by [[Ivor Guest, 4th Viscount Wimborne|Ivor Guest]].
In March 2010 Jones performed for guests at the 18th annual [[Elton John AIDS Foundation]] [[Academy Award]] Viewing Party. The Elton John AIDS Foundation is one of the world\'s leading nonprofit organisations supporting HIV prevention programs, and works to eliminate the stigma and discrimination associated with HIV/AIDS. That evening, US$3.7 million was raised.<ref>{{cite web|title=Grace Jones to Perform at 18th Annual Elton John AIDS Foundation Academy Awards Viewing Party|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/grace-jones-to-perform-at-18th-annual-elton-john-aids-foundation-academy-awards-viewing-party-85444777.html|accessdate=5 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=$3.7 Million Raised at Elton John AIDS Foundation Oscar Party|url=http://www.hauteliving.com/2010/03/3-7-million-raised-at-elton-john-aids-foundation-oscar-party/28565/|accessdate=5 May 2013}}</ref> The same year, a budget DVD version of \'\'A One Man Show\'\' was released, as \'\'Grace Jones \xe2\x80\x93 Live in Concert\'\'. It included three bonus video clips ("[[Slave to the Rhythm (Grace Jones song)|Slave to the Rhythm]]", "[[Love Is the Drug]]" and "[[Crush (Grace Jones song)|Crush]]". 2011 saw Jones again collaborating with Brigitte Fontaine on two tracks from her 2011 release entitled \'\'L\'un n\'emp\xc3\xaache pas l\'autre\'\' and performed at the opening ceremony of the [[61st FIFA Congress]].<ref name="curtain-raises">{{Cite news |date=31 May 2011 |url=http://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/federation/bodies/news/newsid=1441187.html |title=Curtain rises on Congress |publisher=fifa.com}}</ref> Jones released a dub version of the album, \'\'Hurricane \xe2\x80\x93 Dub\'\', which came out on 5 September 2011. The dub versions were made by [[Ivor Guest, 4th Viscount Wimborne|Ivor Guest]], with contributions from [[Adam Green (musician)|Adam Green]], Frank Byng, Robert Logan and Ben Cowan.
In April 2012, Jones joined [[Deborah Harry]], [[Bebel Gilberto]], and [[Sharon Stone]] at the Inspiration Gala in [[S\xc3\xa3o Paulo]], Brazil, raising $1.3 Million for amfAR (the Foundation for AIDS Research). Jones closed the evening with a performance of "La Vie en Rose" and "Pull Up to the Bumper."<ref>{{cite web|title=Sharon Stone, Deborah Harry, Grace Jones, Bebel Gilberto help to Raise $1.3 Million for amfAR in Brazil|url=http://www.amfar.org/in_the_spotlight/press_releases/sharon_stone,_deborah_harry,_grace_jones,_bebel_gilberto_help_to_raise_$1_3_million_for_amfar_in_brazil/|publisher=amfAR|accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref>

Two months later, Jones performed Slave To The Rhythm at the [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II]], and the [[Lovebox Festival#Lovebox 2012|Lovebox Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vadamagazine.com/11/04/2013/entertainment/ladies-and-gentlemen-miss-grace-jones |title=Ladies and Gentlemen \xe2\x80\x93 Miss Grace Jones|work=Vada Magazine |accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref> On 27 October Jones performed her only North American show of 2012, a performance at New York City\'s [[Roseland Ballroom]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/grace-jones-concert-review-roseland-384140 |title=Grace Jones Brings Fierceness, High Fashion to Pre-Hurricane New York City: Concert Review|work=[[Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=3 January 2013 |first=Mick |last=Stingley |date=29 October 2012}}</ref> The same year, Jones presented [[Tom Jones (singer)|Sir Tom Jones]] with not only the [[GQ]] Men of the Year award, but her underwear. Tom Jones accepted the gift in good humour, and replied by saying, \xe2\x80\x9dI didn\'t think you wore any".<ref>{{cite news|title=GQ Men of the Year Awards: highlights and lowlights|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/9522486/GQ-Men-of-the-Year-Awards-highlights-and-lowlights.html|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=26 May 2013|location=London|first=Anita|last=Singh|date=5 September 2012}}</ref>

Jones is currently working on a new album with producer Ivor Guest, and on a book of memoirs, but meanwhile Universal Music Group released a deluxe edition of her \'\'Nightclubbing\'\' album as a 2 disc set and Blu-ray audio on 28 April 2014. The set contains most of the 12" mixes of singles from that album, plus two previoulsy unreleased tracks from the \'\'Nightclubbing\'\' sessions, including a cover of the [[Gary Numan]] track \'\'Me! I Disconnect From You\'\'.

In October 2014, Jones was announced as having contributed a song, "Original Beast," to the soundtrack of \'\'[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay \xe2\x80\x93 Part 1 Soundtrack|The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kanye West, Chvrches, Bat For Lashes, Haim, Pusha T, Charli XCX Appear on Lorde\'s The Hunger Games: Mockingjay, Pt. 1 Soundtrack|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/56191-kanye-west-chvrches-bat-for-lashes-haim-pusha-t-charli-xcx-appear-on-lordes-the-hunger-games-mockingjay-pt-1-soundtrack/|publisher=Pitchfork|accessdate=21 October 2014|location=|first=Evan|last=Minsker|date=21 October 2014}}</ref>

==Artistry and legacy==

===Image===
Jones\' distinctive androgynous appearance, square-cut, angular padded clothing, manner, and height of 5\'10\xc2\xbd<nowiki>\'\'</nowiki><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1083750/Its-hard-freak-Grace-Jones-built-30-year-career-scaring-hell-But-says-shes-really-big-softie.html |title=<nowiki>\'It\'s hard being a freak!\' Grace Jones has built a 30-year career on scaring the hell out of us. But, she says, she\'s really a big softie | Mail Online</nowiki> | location=London | work=Daily Mail |first=Lisa |last=Sewards}}</ref> influenced the [[cross-dressing]] movement of the 1980s. To this day, she is known for her unique look at least as much as she is for her music<ref name="allymolloy">{{cite book |title=A-Z of the 80s |last=Molloy |first=Ally |year=2010 |publisher=[[John Blake Publishing]] |location=London |isbn= |page=134}}</ref> and has been an inspiration for numerous artists, including [[Annie Lennox]],<ref name="O\'Brien 1991">{{cite book |title=Annie Lennox |last=O\'Brien |first=Lucy |authorlink=Lucy O\'Brien |year=1991 |publisher=[[Sidgwick & Jackson]] |location=London |isbn= }}</ref> [[Lady Gaga]], [[Rihanna]],<ref name="guardian2010" /><ref name="clashmusic">{{cite web |url=http://www.clashmusic.com/feature/10-things-you-never-knew-about-grace-jones |title=10 Things You Never Knew About... Grace Jones |work=clashmusic.com |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="p4k-review1"/> [[Brazilian Girls]]<ref name="GETTY Images">{{cite web|title=Brazilian Girls Interview (clip 16) Brazilian Girls on fashion, Grace Jones, designers, Alexander McQueen, Issey Miyake, and Bjork. Produced by Uncensored Interview / Zen Cat Productions. Brazilian Girls Interview (clip 16) on July 24, 2008 in New York City (Footage by WireImage Video/Getty Images)|url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/video/brazilian-girls-on-fashion-grace-jones-designers-news-footage/107834481|publisher=GETTY Images|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref> [[Grimes (musician)|Grimes]],<ref name="p4k-review1">{{cite web | url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19222-grace-jones-nightclubbing-deluxe-edition/ | title=Grace Jones - Nightclubbing | publisher=[[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]] | date=1 May 2014 | accessdate=1 May 2014 | author=Beta, Andy}}</ref> [[R\xc3\xb3is\xc3\xadn Murphy]],<ref name="Roison talks Grace">{{cite web|title=Roison talks Grace|url=http://roisinmurphy.blogspot.com/2008/04/roisin-talks-grace.html|accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref> [[Nile Rodgers]],<ref name="Amazing Grace Nile Rodgers">{{cite web|title=Amazing Grace Nile Rodgers|url=http://www.nilerodgers.com/blogs/planet-c-in-english/584|accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref> [[Santigold]],<ref name="Cool Accidents">{{cite web|title=Cool Accidents, Santigold\'s Mixtape|url=http://coolaccidents.tumblr.com/post/22085159677/santigolds-mixtape|publisher=Cool Accidents|accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref> and [[Basement Jaxx]].<ref name="gettyimages.com">{{cite web|title=Basement Jaxx on Grace Jones, Live Performance, Sex, and Passion|url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/video/basement-jaxx-on-grace-jones-live-performance-sex-passion-news-footage/104333611|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>
Jones was listed as one of the fifty best-dressed over 50s by the \'\'Guardian\'\' in March 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=The 50 best-dressed over 50s|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/fashion/gallery/2013/mar/29/50-best-dressed-over-50s|publisher=The Guardian | location=London|first1=Jess|last1=Cartner-Morley|first2=Helen|last2=Mirren|first3=Arianna|last3=Huffington|first4=Valerie|last4=Amos|date=28 March 2013}}</ref>

===Voice and music===
Jones has a [[contralto]] vocal range. She sings in two modes: either in her monotone speak-sing voice as in songs such as "[[Private Life]]", "[[Walking in the Rain (Flash and the Pan song)|Walking in the Rain]]" and "[[The Apple Stretching]]", or in an almost-[[soprano]] mode in songs such as "[[La Vie en Rose]]", "[[Slave to the Rhythm (Grace Jones song)|Slave to the Rhythm]]", and "[[Victor Should Have Been a Jazz Musician]]". Jones\' voice spans two and a half octaves.<ref name="clashmusic"/>

While her early music was rooted in the [[disco]] genre, she opted for a [[New wave music|new wave]] sound in 1980s. She recorded a series of albums 1980\xe2\x80\x99s \'\'[[Warm Leatherette (album)|Warm Leatherette]]\'\' through 1982\xe2\x80\x99s \'\'[[Living My Life (album)|Living My Life]]\'\'. Backed by the Jamaica [[rhythm section]] duo [[Sly and Robbie]], her music during this era was described as a hybrid of "rock, [[funk]], [[post-punk]], pop and reggae." This hybrid influenced a variety of [[alternative rock|alternative music]] artists, including [[Massive Attack]], [[Todd Terje]], [[Gorillaz]], [[Hot Chip]], and [[LCD Soundsystem]].<ref name="p4k-review1"/>

===Tours===
[[File:Gracejones-hurrican.jpg|thumb|Grace Jones on her \'\'Hurricane Tour\'\' (2009)]]

* \'\'[[A One Man Show]]\'\' (1981)
* \'\'[[Grace In Your Face]]\'\' (1990)
* \'\'[[Hurricane Tour (Grace Jones Tour)|Hurricane Tour]]\'\' (2009)<ref>{{cite web|title=Paulo Goude: Son of a Hurricane|url=http://missgracejones.com/paulo/|publisher=Frank Veldkamp |accessdate=4 February 2014}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Jones\' relationship with her father was strained; he was strict and felt forced to disassociate himself from her because the church refused to make him a bishop as long as he was associated with his daughter. According to the particular denomination\'s beliefs, one should only use one\'s singing ability to glorify God.<ref name="Sawyer" /> Bishop Robert W. Jones died on 7 May 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Winston Jones Obituary|url=http://obits.syracuse.com/obituaries/syracuse/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=109731509#fbLoggedOut|publisher=Syracuse.com|accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref> Her mother, Marjorie, always supported Jones\' career (she sings on "[[Williams\' Blood]]" and "[[My Jamaican Guy]]") but could not be publicly associated with her music.<ref name="Sawyer" /> Marjorie\'s father, William, was also a musician, and played with [[Nat King Cole]].<ref name="Sawyer" />

Through her relationship with long-time collaborator [[Jean-Paul Goude]], Jones has one son, Paulo. From Paulo, Jones has one granddaughter.<ref name="clashmusic"/> Jones has been married twice: to producer Chris Stanley in 1989 and to bodyguard Atila Altaunbay in 1996.<ref name="nndb">{{cite web |url=http://www.nndb.com/people/127/000023058/ |title=Grace Jones |work=nndb.com |accessdate=15 October 2009}}</ref> She spent four years with Swedish actor [[Dolph Lundgren]], her former bodyguard; she was the one who got him a part as a KGB officer in \'\'[[A View to a Kill]]\'\'.<ref name="Chafetz2008">{{cite book |last=Chafetz |first=Gary S. |title=The Perfect Villain: John McCain and the Demonization of Lobbyist Jack Abramoff |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=VewbAQAAMAAJ |accessdate=21 May 2011 |date=September 2008 |publisher=Martin and Lawrence Press |isbn=978-0-9773898-8-9 |page=60}}</ref> Jones started dating Danish actor/stuntman/bodybuilder [[Sven-Ole Thorsen]] in 1990, and was in an open relationship as of 2007.<ref>{{cite news|last=Willman|first=Chris|title=Queen of Pop Shock Struts into the \'90s: Before Madonna and Annie Lennox, Grace Jones paved the way. Now the multi-media artist sets her sights on \'softer\'|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-02-11/entertainment/ca-1001_1_grace-jones|publisher=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=3 June 2013|date=11 February 1990}}</ref>

Jones\' brother is [[megachurch]] preacher Bishop [[Noel Jones (Pentecostal bishop)|Noel Jones]], who starred on the 2013 reality show \'\'Preachers of LA\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realitytea.com/2013/11/04/exclusive-preachers-of-l-a-sneak-peek-bishop-noel-jones-talks-about-his-famous-sister/ |title=Preachers Of L.A. Bishop Noel Jones Talks About Famous Sister Grace |publisher=Realitytea.com |date=2013-11-04 |accessdate=2014-02-11}}</ref>

Jones\'s real last name is often referred to as "Mendoza", which is actually a name she used in her 20s to fool her parents.<ref>{{cite web|author=Miranda Sawyer |url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/oct/12/grace-jones-hurricane |title=State of Grace: Miranda Sawyer meets Grace Jones &#124; Music &#124; The Observer |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}}</ref>

 ****** Hamilton Bohannon

b'{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name                = Hamilton Bohannon
| image                 =
| caption            = Album cover
| image_size            = 200px
| background          = solo_singer

| alias               = Bohannon
| birth_date                = {{birth date and age|1942|3|7|mf=y}}

| death_date                =
| origin              =
| instrument          = [[Human voice|vocals]], [[drum]]s, [[percussion instrument|percussion]]
| genre               = [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[disco]], [[funk]]
| occupation          = [[Musician]], [[songwriter]], [[record producer]]
| years_active        = 1964\xe2\x80\x931990
| label               = Dakar/[[Brunswick Records]]<br/>[[Mercury Records]]
| associated_acts     = [[Caroline Crawford|Carolyn Crawford]]
| website                 =
| current_members     =
| past_members        =
| notable_instruments =
}}
\'\'\'Hamilton Frederick Bohannon\'\'\' (born March 7, 1942), often credited and known professionally simply as \'\'\'Bohannon\'\'\', is an [[United States|American]] [[percussionist]], [[band leader]], songwriter and [[record producer]], who was one of the leading figures in 1970s [[disco]] music.<ref name=allmusic>[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/hamilton-bohannon-mn0000664093 Biography by Ron Wynn at Allmusic.com].  Retrieved 28 January 2013</ref>

== Life and career==
He was born in [[Newnan, Georgia|Newnan]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and learned the [[drums]] at school.  He began playing in local [[band (music)|bands]], one of which featured guitarist [[Jimi Hendrix]], before graduating from [[Clark Atlanta University|Clark College, Atlanta]] with a degree in music and secondary education.<ref name=hna>[http://www.hnarecords.com/book.html  Official biography at HNA Records].  Retrieved 28 January 2013</ref><ref name=jet>[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Tb8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA62&dq=bohannon+wonder&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8J4HUZCSOYeS0QXd9YHoDg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=bohannon%20wonder&f=false David E. Smallwood, \'\'Bohannon emerges as disco heavyweight\'\', \'\'Jet\'\' magazine, 26 January 1978, pp.62,65].  Retrieved 28 January 2013</ref>  After a brief period as a schoolteacher, he was recruited in 1964 as drummer in 13-year-old [[Stevie Wonder]]\'s touring band.  He moved to [[Detroit]] in 1967, where he was employed by [[Motown Records|Motown]] as the leader and [[arrangement|arranger]] of Bohannon & The Motown Sound, who provided backing for many of the [[record label|label]]\'s top [[musician|acts]] on tour, including Stevie Wonder, [[Smokey Robinson]], [[Marvin Gaye]], [[The Temptations]], [[Diana Ross and the Supremes]], [[The Four Tops]] and others.<ref name=allmusic/><ref name=hna/>  

When Motown moved from Detroit to [[Los Angeles]], Bohannon stayed behind to form his own ensemble, featuring members of local band, The Fabulous Counts and including such musicians as [[Ray Parker Jr.]] and [[Dennis Coffey]].<ref name=jet/><ref name=soulwalking>[http://www.soulwalking.co.uk/Hamilton%20Bohannon.html  Biography at SoulWalking.com]. Retrieved 28 January 2013</ref>   He signed in 1972 with the [[Dakar Records|Dakar]] label run by producer [[Carl Davis (record producer)|Carl Davis]], and released his debut album \'\'[[Stop & Go]]\'\' in early 1973.  This was followed by five more albums for the label over the next two years, on which he "perfected his formula of heavy, thudding bass accents and aggressive rhythms".<ref name=allmusic/>  Although several of his tracks were [[nightclub|club]] [[chart-topper|hits]], he had limited [[record chart|chart]] success.  His first hit single, in 1974, was "South African Man", which reached no.78 on the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[R&B chart]] but had more success in the UK, where it reached no.22 on the [[UK singles chart|pop chart]].  This was followed up in 1975 by "Foot Stompin Music" - his only record to reach the US [[Hot 100]] - and "Disco Stomp", his biggest hit in the UK where it reached number 6.<ref name="whitburnr&b"/><ref name="betts"/>  

In 1976, Bohannon signed to [[Mercury Records]] and two years later had one of his biggest successes with "Let\xe2\x80\x99s Start The Dance," which reached no.9 on the [[R&B chart]]<ref name="whitburnr&b"/> and no.7 on the disco chart.<ref>{{cite book |title= Hot Dance/Disco: 1974-2003|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=38}}</ref> "Let\'s Start the Dance" featured [[singing|singer]] [[Caroline Crawford|Carolyn Crawford]], whose subsequent [[solo (music)|albums]] Bohannon went on to [[record producer|produce]].  In 1981, a new mix of "Let\'s Start the Dance" was successful on the dance charts.<ref name=allmusic/>  In 1980 he established Phase II Records,<ref name=soulwalking/> and continued to have minor hits on the R&B chart for the next three years, using new vocalists [[Liz Lands]] and Altrinna Grayson.<ref name="whitburnr&b"/>  He signed with [[MCA Records]] in 1984 and released several more albums.<ref name=allmusic/>  His last album, \'\'It\'s Time To Jam\'\', was issued on the South Bound label in 1990.<ref name=soulwalking/>

Much of his [[music]] has been widely [[Sampling (music)|sample]]d, most notably on Chicago DJ/producer [[Paul Johnson (producer)|Paul Johnson]]\'s 1999 hit "Get Get Down" which heavily sampled Bohannon\'s "Me and the Gang."  Other musicians who have used samples of his music include [[Jay Z]], [[Digable Planets]], and [[Snoop Dogg]].  His name was also mentioned in the [[Tom Tom Club]] song "[[Genius of Love]]."  His composition "[[Ooh!]]" was included on [[Mary J. Blige]]\'s album \'\'[[Love & Life (Mary J. Blige album)|Love & Life]]\'\' in 2003.<ref name=hna/>

In recent years Bohannon has produced a new singer, Governor, on [[Atlantic Records]], as well as working on material with his son, Hamilton Bohannon II and publishing an [[audiobook]] memoir of his early years in the music business, \'\'Bohannon Speaks from the Beginning\'\'.<ref name=hna/><ref name=soulwalking/> 

Bohannon is a devout [[Christian]]<ref name=hna/> and dedicated his album \'\'Dance Your Ass Off\'\' to "God and His Son, Jesus Christ". The album also included a disclaimer that "The word \'ass\' is not used here in the sense of profanity."

 ****** Heatwave (band)

b'{{About||the weather phenomenon|Heat wave|other uses|Heat wave (disambiguation)}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = Heatwave
| image             = Heatwave (band photo, 1976).jpg
| caption        = Heatwave, 1982
| image_size        = 
| background      = group_or_band
| years_active    = 1975\xe2\x80\x931984, 1988-present
|genre            = [[Funk]], [[disco]]
| origin          = [[Germany]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Heatwave "boogies\' in with Rufus, Stargard|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EwQnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PgMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=1700%2C3182826|newspaper=The Baltimore Afro-American}}</ref>| label           = [[GTO Records]], [[Epic Records]]
| current_members = Keith Wilder, Napoleon Eugene Phillips, Elliott Levine, Elwarren Witherspoon, Keith Busey, Anthony Contee, Geno Myers, Ignatious Mason, Byron Byrd, Donovan Blackwood, Nathan Watson
| past_members    = [[Johnnie Wilder, Jr.]] (deceased) <br>Keith Wilder<br>[[Rod Temperton]]<br>[[Mario Mantese]]<br>Ernest Berger<br>Eric Johns<br>Roy Carter<br>Billy Jones<br>Derek Bramble<br>Calvin Duke<br>J.D. Nicholas<br>Keith Harrison

}}
\'\'\'Heatwave\'\'\' is an international [[funk]]/[[disco]] band featuring [[United States|Americans]] [[Johnnie Wilder, Jr.]] and Keith Wilder (vocals) of [[Dayton, Ohio]], [[England|Englishman]] [[Rod Temperton]] ([[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]]), [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Mario Mantese]] (bass), [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak]] Ernest "Bilbo" Berger (drums), [[Jamaica]]n Eric Johns (guitar) and [[British people|Briton]] Roy Carter (guitar).

They were known for their successful songs "[[Boogie Nights (song)|Boogie Nights]]", "[[Always and Forever (Heatwave song)|Always and Forever]]", and "[[The Groove Line]]".

==Heatwave\'s mainstream years==
Founding member Johnnie Wilder was an American serviceman based in [[West Germany]] when he first began performing; upon his discharge from the [[U.S. Army]], he stayed in Germany.  He sang in nightclubs and taverns with an assortment of bands while still enlisted.  By mid-year, he decided to relocate to the [[United Kingdom]] and through an ad placed in a local paper he linked up with [[songwriter]]/[[keyboardist]] [[Rod Temperton]].

Touring the [[London]] nightclub circuit billed as \'\'Chicago\'s Heatwave\'\' during the mid-1970s allowed them to refine their sound, adding a funk groove to disco beats. In search of a fuller sound vocally, Johnnie Wilder called upon his brother Keith Wilder (who was performing in a local band in Dayton, Ohio) to join the band on vocals.  The group signed to [[GTO Records]] in 1976 ([[Epic Records]] would handle GTO\'s releases in the states). They were paired in the studio with GTO house producer/session guitarist [[Barry Blue]] and rhythm guitarist Jesse Whitten. Rhythm guitarist Roy Carter replaced Whitten after Whitten was killed in a stabbing incident. They began creating their first album \'\'[[Too Hot to Handle (Heatwave album)|Too Hot to Handle]]\'\' in the fall of 1976.

Their third single, "Boogie Nights" from their debut album, in 1977 reached #2 on the British popular music charts in January and in America in November. The single was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].<ref name="Whitburn 2010 p 40">[[Joel Whitburn|Whitburn, Joel]] (2010). \'\'The Billboard Book of Top 40 Hits\'\', 9th Edition (Billboard Publications), page 293.</ref> The group\'s debut album, \'\'Too Hot to Handle\'\', was released in the spring of 1977, giving Heatwave a #11 on the Hot 200 and #5 on the R&B charts, while the next single, the soul ballad "Always and Forever", reached #18 on the Hot 100 in April 1978 and #2 on the R&B charts. The single was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].<ref name="Whitburn 2010 p 40"/>

Continuing to use Barry Blue\'s production skills, Heatwave released their second album \'\'[[Central Heating (Heatwave album)|Central Heating]]\'\' in April 1978. Lead single "The Groove Line," reached #7 on the Hot 100 in July 1978. The single was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].<ref name="Whitburn 2010 p 40"/>

During the late 1970s the band changed.  At first Eric Johns quit the band and Billy Jones was his replacement as guitarist.  Then Rod Temperton quit the band.  Although Temperton would continue writing new songs for Heatwave, he soon became better-known for his [[songwriter|songwriting]] for other artists, penning award-winning songs for some of funk\'s biggest names, including [[Rufus (band)|Rufus]], [[The Brothers Johnson]] and [[George Benson]].  He also wrote for [[Herbie Hancock]] and [[Quincy Jones]], but his most famous partnership remains the one forged with [[Michael Jackson]], writing three songs for his 1979 [[Epic Records|Epic]] debut \'\'[[Off the Wall (album)|Off the Wall]]\'\' - "Rock With You," "Off the Wall" and "Burn This Disco Out", and three songs for the 1982 \'\'[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]\'\' LP, including the title track.

Despite these changes Heatwave were about to return to the studio, when Mantese attended a party at Elton John\'s house in London.  He was with his girlfriend, who decided to go home early from the party, reason unknown.  When Mantese arrived home, she was furious with him, perhaps from an incident that happened at the party and stabbed him.  The knife hit him in the heart and for several minutes, he was clinically dead.  When, after several months, he awoke from coma, he was blind, mute and paralysed in his entire body.  To date, he has no memory of this tragic event.  He decided not to press charges against his girlfriend, and moved in with her after leaving the hospital.  Mantese was replaced by bassist Derek Bramble. Adding keyboardist Calvin Duke to the group, and now working with new producer [[Phil Ramone]], Heatwave cut \'\'[[Hot Property (album)|Hot Property]]\'\', released in May 1979.

During the spring of 1979, Johnnie Wilder, Jr., suffered injuries in an [[auto accident]] while visiting family and friends in [[Dayton, Ohio]].  Although he survived, the accident left him [[paralyzed]] from the neck down and unable to continue performing with the group.  After the accident, Johnnie remained a co-producer of the group, along with Blue.

Determined to continue working with the band he had nurtured since the very beginning, Wilder participated with studio work and, during 1980, Heatwave recorded the \'\'[[Candles (album)|Candles]]\'\' LP, with Temperton again providing the songs, except stand out track "All I Am", written by  Blue\'s former writing partner [[Lynsey de Paul]]. The group recruited James Dean "J.D." Nicholas, who later became a member of the [[Commodores]], to handle vocals in concert.<ref name="NME Rock \'N\' Roll Years">{{cite book
| first= John
| last= Tobler
| year= 1992
| title= NME Rock \'N\' Roll Years
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Reed International Books Ltd 
| location= London
| page= 353
| id= CN 5585}}</ref>

Heatwave\'s popularity was on the wane, though, as the November single "Gangsters of the Groove" proved to be their last popular music success, scoring number twenty-one in the U.S., and number 20 in the [[United Kingdom]] early in the New Year. But the album peaked at a mere number 71 in the United States in December 1980.

Heatwave\'s 1982 LP, \'\'[[Current (album)|Current]]\'\', marked yet another new era for the band, as they returned to producer Blue. The album managed only number 156 on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], although it scored the band a number 21 success on the R&B charts, where Heatwave continued to be a strong presence. A Rod Temperton penned single, "Lettin\' It Loose," proved a minor success during August.

Derek Bramble quit the band at the end of 1982, like Roy Carter, for a career in production (he would go on to work with [[David Bowie]] on 1984s \'\'Tonight\'\' LP, and later masterminded [[Jaki Graham]]\'s breakthrough). J.D. Nicholas left to replace [[Lionel Richie]] as the lead singer of the [[Commodores]]. After this long series of departures, the remaining members of Heatwave effectively disbanded.

==Post 1988 Heatwave==
Silent since early 1983, Heatwave reconvened in a new line-up to record and release the album \'\'The Fire\'\' in 1988.  However, Keith Wilder was the only original member of the band present in this incarnation (although Billy Jones, who had joined the band in the late 1970s returned as well).<ref name="Discogs">[http://www.discogs.com/Heatwave-The-Fire/release/1725006 Heatwave- \'\'The Fire\'\' @ Discogs]</ref>  Meanwhile, that same year, Johnnie Wilder released a solo spiritual album \'\'My Goals on Light\'\'.  The Wilder brothers once again teamed up the following year for the [[gospel music|gospel]] album, \'\'Sound of Soul\'\'.  None of these late 1980s albums sold well, but Heatwave\'s recognition was revitalized in 1991, when a [[remix]] version of their "Mind Blowing Decisions" charted in the UK.  By the middle of the 1990s, Keith Wilder had again reformed the band. Joined by bassist Dave Williamson, keyboardists [[Kevin Sutherland]] and [[Sun (R&B band)|Byron Byrd]], guitarist [[Bill Jones]]{{disambiguation needed|date=February 2012}}, and original drummer Ernest Berger, the reborn Heatwave launched an American tour with a live album recorded at the [[Greek Theatre (Los Angeles)|Greek Theater]] in [[Hollywood]], arriving in 1997.

Heatwave released an extended club remix of "Boogie Nights" in 2002.  Keith Wilder is the lead singer of the current line-up (and the only remaining original member). The current touring line-up includes a host of lesser known musicians, including New Orleans keyboardist Jeremy Crump and Washington, DC keyboardist [[Elliot Levine]].

Johnnie Wilder died in his sleep at his home in [[Dayton, Ohio]] in May 2006.
