 ****** Maze (band)

b'{{blpsources|date=April 2015}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->
| name                = Maze
| image                 =
| caption            = 
| image_size            = 200
| background          = group_or_band
| alias               = 
| origin              = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] / [[San Francisco Bay Area]], [[United States]]
| genre               = [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[funk]]
| years_active        = 1976&ndash;present
| label               = [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]
| associated_acts     = 
| website                 = 
| current_members     = [[Frankie Beverly]]<br/>Roame Lowry<br/>Carl Wheeler<br/>Larry Kimpel<br/>Vance Taylor<br/>Jubu Smith<br/>Calvin Napper
| past_members        = McKinley "Bug" Williams (deceased)<br/>Sam Porter (deceased)<br/>Robin Duhe<br/>Wuane Thomas<br/>Joe Provost<br/>Ahaguna Sun<br/>Ron Smith<br/>Billy Johnson<br/>Phillip Woo<br/>Wayne "Ziggy" Lindsay<br/>Vernon "Ice" Black<br/>William Bryant<br/>Michael White<br/>Anthony Beverly<br/>Chris Johnson<br/> Road Manager: Calvin "VJ" Jones<br/> Stage Manager: Michael Burton<br/> Light Director: Michael Lowry
| notable_instruments = 
}}

\'\'\'Maze\'\'\' are an American [[Soul music|soul]] / [[quiet storm]] [[musical ensemble|band]], also known alternately as \'\'\'Maze Featuring Frankie Beverly\'\'\' and \'\'\'Maze & Frankie Beverly\'\'\', was established in [[San Francisco]], [[California]] in the early 1970s.

==Career==
[[Frankie Beverly]] started the group as Raw Soul in 1970. They recorded a couple of [[single (music)|singles]] on the small Gregar [[record label|label]], but without any major [[hit record|hits]]. With a few personnel changes, a relocation from Philadelphia to the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] in California in 1971, and an introduction to [[Marvin Gaye]], the group became an immediate success. Gaye took the group on the road with him as one of his opening acts, and in 1976, he suggested that they changed their name from Raw Soul to Maze.

Maze signed a [[recording contract]] with [[Capitol Records]] in 1976, and released their debut album, [[Maze featuring Frankie Beverly (album)|\'\'Maze featuring Frankie Beverly\'\']], in 1977.  From that album, the hit singles included "Happy Feelin\'s", "While I\'m Alone", and "Lady of Magic", ultimately giving them their first [[music recording sales certification|gold record]] and earning Maze a devoted following. They also had success with the albums \'\'Golden Time of Day\'\' (1978), \'\'Inspiration\'\' (1979) and \'\'Joy and Pain\'\' (1980).

Their next [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] was \'\'Live in New Orleans,\'\' three quarters of which was recorded at the [[Saenger Theatre (New Orleans, Louisiana)|Saenger Theatre]], on November 14\xe2\x80\x9315, 1980. Three of those songs got into the [[United States|US]] [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]], including "Running Away", "[[Before I Let Go]]", and "We Need Love To Live". By that time, the band had both a reputation in [[United States|America]] and also enjoyed a following in the [[United Kingdom]] with promotional support from the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Disc jockey|DJ]] [[Robbie Vincent]]. In May 1985, Maze sold out eight nights at the [[Hammersmith Odeon]].<ref name="NME Rock \'N\' Roll Years">{{cite book
| first= John
| last= Tobler
| year= 1992
| title= NME Rock \'N\' Roll Years
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Reed International Books Ltd 
| location= London
| page= 404
| id= CN 5585}}</ref>

The group released their next album, \'\'Can\'t Stop the Love\'\' in March 1985, which featured the group\'s first number one R&B hit "Back In Stride." The [[Top 40|Top 5]] follow-up, "Too Many Games" was also featured on this album.  The latter single also became the band\'s biggest hit in the [[United Kingdom|UK]], where it peaked at number 36 on the charts.

In 1989, they signed with Warner Bros. and released the hit album \'\'Silky Soul\'\', plus \'\'Back to Basics\'\' in 1993, and released the [[live album|live]] [[DVD]] recording at [[London]]\'s [[Hammersmith Odeon]] in 1994. The two albums also attained gold disc status. They had another number one R&B success with "Can\'t Get Over You".

In October 2004, "Twilight" appeared in the [[video game]], \'\'[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]\'\', playing on funk radio station,  [[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas soundtrack#Bounce FM|Bounce FM]] .

In 2009, a tribute to the hits of Maze was released. Called \'\'Silky Soul Music: An All Star Tribute to Maze Featuring Frankie Beverly,\'\' it included modern stars performing Maze\'s biggest hits with Maze acting as the backing band.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soultracks.com/maze.htm |title=Maze featuring Frankie Beverly &#124; SoulTracks - Soul Music Biographies, News and Reviews |publisher=SoulTracks |date= |accessdate=2012-12-17}}</ref>

On September 2, 2011, their percussionist and background singer, McKinley "Bug" Williams, died of an apparent [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at a hotel in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]].

Maze continues to tour around the United States as well as [[Europe]] to this day. Every year they are the closing act for the [[Essence Music Festival]].

 ****** Medeski Martin %26 Wood

b'{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = Medeski Martin & Wood
| image             = Medeski Martin & Wood.jpg
| caption        = Medeski Martin & Wood performing at the 2006 Jazzfest in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA
| landscape       = yes
| background      = group_or_band
| origin          = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York]], [[United States of America|USA]]
| genre           = [[Jazz]], [[jazz-funk]], [[jazz fusion]], [[acid jazz]], [[nu jazz]], [[soul jazz]], [[avant-jazz]], [[post-bop]], 
| years_active    = 1991\xe2\x80\x93present
| label           = [[Blue Note Records|Blue Note]], [[Gramavision Records|Gramavision]], [[Indirecto Records|Indirecto]], [[Ropeadope Records|Ropeadope]]
| website             = {{URL|http://www.mmw.net/}}
| current_members = [[John Medeski]]<br/>[[Billy Martin (percussionist)|Billy Martin]]<br/>[[Chris Wood (jazz musician)|Chris Wood]]
}}

\'\'\'Medeski Martin & Wood\'\'\' (or \'\'\'MMW\'\'\') is an [[United States|American]] [[avant-jazz|avant]]-[[jazz-funk]] [[Musical ensemble|band]] formed in 1991, consisting of [[John Medeski]] on [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]] and [[piano]], [[Billy Martin (percussionist)|Billy Martin]] on [[Drum kit|drums]] and [[Percussion instrument|percussion]], and [[Chris Wood (jazz musician)|Chris Wood]] on [[double bass]] and [[bass guitar]]. 

The band draws on influences from a number of musical traditions, from [[funk]] to [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], and is known for an unconventional style sometimes described as "[[avant-jazz|avant]]-[[Groove (music)|groove]]".

MMW has found moderate mainstream success, often working with noted guitarist [[John Scofield]] and touring on the [[jam band]] circuit.

==History==
The band members were introduced to each other by jazz drummer [[Bob Moses (musician)|Bob Moses]], who had performed with Medeski and Wood, and was Martin\'s instructor. 

Medeski Martin & Wood\'s first performances together were at the [[Village Gate]], a popular New York jazz club. They were initially an acoustic jazz trio, but Medeski added a [[Hammond organ]] when the difficulties of touring with a piano became apparent{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}}. Their first album, \'\'[[Notes from the Underground (Medeski Martin & Wood album)|Notes from the Underground]]\'\', is a record of their entirely-acoustic era. All of their subsequent albums reveal Medeski\'s use of a wide variety of keyboards, including [[mellotron]], [[melodica]], and a [[clavinet]]. Wood entirely eschewed the electric bass for MMW\'s first three albums, and still relies heavily on the acoustic upright bass in recordings and during live performances. Their earlier albums reveal a [[Hip hop music|Hip Hop]] influenced updating of classic [[soul jazz]] sounds, which is the primary theme of their well-known 1996 album, \'\'[[Shack-man]]\'\'. 

The band received some of their first significant exposure outside of the [[New York City]] jazz scene by performing with [[Phish]] at their October 14, 1995 concert, which led to the association of the group as a [[jam band]].<ref>[http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/medeskimartinandwood]{{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref> In addition, their performance on [[John Scofield]]\'s 1997 album \'\'[[A Go Go (John Scofield album)|A Go Go]]\'\' helped to further their exposure.  The band collaborated further with Scofield again in 2006, releasing the album \'\'[[Out Louder]]\'\' under the name Medeski Scofield Martin & Wood.  This was the first album released on MMW\'s own [[Indirecto Records]].

From 1998 to 2005, MMW were signed to leading jazz label [[Blue Note Records]], and showed them delving deeper into dense, electronic funk than their earlier albums, although the band continued to experiment with [[free jazz]] and [[free improvisation]] both on their albums and in concert. In 2001 MMW performed several songs for the [[Red Hot Organization]]\'s compilation album \'\'[[Red Hot + Indigo]]\'\', a tribute to [[Duke Ellington]], which raised money for various charities devoted to increasing [[AIDS]] awareness and fighting the disease. 

Medeski Martin & Wood\'s live performances are renowned for their exploratory nature. Their concerts usually involve extended improvisations, which may be both arrhythmic and [[atonality|atonal]], an aspect of their musicianship that is rarely documented in the studio. They occasionally tour using only acoustic instruments, reverting to the instrumentation that they began their career with. Their album \'\'[[Tonic (Medeski Martin & Wood album)|Tonic]]\'\' is an example of these more contemporary acoustic performances. They have also done short tours of entirely improvisatory performances. These shows usually consisted of two sets of improvisation, followed by an encore of a song from an album.

==Side projects==
Each of the trio\'s three members is involved in a large music community, and has participated in numerous side projects over the years.  

In 2001 John Medeski collaborated with the [[North Mississippi Allstars]] and [[steel guitar]]ist [[Robert Randolph (guitarist)|Robert Randolph]]; together, these five musicians formed [[The Word (band)|The Word]], a [[blues]]y [[gospel music|gospel]] [[instrumental]] [[jam band]]. They released one self-titled album and toured extensively.

Beginning around 2005 Chris Wood formed [[The Wood Brothers]] with his brother, blues guitarist Oliver Wood. They have released several albums to date and continue to tour and record together. 

In 2007 John Medeski and Billy Martin released an album as a duo, called \'\'[[Mago (album)|Mago]]\'\'. They performed that material together at the 2007 [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]].<ref>[http://www.bonnaroo.com/2007-lineup ]{{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref>

 ****** Paulo Mendon\xc3\xa7a

b''

 ****** Mickey %26 the Soul Generation

b'\'\'\'Mickey & the Soul Generation\'\'\' were a [[funk]] band from [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]]. The group formed in the late 1960s in the midst of the Texas funk scene, which consisted mostly of locally and regionally known bands but which was extraordinarily prolific (and known today mostly through [[hip hop]] [[sample (music)|sampling]] and [[reissue]]s on labels such as Jazzman Records).

==History==
Mickey Foster and Emil Carter first played together in a Latino soul group called The Royal Tokens. The two split from the group to form a new band; picking up George Salas and Gilbert Rivera, they called themselves "The Fabulous Four". After further lineup changes, the group became "The Fabulous Five", "Mickey and the Fabulous Five" and lastly "Mickey and the Soul Generation". The group won several local talent shows and began recording in a local [[Tejano music|Tejano]] studio. Their 1969 single, "Iron Leg", was picked up for distribution nationwide by [[Maxwell Records]], a [[New York]] label, and the 45 sold well regionally in [[Florida]], [[California]], and [[Texas]]. At the height of its popularity, it was used in a segment by [[Nipsey Russell]] on a routine he did for [[The Tonight Show]].<ref name=davis>[[DJ Shadow|Josh Davis]]. Liner Notes, \'\'Iron Leg\'\'. Cali-Tex, 2002, \'\'passim\'\'.</ref>

After the release of a second single, "Football", the group went on tour, opening for [[Sam & Dave]], [[The Supremes]], [[Clarence Carter]], and [[Kool & the Gang]] in the American South and Midwest. After moving to New York to fill an opening slot for fellow Maxwell artists [[Faith, Hope & Charity]], the group split with its label over monetary disputes and returned to Texas. Further recording ensued at local studios, but the group soon splintered, recording its last singles in 1973.<ref name=davis/>

Mickey & the Soul Generation saw little widespread success while active as a band. However, the group became better known when Josh Davis ([[DJ Shadow]]) began interpolating their music into his records and mixes. Davis, who called the group his \'favorite funk band\',<ref name=davis/> collected the group\'s recordings and had them reissued on [[Cali-Tex]] records in 2002 in the double [[long play|LP]] and [[double CD]] formats. The reissue, \'\'Iron Leg\'\', won highly positive reviews from many press outlets.<ref>[http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/Content?oid=oid%3A14582 Album Review]. \'\'[[Sacramento News & Review]]\'\', March 20, 2003. Accessed November 19, 2007.</ref><ref>[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r624733|pure_url=yes}} Album Review]. [[Allmusic]]. Accessed November 19, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.boomkat.com/item.cfm?id=9649 Album Review]. \'\'Boomkat\'\'. Accessed November 19, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.sfweekly.com/2003-01-29/music/mickey-and-the-soul-generation/ Album Review]. \'\'San Francisco Weekly\'\', January 29, 2003. Accessed November 19, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.blender.com/guide/reviews.aspx?id=641 Album Review]. \'\'[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]\'\'. Accessed November 19, 2007.</ref> Since then, the group\'s material has also shown up on funk compilations on record labels such as Jazzman Records.<ref>[http://www.discogs.com/artist/Mickey+&+The+Soul+Generation Mickey & The Soul Generation] at [[Discogs]].</ref>

==Members==
*Gilbert Rivera - bass
*Andrew Gordon - drums
*George Salas - guitar
*Mickey Foster - organ
*Johnny Hooks - tenor sax
*Emil Carter - vocals, sax
*Harvey Edmerson - drums (deceased)
*Charles Johnson - vocals
*Chris Urrutia - drums

 ****** Midnight Star

b'{{About||the "Weird Al" Yankovic song|Midnight Star (song)|the video game|Midnight Star (video game)}}

{{Refimprove|date=January 2007}}

{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name                = Midnight Star
| image                 =
| caption            = 
| image_size            = 
| background          = group_or_band
| alias               = 
| origin              = [[Frankfort, Kentucky|Frankfort]], [[Kentucky]], [[United States]] 
| genre               = [[Electro-funk]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[disco]]
| years_active        = 1976\xe2\x80\x931990, 2000\xe2\x80\x93present 
| label               = [[Solar Records|Solar]], [[RCA Records|RCA]] 
| associated_acts     = 
| website                 = 
| current_members     = Belinda Lipscomb<br />Melvin Gentry<br />Kenneth Gant<br />Bobby Lovelace<br />Bo Watson<br />Bill Simmons
| past_members        = [[Reginald Calloway]]<br />[[Vincent Calloway]]<br />Jeff Cooper
}}

\'\'\'Midnight Star\'\'\' is an American [[musical ensemble|group]] that had a string of [[Hit record|hits]] in the 1980s.

==Band history==
The group was formed in 1976 at [[Kentucky State University]] by trumpeter Reggie Calloway, vocalist Belinda Lipscomb, guitarist/drummer/vocalist Melvin Gentry, bassist Kenneth Gant, multi-instrumentalist Bill Simmons, keyboard player/vocalist Bo Watson and guitarist/keyboardist Jeff Cooper, as a self-contained group. They would later add non-KSU student trombonist Vincent Calloway (Reginald\'s younger brother). A 1978 New York City showcase inspired [[SOLAR Records]] chief [[Dick Griffey]] to sign the group. They released their debut album \'\'The Beginning\'\' (1980) with some guest [[recording studio|studio]] [[session musician|musicians]].  In 1981 their second album, released on Solar Records, \'\'Standing Together,\'\' reached position #54 on the [[United States|U.S.]] [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]]. In 1982 they released a third album, \'\'Victory\'\'.
 
Utilizing elected band leader Reggie Calloway\'s production skills, it did not take long for Midnight Star to hit the U.S. [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]]  chart with early [[single (music)|singles]] like "Hot Spot" and "I\'ve Been Watching You".  Drummer Bobby Lovelace joined the group in late 1982, freeing Gentry to sing and play guitar exclusively.  Their fourth album, \'\'[[No Parking on the Dance Floor]]\'\', was released in 1983, and it took them to the top of the charts with the first single, "Freak-A-Zoid", which went to number two.  Other singles from the album included "Wet My Whistle", and the title track. These singles, along with the hit album tracks "Slow Jam" (co-written by [[Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds]]) and "Electricity"  propelled the album to double platinum status.  Their next album, \'\'[[Planetary Invasion]]\'\', was almost as big, selling platinum again and making the [[Billboard Hot 100|pop]] Top 20 and the number one spot on the R&B chart with its first single, "[[Operator (Midnight Star song)|Operator]]".  This song remains the band\'s only [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]] [[Top 40]] hit to date.

In 1986 they released their sixth album, \'\'Headlines\'\', which was their third album to sell at least gold.  It was to be their last with the Calloway brothers. Due to irreconcilable differences with the other members, Reggie was out of the group and Vincent left shortly thereafter.  They achieved their biggest success in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] with "Midas Touch", which made #8, and "Headlines", a #16 hit earlier the same year.<ref name="British Hit Singles & Albums">{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Roberts
| year= 2006
| title= British Hit Singles & Albums
| edition= 19th
| publisher= Guinness World Records Limited 
| location= London
| isbn= 1-904994-10-5
| page= 363}}</ref>  Without the Calloways (who would go on to form the group [[Calloway (band)|Calloway]] and release an album that spawned the hit single "[[I Wanna Be Rich]]" in 1989), Midnight Star recorded two more albums, the self-titled \'\'Midnight Star\'\' and \'\'Work It Out\'\'. These two albums proved not as successful as their previous three release, but did bear fruit with Top Ten R&B singles such as: "Don\'t Rock The Boat" and "Snake In The Grass". The group went on a long hiatus, though they never officially broke up.

The group reunited in 2000 with many of the original members (including all of the singers) and released the album \'\'15th Avenue\'\' two years later.  Since then, the group has [[concert tour|toured]] sporadically, most recently with a lineup that includes Belinda Lipscomb, Kenneth Gant, Melvin Gentry, Bo Watson, and Bobby Lovelace, with Bill Simmons sometimes joining as well.

==Outside work==
Outside of Midnight Star, a few band members have contributed to other projects. Bo Watson co-wrote a few songs for singer [[Toni Braxton]]. He co-wrote the [[Babyface (musician)|Babyface]] duet "Give U My Heart" and "Love Shoulda Brought You Home" from the \'\'[[Boomerang (soundtrack)|Boomerang]]\'\' soundtrack<ref>{{cite web|title=Various \xe2\x80\x93 Boomerang: Original Soundtrack Album|url=http://www.discogs.com/Various-Boomerang-Original-Soundtrack-Album/release/1810821|website=discogs.com|publisher=Discogs|accessdate=2014-12-21}}</ref> as well as the song "Spending My Time With You" on Braxton\'s [[Toni Braxton (album)|self-titled debut]]. Watson also helped write other songs such as "Turn Down the Lights" for [[Shanice]], "Rock Steady" for [[The Whispers]] and "Meeting in the Ladies\' Room" for [[Klymaxx]].

Reggie and Vincent Calloway went on to produce such acts as [[Teddy Pendergrass]], [[The Deele]] and [[LeVert]]- the latter with whom they would have their biggest success with the song "Casanova".

Belinda Lipscomb appears on [[Reflection Eternal]]\'s 2010 album \'\'[[Revolutions per Minute (Reflection Eternal album)|Revolutions Per Minute]]\'\' on the album track "Long Hot Summer" as well as the second single "In This World".<ref>{{cite web|title=Talib Kweli + Hi-Tek Are Reflection Eternal \xe2\x80\x93 Revolutions Per Minute|url=http://www.discogs.com/Talib-Kweli-Hi-Tek-Are-Reflection-Eternal-Revolutions-Per-Minute/release/2285240|website=discogs.com|publisher=Discogs|accessdate=2014-12-21}}</ref> Lipscomb would also contribute additional background vocals on "Toyz N Da Hood" from [[Snoop Dogg]]\'s 2011 album \'\'[[Doggumentary]]\'\'.<ref>Snoop Dogg- Doggumentary (CD liner notes). Doggystyle/Priority Records. 509999 07952 2 0</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Snoop Dogg \xe2\x80\x93 Doggumentary|url=http://www.discogs.com/Snoop-Dogg-Doggumentary/release/3001368|website=discogs.com|publisher=Discogs|accessdate=2014-12-21}}</ref>

 ****** Marcus Miller

Marcus Miller V7 Bass}}

\'\'\'Marcus Miller\'\'\' (born \'\'\'William Henry Marcus Miller, Jr.\'\'\'; June 14, 1959) is an American [[jazz]] composer, producer and [[multi-instrumentalist]], best known as a [[bass guitar]]ist. Throughout his career, Miller worked with trumpeter [[Miles Davis]], pianist [[Herbie Hancock]], singer [[Luther Vandross]], and saxophonist [[David Sanborn]], as well as maintaining a successful solo career. Miller is classically trained as a [[clarinet]]ist and also plays [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]], [[saxophone]] and [[guitar]].

==Life and career==

===Early life===
Miller was born in [[Brooklyn]], New York City, in 1959 and raised in a musical family that includes his father, William Miller (a church organist and choir director) and jazz pianist [[Wynton Kelly]]. By 13, Marcus was proficient on clarinet, piano and bass guitar, and already writing songs. Two years later he was working regularly in New York City, eventually playing bass and writing music for jazz flutist [[Bobbi Humphrey]] and keyboardist [[Lonnie Liston Smith]]. Miller soon became a first call session musician, appearing on over 500 albums by such artists as [[Michael Jackson]], [[Herbie Hancock]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Wayne Shorter]], [[McCoy Tyner]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[George Benson]], [[Dr. John]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Elton John]], [[Grover Washington, Jr.]], [[Donald Fagen]], [[Bill Withers]], [[Chaka Khan]], [[LL Cool J]] and [[Flavio Sala]].

===Professional career===
[[Image:MarcusMillerParadiso.jpg|thumb|170px|Miller at the [[Paradiso (Amsterdam)|Paradiso]] in Amsterdam, 2007]]
Miller spent approximately 15&nbsp;years performing as a [[sideman]] or [[session musician]], observing how band leaders operated. During that time he also did a lot of arranging and producing. He was a member of the \'\'[[Saturday Night Live]]\'\' band 1978-1979. He wrote the intro to Aretha Franklin\'s "I Wanna Make It Up To You". He has played bass on over 500 recordings including those of Luther Vandross, Grover Washington Jr., [[Roberta Flack]], [[Carly Simon]], McCoy Tyner, [[Bryan Ferry]] and [[Billy Idol]].  He won the "Most Valuable Player" award, (awarded by [[NARAS]] to recognize studio musicians) three years in a row and was subsequently awarded "player emeritus" status and retired from eligibility. In the nineties, Miller began to make his own records, putting a band together to take advantage of touring opportunities.

Between 1988 and 1990 he appeared in the first season and again toward the end as both the musical director and also as the house band bass player in the Sunday Night Band during the two seasons of the acclaimed music performance program \'\'[[Sunday Night (American TV program)|Sunday Night]]\'\' on [[NBC]] late-night television.<ref>\'\'Sunday Night\'\' episodes No.&nbsp;104 (1988), No.&nbsp;121 (1989)</ref>

As a composer, Miller wrote all but two of the songs on \'\'[[Tutu (album)|Tutu]]\'\' for Miles Davis, including its title track &ndash; a piece that defined Davis\'s career in the late 1980s. He also composed "Chicago Song" for [[David Sanborn]] and co-wrote "[[\'Til My Baby Comes Home]]", "[[It\'s Over Now (Luther Vandross song)|It\'s Over Now]]", "[[For You to Love]]", and "[[Power of Love/Love Power|Power of Love]]" for Luther Vandross.  Miller also wrote "[[Da Butt]]", which was featured in [[Spike Lee]]\'s \'\'[[School Daze]]\'\'.

Miller currently has [[bandleader|his own band]]. In 1997 he played bass guitar and bass clarinet in a band called Legends, featuring [[Eric Clapton]] (guitars and vocals), [[Joe Sample]] (piano), David Sanborn (alto sax) and [[Steve Gadd]] (drums). It was an 11-date tour of major jazz festivals in Europe.

On Sunday November 25, 2012, Miller\'s tour bus crashed in Switzerland, en route to [[Monte Carlo]]. The driver was killed, but Miller, ten members of his band, and another driver sustained no life-threatening injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/474030/bassist-marcus-miller-injured-in-fatal-bus-crash |title=Bassist Marcus Miller Injured in Fatal Bus Crash |publisher=Billboard |date= |accessdate=2014-05-19}}</ref>

In addition to his recording and performance career, Miller has established a parallel career as a [[film score]] composer ([[Marcus Miller#Film scores|see listing below]]), having written numerous scores for films.<ref>See also interview on ABC Radio National Music Show with Andrew Ford Nov 2010</ref>

===Awards and recognition===
[[File:Marcus Miller at Stockholm Jazz Fest 2009.jpg|thumb|240px|Marcus Miller at Stockholm Jazz Fest 2009]]
Miller has won numerous [[Grammy Award]]s as a producer for Miles Davis, Luther Vandross, David Sanborn, [[Bob James (musician)|Bob James]], [[Chaka Khan]] and [[Wayne Shorter]]. He won a [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Song]] in 1992, for Luther Vandross\' "[[Power of Love/Love Power|Power of Love]]" and in 2001 he won for [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Jazz Album|Best Contemporary Jazz Album]] for his seventh solo instrumental album, [[M2 (album)|M2]].

In 2012 Miller was appointed an [[UNESCO]] Artist for Peace supporting and promoting the UNESCO Slave Route Project.

==Instruments==
He plays a 1977 [[Fender Jazz Bass]] that was modified by [[Sadowsky|Roger Sadowsky]] with the addition of a Bartolini preamp so he could control his sound in the studio.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]] started to produce a [[Marcus Miller signature Fender Jazz Bass]] in four- (Made in Japan) and five-string (made in U.S) versions. Later, Fender moved the production of the 4-string to their Mexico factory<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fender.com/products/search.php?partno=0257802321 |title=Fender,com |publisher=Fender.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}} {{dead link|date=November 2013}}</ref> and discontinued both 4 and 5-string models in 2015. DR Strings also produced a series of Marcus Miller signature stainless steel strings known as "Fat Beams," which come in a variety of sizes.<ref>[http://www.drstrings.com/#!fat-beams/c1k2b Marcus Miller Fat Beams at Drstrings.com.] Retrieved 23 November 2014.</ref> As of 2015, Dunlop has began producing Marcus Miller Super Bright bass strings which Miller has switched to.<ref>[http://www.jimdunlop.com/product/marcus-miller-super-bright Marcus Miller Super Bright Strings and Dunlop.com] Retrieved 26 March 2015.</ref>

==Discography==
Miller has an extensive discography, and tours frequently and widely in [[Europe]] and [[Japan]].

 ****** Mingo Fishtrap

b'{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = Mingo Fishtrap
| image             = 
| alt         = 
| caption        = 
| image_size        = 
| background      = group_or_band
| alias           = 
| origin          = 
| genre           = [[Soul music|Soul]] and [[Funk]]
| years_active    = {{Start date|1996}}\xe2\x80\x93 Present
| label           = 
| associated_acts = 
| website             = {{URL|mingofishtrap.com}}
| current_members = Roger Blevins, Jr. [[Guitar]]/[[Lead Vocals]], Chip Vayenas [[Drum kit|Drums]]/[[Vocals]], Dane Farnsworth [[Organ (music)|Organ]]/[[Keyboards]], Mikel Urdy [[Percussion]], Roger Blevins Sr. [[Bass Guitar|Bass]], Steve Butts [[Trumpet]]/[[Fl\xc3\xbcgelhorn]], Dan Bechdolt [[Tenor Saxophone]], Zol Waterhouse [Trombone]
| past_members    = Scott Davis [[Drum kit|Drums]], Mark Gonzales [[Trombone]], Aeron Riordon [[Organ (music)|Organ]]/[[Keyboards]], Tim Young [[Organ (music)|Organ]]/[[Keyboards]], Paul Elder [[Baritone Saxophone]], Michael Duffy [[Percussion]] Greg Wilson [[Baritone Saxophone]]/[[Alto Saxophone]]
}}

\'\'\'Mingo Fishtrap\'\'\' is a [[Soul music|Soul]] and [[funk]] band based in [[Austin, Texas]].<ref>Carolyn Lamberson. "Group\'s New Orleans Funk Takes Detour Through Austin". \'\'[[Eugene Register-Guard]]\'\', 6/24/2005.</ref><ref>"Mingo Fishtrap plans McDavid New Years Eve bash". \'\'[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]\'\', 12/23/2009.</ref><ref>Ron Williams. [http://packet-media.com/2011/05/01/prepare-to-be-funktified-with-mingo-fishtrap/ "Prepare To Be Funktified With Mingo Fishtrap".] \'\'[[The Columbus Packet]]\'\', 5/1/2011</ref><ref>Casey Phillips. [http://timesfreepress.com/news/2011/aug/05/q-roger-blevins-jr-front-man-mingo-fishtrap/ "Q&A with Roger Blevins, Jr., front man of Mingo Fishtrap".] \'\'[[Chattanooga Times Free Press]]\'\', 8/5/2011.</ref><ref>Jessica Szafoni. [http://articles.mcall.com/2011-08-09/news/mc-musikfest-mingo-20110809_1_music-school-band-members-musikfest "Mingo Fishtrap bring a funky party to Musikfest".] \'\'[[The Morning Call]]\'\', 8/9/2011.</ref><ref>Chris Riemenschneider. "The BIGGER they are, the HARDER they GROOVE; Horns. Drums. Crowds." \'\'[[Austin American-Statesman]]\'\', 11/2/2000.</ref><ref>Jim Beal Jr. "Bands rock clubs with groove, noise". \'\'[[San Antonio Express-News]]\'\', 1/24/2000</ref> They were formed in the mid-1990s in [[Denton, Texas|Denton]], Texas. The band consists of Roger Blevins, Jr. [[Guitar]]/[[Lead Vocals]], Chip Vayenas [[Drum kit|Drums]]/[[Vocals]], Dane Farnsworth [[Organ (music)|Organ]]/[[Keyboards]], Mikel Urdy [[Percussion]], Roger Blevins Sr. [[Bass Guitar|Bass]], Steve Butts [[Trumpet]]/[[Fl\xc3\xbcgelhorn]], Dan Bechdolt [[Tenor Saxophone]], Zol Waterhouse [Trombone] They have, with a few personnel changes over the years, released six albums and one concert video: \'\'Succotash\'\' 1997, \'\'From The Private Bag\'\' 2000, \'\'EP2\'\' 2004, \'\'Yesterday\'\' 2005 and "On Time" 2014<ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2005-09-16/290807/ "Record review: Mingo Fishtrap&mdash;Yesterday (Manor Productions)".] \'\'[[The Austin Chronicle]]\'\', 9/16/2005.</ref> a concert DVD; \'\'Live at the Granada\'\' 2006, \'\'EP3\'\' 2008 and \'\'In The Meantime\'\' 2010.

== References ==
<references/>

==External links==
*[http://www.mingofishtrap.com Official Website]

 ****** Blue Mitchell

b'{{Refimprove|date=July 2014}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}}
{{Infobox musical artist
|name = Blue Mitchell
|image =
|caption = 
|background = non_vocal_instrumentalist
|birth_name = Richard Allen Mitchell
|alias = Blue Mitchell
|birth_date = {{birth date|1930|3|13|mf=y}}
|birth_place =Miami, Florida, United States 
|death_date = {{death date and age|1979|5|21|1930|3|13|mf=y}}
|death_place =Los Angeles, California, United States 
|instrument = Trumpet
|genre = [[Jazz]], [[soul jazz]], [[hard bop]]
|occupation = Musician
|years_active = 
|label = [[Blue Note Records|Blue Note]], [[Mainstream Records|Mainstream]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Riverside Records|Riverside]]
|associated_acts = [[Julian Cannonball Adderley|Cannonball Adderley]], [[Earl Bostic]], [[Horace Silver]], [[Paul Williams (saxophonist)|Paul Williams]], [[Chuck Willis]]
|website = 
}}

\'\'\'Richard Allen\'\'\' "\'\'\'Blue\'\'\'" \'\'\'Mitchell\'\'\' (March 13, 1930 \xe2\x80\x93 May 21, 1979) was an American [[jazz]], [[rhythm and blues]], soul, rock, and [[funk]] trumpeter, known for many albums recorded as leader and sideman for [[Riverside Records|Riverside]], [[Blue Note Records|Blue Note]] and then [[Mainstream Records]].<ref name=ALLMUSIC>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p7140/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic Biography]</ref>

==Biography==
Mitchell was born and raised in [[Miami, Florida]]. He began playing trumpet in high school, where he acquired his nickname, Blue.<ref name="ALLMUSIC"/>

After high school he played in the rhythm and blues ensembles of [[Paul Williams (saxophonist)|Paul Williams]], [[Earl Bostic]], and [[Chuck Willis]]. After returning to Miami he was noticed by [[Julian Cannonball Adderley|Cannonball Adderley]], with whom he recorded for [[Riverside Records]] in New York in 1958.

He then joined the [[Horace Silver]] Quintet, playing with tenor saxophonist [[Junior Cook]], bassist [[Gene Taylor (bassist)|Gene Taylor]] and drummer [[Roy Brooks]]. Mitchell stayed with Silver\'s group until the band\'s break-up in 1964, after which he formed a group with members from the Silver quintet, substituting the young pianist [[Chick Corea]] for Silver and replacing Brooks, who had fallen ill, with drummer [[Al Foster]]. This group produced a number of records for [[Blue Note]]. It disbanded in 1969, after which Mitchell joined and toured with [[Ray Charles]] until 1971.

From 1971 to 1973 Mitchell performed with [[John Mayall]], appearing on \'\'[[Jazz Blues Fusion]]\'\' and subsequent albums. From the mid-70s he recorded and worked as a session man in the genres noted previously, performed with the big band leaders [[Louie Bellson]], [[Bill Holman (musician)|Bill Holman]] and [[Bill Berry (trumpeter)|Bill Berry]] and was principal soloist for [[Tony Bennett]] and [[Lena Horne]]. Other band leaders Mitchell recorded with include [[Lou Donaldson]], [[Grant Green]], [[Philly Joe Jones]], [[Jackie McLean]], [[Hank Mobley]], [[Johnny Griffin]], [[Al Cohn]], [[Dexter Gordon]] and [[Jimmy Smith (musician)|Jimmy Smith]]. Blue Mitchell kept his hard-bop playing going with the [[Harold Land]] quintet up until his death from cancer on May 21, 1979, in Los Angeles, at the age of 49.

 ****** Janelle Mon\xc3\xa1e

b''

 ****** Walter Morrison

b'{{About|the musician|the inventor|Walter Frederick Morrison|the British politician|Walter Morrison (MP)}}
{{BLP unsourced|date=April 2015}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name                = Junie Morrison
| image               =
| image_size          =
| caption             =
| background          = solo_singer
| birth_name          = Walter Morrison
| birth_date          = {{birth year and age|1954}}
| birth_place         = [[Dayton, Ohio]], U.S.
| origin              = 
| instrument          = [[Multi-instrumentalist]]
| genre               = [[Funk]]
| occupation          = [[Keyboardist]], [[vocalist]], [[record producer|producer]]
| associated_acts     = [[Ohio Players]], [[Parliament-Funkadelic]]
| website             = {{Official website|http://www.juniemorrison.com}}
}}

\'\'\'Walter "Junie" Morrison\'\'\' is a musician and [[record producer|producer]] born in [[Dayton, Ohio]]. Morrison was a producer, writer, keyboardist and [[singing|vocalist]] for the [[funk]] band the [[Ohio Players]] in the early 70s, where he wrote and produced their first major hits, "Pain", "Pleasure", "Ecstasy" and "Funky Worm" (1971-1972). He left the band in 1974 to release three [[solo album]]s on [[Westbound Records]] (\'\'When We Do\'\', \'\'Freeze\'\', and \'\'Suzie Supergroupie\'\').

In 1977 Morrison joined [[George Clinton (funk musician)|George Clinton]]\'s [[P-Funk]] ([[Parliament (band)|Parliament]]-[[Funkadelic]]) where he became musical director.  He brought a unique sound to P-Funk and played a key role during the time of their greatest popularity from 1978 through 1980. In particular, he made prominent contributions to the platinum-selling Funkadelic album \'\'[[One Nation Under a Groove]]\'\', the single "[[(Not Just) Knee Deep]]" (a #1 hit on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|U.S. R&B charts]] in 1979) and the gold-selling Parliament albums \'\'[[Motor Booty Affair]]\'\', and \'\'[[Gloryhallastoopid]]\'\'.  Morrison also played on and produced some P-Funk material under the [[pseudonym]] J.S. Theracon, apparently to avoid contractual difficulties. Morrison is a member of the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]], inducted in 1997 with fifteen other members of [[Parliament-Funkadelic]].

After his time with Parliament-Funkadelic, he recorded three solo albums in the eighties including 1980\'s \'\'[[Bread Alone]]\'\', 1981\'s \'\'[[Junie 5]]\'\', and 1984\'s \'\'[[Evacuate Your Seats]]\'\'.

Morrison produced other artists throughout the [[1990s in music|90s]] and continued to contribute to P-Funk albums, most recently in 1996.

He released a new solo album, \'\'When the City\'\', on his own label Juniefunk in 2004.

==Discography==

===Solo albums===
*\'\'When We Do\'\' (1975) - Credited to \'\'\'Junie\'\'\'
*\'\'Freeze\'\' (1975) - Credited to \'\'\'Junie\'\'\'
*\'\'Suzie Supergroupie\'\' (1976) - Credited to \'\'\'Junie\'\'\'
*\'\'[[Bread Alone]]\'\' (1980)
*\'\'[[Junie 5]]\'\' (1981)
*\'\'Evacuate Your Seats\'\' (1984)

==External links==
* [http://www.discogs.com/artist/Junie+Morrison Partial discography at discogs.com]

 ****** The Motet

b':\'\'For the type of composition, see [[motet]]
{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = The Motet
| image           =
| image_size      =
| landscape       =
| alt             =
| caption         =
| background      = group_or_band
| alias           =
| origin          =[[Denver, Colorado]]
| genre           =[[Funk]], [[rock music|rock]], [[jazz]], [[Afro-beat]]
| years_active    = {{start date|1998}}\xe2\x80\x93present
| label           = aNOnym reCOrds, Harmonized Records
| associated_acts =
| website         = {{URL|http://www.themotet.net/}}
| current_members =Dave Watts, Jans Ingber, Ryan Jalbert, Joey Porter, Garrett Sayers, Gabe Mervine, Matt Pitts
| past_members    =Dominic Lalli, Mike Tiernen, Kurt Reeber, Steve Vidiac, Scott Messersmith, Gregoire Raymond, Mark Donovan, Adam Revell, Matt Spencer
}}

\'\'\'The Motet\'\'\' is an American [[funk]], [[afrobeat]] and [[jazz]] influenced group based in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]]. Founded in 1998 by drummer and bandleader Dave Watts, The Motet is Watts, percussionist and vocalist Jans Ingber, guitarist Ryan Jalbert, bassist Garrett Sayers, keyboardist Joey Porter, trumpeter Gabe Mervine, and saxophonist Matt Pitts.<ref name="allmsuicbio"/>

Known for energetic live shows including an annual Halloween concert, the band has released seven studio albums. Their latest self-titled album was co-written and produced by all the band members, and was cut on analog recording equipment to capture their instruments\' live sounds. They continue to tour nationally and have performed at festivals such as [[Bonnaroo]], [[North Coast Music Festival]], [[Wakarusa Music and Camping Festival|Wakarusa]]<ref name="waka"/> and [[Summer Camp Festival]].<ref name="summercampfestival"/>

==History==

===1998\xe2\x80\x932004: Founding and first albums===
The Dave Watts Motet was founded in [[Boulder, Colorado]], in 1998 by drummer and arranger Dave Watts as a musical collective with a rotating cast of musicians. By 2000 the group had changed its name to The Motet and become a sextet consisting of Watts on drums, percussionist and vocalist Jans Ingber, percussionist Scott Messersmith, guitarist Mike Tiernen, bassist Kurt Reeber, and organist-keyboardist Steve Vidiac.<ref name="allmsuicbio"/> Watts, Ingber, and Messersmith had also traveled to [[Cuba]] twice to study [[bata drums]] of the [[Santeria]] religion, which at the time heavily influenced the band\'s sound, as can be heard on their first two albums.<ref name="cohnbrain"/>

The Dave Watts Motet first performed together on Halloween 1998, and at that time were incorporating elements of funk, jazz, folk, and world music into their sound.<ref name="allmsuicbio"/> Watts wrote and arranged the majority of their early music for a rotating lineup of musicians, throwing energetic local dance parties.<ref name="motetabout"/> Their debut release, \'\'Breathe\'\', was self-released in 1999, and produced entirely by Watts.<ref name="allmsuicbio"/><ref name="breathcd"/>

The band released their second album, \'\'Play\'\', on aNOnym reCOrds in 2001, which was followed in 2002 by the album \'\'Live\'\', their first record on Harmonized Records. \'\'Music for Life\'\', released in 2004, was also on Harmonized Records.<ref name="donbreath"/> Also in 2004, the band self-released the DVD \'\'Shine\'\', which was produced by James Marshello.

===2006: \'\'Instrumental Dissent\'\'===
On September 12, 2006, they released their studio album \'\'Instrumental Dissent\'\'. While the album is largely instrumental, the voices of activists such as [[Harry Belafonte]], [[Alice Walker]], and [[Noam Chomsky]] are woven into many of the songs.<ref name="allmsuicinstrument"/> [[Allmusic]] gave release 3.5/5 stars and largely positive review, writing "Motet gets off to an impressive start as the opening salvo of tunes darts between funk, Afro-beat, Latin and world sounds with a slight underpinning of electronic touches, all driven by a nimble yet fiery attack." Allmusic praised the production and audio quality as well, stating "Many of the tracks blend into each other, creating a near seamless whole."<ref name="allmsuicinstrument"/> Allmusic criticized the slower pace in the latter half of the disc, stating the album "loses some of the imagination, if not steam, of the early tunes, becoming a solid yet rather conventional work from a jazz-funk fusion outfit." However, "Scott Messersmith\'s bubbling percussion and drummer Dave Watts\' elastic beats keep the heat turned up even when the tracks tend to extend longer than needed."

===2009: \'\'Dig Deep\'\'===
Around half of The Motet\'s self-released 2009 album \'\'Dig Deep\'\'<ref name="souraudio"/> features compositions written and arranged by Watts,<ref name="jambase"/> with the drummer turned producer utilizing [[Ableton Live]] to add an electronica sound to various tracks.<ref name="cohnbrain"/> Allmusic gave \'\'Dig Deep\'\' 3/5 stars, stating "Covers of three [[Fela Kuti]] tunes show that this funk-world ensemble\'s heart lies in the tough, often horn-driven Afro-beat that dominates this set." The review acknowledges the new touches of techno, stating that Watts expands the band\'s sound, "in particular toward [[Kraftwerk]]-styled techno at times, also pushing into spacy areas that will likely be a bit alienating to some longtime fans." Much of the album also relies on "percussive [[Afro-funk]]" and Allmusic pointed out elements of [[prog rock]] on tracks such as "Guru." <ref name="allmusicbeigdeep"/>

===2014: \'\'The Motet\'\' and recent projects===
They released their seventh studio album, \'\'The Motet,\'\' in February 2014. Each member of the band contributed to the writing process, with hundreds of hours spent in the studio creating vintage funk sounds.<ref name="motetabout"/> The group came up with the basic ideas for the album\'s original nine tracks in Watts\'s home studio, then recorded and mixed the album at Immersive Studios in Boulder, Colorado and Scanhope Sound in [[Littleton, Colorado]].<ref name="westwordd"/> About \'\'The Motet\'\', Watts says "The album is really like a new era for us. Writing our own music as a band, a 100 percent collaborative effort, it\xe2\x80\x99s a real stepping stone to a sound we\xe2\x80\x99re going to be bringing consistently\xe2\x80\x9d<ref name="relix"/> Writes Dave Kirby of the \'\'[[Boulder Weekly]]\'\', \xe2\x80\x9cutterly flawless production...and not a throwaway in the bunch...ambitious, airtight and built to travel.\xe2\x80\x9d  \'\'Upstate Live\'\' says that \'\'The Motet\'\'\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c55 glorious minutes showcase their growth as individuals and as an unstoppable funk machine.\xe2\x80\x9d

===Live performances===
{{ external media
| align  =right
| video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rwhd-GKjCyA&list=UUB40I1T1eQDV7YpOGcJrW7w The Motet "Closed Mouth Don\'t Get Fed" Live] (May 2, 2014)
| video2 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mUHOTiPPQC4 "123" by The Motet, The Fillmore, Denver 4.20.13]
| video3 = [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Oq-mENgCNo "Like We Own It" Red Rocks (July 5, 2014)]
}}
The band has toured annually since its founding, primarily performing in the United States with six or seven live members<ref name="relix"/> and Dave Watts serving as bandleader.<ref name="motetabout"/>

They periodically bring special guests on stage; in January 2014, for example, they were joined on stage by drummer [[String Cheese Incident|Jason Hann]] of the [[String Cheese Incident]], trumpeter Jen Hartswick,  and vocalist and jazz trombonist [[Natalie Cressman]].<ref name="cohnallison"/>

In 2013 they played as far north as [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]],<ref name="frazier"/> and that year also performed at [[Wakarusa Music and Camping Festival|Wakarusa]].<ref name="waka"/> The following year the band toured the United States in support of their album \'\'The Motet,\'\'<ref name="souraudio"/><ref name="relix"/> performing at festivals such as [[Summer Camp Festival]].<ref name="summercampfestival"/>

==Halloween concerts==
Since 2001 The Motet has performed a series of concerts on Halloween weekend, typically in Colorado, covering the music of one particular band and dressing the part.<ref name="sweetwine"/>  Examples have included [[Earth, Wind, and Fire]],<ref name="souraudio"/> [[Parliament Funkadelic]], [[Tower of Power]], [[Jamiroquai]], [[Stevie Wonder]], and [[Prince (musician)|Prince]].<ref name="motetabout"/>

The following is a list of their annual Halloween concerts:
{{col-begin}}{{col-break}}
* 2000: [[The Beatles]]
* 2001: [[The Headhunters]]
* 2002: [[Stevie Wonder]]
* 2003: [[Tower of Power]]
* 2004: [[Prince (entertainer)|Prince]]
* 2005: [[Michael Jackson]]
* 2006: [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]
* 2007: [[Jamiroquai]]{{col-break|gap=4em}}
* 2008: [[Talking Heads]]
* 2009: [[Sly and the Family Stone]]
* 2010: [[Earth, Wind and Fire]]
* 2011: [[Grateful Dead]] (\'\'Funk is Dead\'\')
* 2012: [[Parliament/Funkadelic]]
* 2013: The Year 1980 (Mixtape 1980)
* 2014: The Year 1975 (Mixtape 1975)
{{col-end}}

==Members==
;Current<ref name="motetabout"/><ref name="souraudio"/>
* Dave Watts - drums, bandleader <small>(1998\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>
* Jans Ingber - vocalist, percussion <small>(2000\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>
* Ryan Jalbert - guitar <small>(2005\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>
* Joey Porter  - keys <small>(2006\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>
* Garrett Sayers - bass <small>(2002\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>
* Gabe Mervine - trumpet <small>(2009\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>
* Matt Pitts - tenor sax <small>(2010\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>

;Past
* Dominic Lalli - saxophone<ref name="jambase"/>
* Scott Messersmith - percussion <small>(1998-2011)</small>
* Gregoire Raymond - guitar <small>(2002-2004)</small>
* Mark Donovan - keys <small>(2004-?)</small>
* Mike Tiernen - guitar <small>(2000-2003)</small>
* Kurt Reeber - bassist <small>(2000-2002)</small>
* Steve Vidiac - organist/keyboardist <small>(2000-2002)</small>
* Adam Revell \xe2\x80\x93 keys <small>(2005-?)</small>
* Matt Spencer \xe2\x80\x93 bass <small>(1998-1999, 2002-2003)</small>

 ****** N.E.R.D

b'{{other uses2|Nerd}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
|name                = N*E*R*D
|image               = N.E.R.D @ Pori Jazz 2010.jpg
|caption             = Pharrell Williams and Shay Haley from N*E*R*D performing at Pori Jazz 2010
|image_size          = 240px
|background          = group_or_band
|origin              = [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]], United States
|genre               = [[Funk]], [[alternative rock]], [[alternative hip hop]]
|years_active        = 2000\xe2\x80\x93present
|label               = [[Virgin Records|Virgin]], [[Star Trak Entertainment|Star Trak]], [[Interscope Records|Interscope]], [[i Am Other]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]
|associated_acts     = [[The Neptunes]]
|website             = {{URL|http://www.n-e-r-d.com/}}
|current_members     = [[Pharrell Williams]]<br />[[Chad Hugo]]<br />[[Shay Haley]]
|past_members        = Rhea Dummett<br /> Eric Greene
}}

\'\'\'N*E*R*D\'\'\' (an acronym of \'\'\'No-One Ever Really Dies\'\'\') is an American [[Rock music|rock]], [[funk]], and [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] band. [[Pharrell Williams]] and [[Chad Hugo]] were signed by [[Teddy Riley (producer)|Teddy Riley]] to [[Virgin Records]] as a duo, [[The Neptunes]]. After producing songs for several artists throughout the late 1990s and early 2000s, the production duo formed the band with [[Shay Haley]] as a side project of The Neptunes in 2001. N*E*R*D\'s debut album, \'\'[[In Search of... (N*E*R*D album)|In Search Of...]]\'\', sold 603,000 copies in the United States and was certified [[Music recording sales certification|Gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). It was also awarded the second annual [[Shortlist Music Prize]]. The band\'s second album, \'\'[[Fly or Die]]\'\', sold 412,000 copies in the United States, but shipped at least 500,000 units making it qualify for RIAA\'s Gold Certification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinum.php?content_selector=criteria |title=Recording Industry Association of America |publisher=RIAA |accessdate=2012-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=N.E.R.D&format=ALBUM&startYear=1958&endYear=2009&sort=Artist&perPage=25 |title=Recording Industry Association of America |publisher=RIAA |accessdate=2012-03-29}}</ref>

In 2005, N*E*R*D ended their contract with Virgin and disbanded. Three years later, the band reunited under [[Star Trak Entertainment]], a subsidiary of [[Interscope Records]] established by Williams and Hugo. The band\'s third album, \'\'[[Seeing Sounds]]\'\', sold 80,000+ copies in its first week.

==History==

===Formation and early career===
[[Pharrell Williams]] and [[Chad Hugo]] met at the age of 12 at a band class in Virginia Beach.<ref name="The Age">{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/05/12/1084289744331.html|title=Like the song? These guys wrote it|date=2004-05-15|work=[[The Age]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=2009-02-06}}</ref><ref name="Westword">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.westword.com/backbeat/2008/04/vintage_nerd_profile.php|title=Vintage N.E.R.D. Profile|last=Roberts|first=Michael|date=2008-04-23|work=[[Westword]]|publisher=[[New Times Media]]|accessdate=2009-02-06}}</ref> Additionally was the Drum Major for the Kempsville High School Marching Chiefs, under the direction of current University of Virginia Band Director, William Pease, while Pharrell was a drumline member of the (FMC) The Fabulous Marching Cavaliers of Princess Anne High School, both of Virginia Beach, VA. They spent their free time making [[beat (music)|beats]] and performing in groups with fellow childhood friend [[Timbaland]]. Williams and Hugo met [[Shae Haley]] in high school and began performing together. The trio often met in Hugo\'s garage, where he [[beatboxing|beatboxed]] through a [[loudspeaker|speaker system]] while Haley danced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25111550-5013575,00.html|title=Hip-hop\'s glittering touchstone|date=2009-02-27|work=[[The Australian]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=2009-03-11}}</ref> After watching the duo perform at a high school [[talent show]], [[Teddy Riley (producer)|Teddy Riley]], a musician and producer, signed Williams and Hugo in 1992.<ref name="Westword" /> After producing songs for several artists throughout the late 1990s and early 2000s, the production duo formed N.E.R.D in 2001 as a side project.<ref name="The Age"/><ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p415988|pure_url=yes}}|title=N.E.R.D. - Biography|last=Kellman|first=Andy|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=2009-01-30}}</ref><ref name="Los Angeles Times">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-ca-nerd1-2008jun01,0,3641264.story|title=The cool part about being a N.E.R.D.|last=Lee|first=Chris|date=2008-06-01|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|pages=1\xe2\x80\x932|accessdate=2009-02-06}}</ref>

===2001\xe2\x80\x932002: \'\'In Search Of...\'\'===
The band\'s debut album, \'\'[[In Search Of... (N.E.R.D album)|In Search Of...]]\'\', was released in Europe in September 2001. Williams and Hugo used similar digital production techniques as they did for other artists. However, the band decided that they wanted to sound different from their previous work.<ref name="Jakarta Globe">{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/life-times/arts-entertainment/article/13377.html|title=N.E.R.D.\'s Not Your Stereotypical Group|last=Siahaan|first=Armando|date=2009-03-18|work=[[Jakarta Globe]]|publisher=Jakarta Globe Media|accessdate=2009-04-05}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> This led them to rerecording the album using live instruments with [[rock music|rock]] band [[Spymob]] for a worldwide release in 2002.<ref name="Jakarta Globe"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/nerd/articles/story/5938447/in_search_of____pharrell_williams|title=In Search of... Pharrell Williams|last=Edwards|first=Gavin|date=2002-06-21|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|accessdate=2009-04-05}}</ref> The album debuted at number 61 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]] and peaked at number 56.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1435189|title=\'O Brother\' Still Finds Itself On Top|last=Martens|first=Todd|date=2002-03-21|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Nielsen Company|Nielsen Business Media]]|accessdate=2009-04-05}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="ISO sales">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/search/google/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000475647|title=Usher Breaks Records With \'Confessions\' Debut|last=Martens|first=Todd|date=2004-03-31|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|accessdate=2009-01-30}}</ref> It failed to replicate the success of The Neptunes\' previous productions. The album won the second annual [[Shortlist Music Prize]], an accolade awarded to albums released in the United States that have not achieved mainstream success and have sales of 500,000 copies or less at the time of nomination.<ref name="Jakarta Globe"/> The album sold 603,000 copies in the United States and was certified [[music recording sales certification|Gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].<ref name="ISO sales"/><ref name="RIAA">{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=N.E.R.D&format=ALBUM&startYear=1958&endYear=2009&sort=Artist&perPage=25|title=RIAA - Gold & Platinum|work=[[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]|accessdate=2009-01-30}}</ref>

The album\'s lead single, "[[Lapdance (song)|Lapdance]]", peaked at number 36 of the [[Hot Rap Tracks]] chart and number 85 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1075298|title=Neptunes\' N*E*R*D Pushed To November|last=Carpenter|first=Troy|date=2001-10-08|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|accessdate=2009-04-05}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The second single, "[[Rock Star (N.E.R.D song)|Rock Star]]", peaked at number 36 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' [[Hot Modern Rock Tracks]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/retrieve_chart_history.do?model.chartFormatGroupName=Singles&model.vnuArtistId=383104&model.vnuAlbumId=1146053|title=Artist Chart History - N.E.R.D. - Singles|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|accessdate=2009-04-05}}</ref> A 6.1 surround mix of this album was released by DTS Entertainment on a [[DVD-Audio]] disc in 2005. The original version of the album is a collectors\' item.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}

===2003\xe2\x80\x932004: \'\'Fly or Die\'\'===
[[File:NERD April 2003 cropped.jpg|thumb|N.E.R.D performing at a United Kingdom concert in April 2003]]
The band recorded its second album, \'\'[[Fly or Die]]\'\', in 2003. They learned to play the songs live, as Chad Hugo told [[MTV News]] on December 9, 2003: "We\'re the ones playing the instruments live this time. I just started playing guitar last year so I\'m learning as we go. Pharrell\'s playing drums. [Last time] we didn\'t have time to learn certain instruments so we got Spymob to help us out."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1480969/20031209/story.jhtml|title=N.E.R.D. Step Up Their Game On Fly Or Die, Reminisce About Teen Years|last=Patel|first=Joseph|date=2003-12-09|work=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=2009-04-05}}</ref>

\'\'Fly or Die\'\' was released in March 2004. The album debuted at number six on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], selling 119,000 copies in its first week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000475647|title=Usher Breaks Records With \'Confessions\' Debut|last=Martens|first=Todd|date=2004-03-31|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|accessdate=2009-04-05}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The album sold 412,000 copies in the United States and was certified [[music recording sales certification|Gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].<ref name="RIAA" /><ref name="FoD sales">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/57937/pharrell-finds-time-for-nerd-jay-z|title=Pharrell Finds Time For N.E.R.D., Jay-Z|last=Hope|first=Clover|date=2006-07-03|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|accessdate=2009-01-30}}</ref> The first single, "[[She Wants to Move]]", has gone top 5 in the United Kingdom, top 20 in Norway, Ireland, and Denmark, and top 40 in Australia and the Netherlands. The music videos for "She Wants to Move" and its follow-up single, "[[Maybe (N.E.R.D song)|Maybe]]", have received strong support from the digital cable network [[VH1 Soul]] in America.

===2005\xe2\x80\x932009: Hiatus and \'\'Seeing Sounds\'\'===
In 2005, N.E.R.D ended their contract with [[Virgin Records]] over a label dispute and the band disbanded.<ref name="Jakarta Globe" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.westword.com/backbeat/2008/04/qa_with_pharrell_williams_of_n.php|title=Q&A With Pharrell Williams of N.E.R.D.|last=Roberts|first=Michael|date=2008-04-28|work=Westword|publisher=New Times Media|accessdate=2009-02-06}}</ref> While touring, the band became "hooked" on the energy from their fans, which led them to begin recording their third [[studio album]], spending their own money while still unsigned. Williams and Hugo later established [[Star Trak Entertainment]], a subsidiary of [[Interscope Records]].<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> In March 2008, the band performed at [[South by Southwest]] in Austin, Texas. While there they filmed a [[Public service announcement|PSA]] for [[Rock the Vote]] saying why they thought voting was important and the issues they cared about that election year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RKLizKy2PO4 |title=NERD - Rock the Vote at SXSW |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-05-27 |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref>

[[File:NERD at Virgin Festival Ontario day 2 2009.JPG|left|thumb|N.E.R.D performing at the [[Virgin Festival]] in [[Ontario]], [[Canada]], 2009]]

From April to June 2008, the band toured with [[Kanye West]] as an opening act along with [[Rihanna]] and [[Lupe Fiasco]] as part of the [[Glow in the Dark Tour]]. On June 13, they gave an energetic performance at the [[Isle of Wight]] festival, however they almost missed their scheduled show because they didn\'t know where the island was.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/nerd%20just%20make%20it%20for%20isle%20of%20wight_1071467 |title=NERD Just Make It For Isle of Wight |publisher=Contactmusic.com |date=2008-06-14 |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> On June 25, they performed in front of 40,000 people at the Isle of MTV 2008 at the Floriana granaries, [[Malta]] with free admission.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isleofmtv.com |title=Malta Special 2008 |publisher=Isle of MTV |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref><ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfIp92BnjiU YouTube - Broadcast Yourself]{{dead link|date=August 2011}}</ref>
On August 9, 2008, the band played at the Way Out West music festival held in the city park of Gothenburg, Sweden. In September 2008, N.E.R.D performed to a sold-out crowd at the [[House of Blues]] in [[Chicago]], and brought special guest [[Bad Brains]] onstage.

N.E.R.D released their third studio album, \'\'[[Seeing Sounds]]\'\' in June 2008. The first single off the album, titled "[[Everyone Nose (All the Girls Standing in the Line for the Bathroom)]]", was first mentioned on their [[Billionaire Boys Club (clothing)|Billionaire Boys Club]] blog in January 2008. The second single off the album, titled "[[Spaz (song)|Spaz]]", was used in a TV commercial for the Microsoft [[Zune]].

A song entitled "Soldier" featuring [[Santigold]] and [[Lil Wayne]] was featured on the [[Soundtrack 90210|soundtrack]] of the teen drama \'\'[[90210 (TV series)|90210]]\'\'.

The group toured with an American [[rock music|rock]] band, [[Linkin Park]] on their music festival [[Projekt Revolution]] on it\'s 2008, European leg with artists like [[HIM (Finnish band)|HIM]], [[The Used]] and [[Jay-Z]]. The group also played at the [[National Bowl]], [[Milton Keynes]] before the recording of [[Road to Revolution: Live at Milton Keynes|Road to Revolution]] by Linkin Park.<ref>[http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/nerd/2008/milton-keynes-national-bowl-milton-keynes-england-bd22586.html N.E.R.D. setlist at National Bowl]</ref>

===2010\xe2\x80\x93present: \'\'Nothing\'\'===
In 2010, N.E.R.D announced the release of their fourth studio album entitled \'\'[[Nothing (N.E.R.D. album)|Nothing]]\'\', which had a scheduled release date for September 7, 2010, but was pushed back to November 2, 2010. The first single from the album, "[[Hot-n-Fun]]" featuring Canadian recording artist [[Nelly Furtado]], was released on May 18, 2010 on iTunes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2010/04/24/new-music-nerd-f-nelly-furtado-hot-fun-full/|title=New Music: N.E.R.D. f/ Nelly Furtado \xe2\x80\x93 \'Hot-n-Fun\' [Full]|date=April 24, 2010|work=[[Rap-Up]]|accessdate=April 25, 2010}}</ref> It was released in the United Kingdom on August 30, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author=Praxis Media |url=http://www.radio1.gr/music/forthcoming_uk_singles.htm |title=Radio1 Rodos Greece ::: UK Forthcoming Singles |publisher=Radio1.gr |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref>

On August 20, 2010, a track titled "Party People" leaked onto the internet. It was rumored to be the second single from the album. On September 28, 2010, they premiered another track from the album titled "[[Hypnotize U]]" on \'\'[[Late Show with David Letterman]]\'\', produced by [[electronic music]] duo [[Daft Punk]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.missinfo.tv/index.php/video-n-e-r-d-debuts-hypnotize-you-live-on-david-letterman/|title=Video: N.E.R.D. debuts "Hypnotize You" (Live on David Letterman)|date=September 29, 2010|work=[[Miss Info]]|accessdate=September 29, 2010}}</ref> On September 30, 2010, in an interview with [[Mark Hoppus]] on \'\'[[A Different Spin with Mark Hoppus]]\'\', Pharrell explained the album cover as "a mix of so many things. The feathers represent the peace, and the helmet represents the war. It\'s like where we are right now. There\'s a lot of war, that people can\'t necessarily explain. The economy sucks, girls are still beautiful. We wanted to make music that reflected that. So people can look back twenty years from now, and say \'this is what was going on\'". They then announced in the interview that the next two singles would be "I\'ve Seen the Light" and "Hypnotize U". Pharrell described "Hypnotize U" as being "so different from the rest of the album", stating he was "very pleased because it serves a different purpose" in the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bbcicecream.com/blog/2010/10/01/nerd-interview-w-mark-hoppus/|title=N*E*R*D INTERVIEW W/ MARK HOPPUS|date=October 1, 2010|accessdate=October 1, 2010}}</ref>

On October 17, 2010, the standard edition and the deluxe edition of the album became available for pre-order on [[iTunes]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://itunes.apple.com/us/preorder/nothing-deluxe-version/id398037651|title=Nothing (Deluxe Version)by N.E.R.D.|date=October 17, 2010|accessdate=October 17, 2010}}</ref> It was later announced that they would support [[Gorillaz]] on the North American leg of their 2010 \'Escape to Plastic Beach\' world tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gorillaz.com/news/news/gorillaz-confirm-nerd-as-support-special-guests-for-north-american-dates|title=GORILLAZ CONFIRM N.E.R.D. AS SUPPORT, SPECIAL GUESTS FOR NORTH AMERICAN DATES|date=September 10, 2010|accessdate=September 10, 2010}}</ref> In 2013, Pharrell confirmed a N.E.R.D album was in progress, but also mentioned that the album would not be released that year due to the projects he was working on with other artists. He has also said the album will be "nature-based". The group reunited on December 26, 2014 to release the song "Squeeze Me" for the film \'\'[[The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water]]\'\'.

==Musical style==
The band\'s sound generally contains elements of [[rock music|rock]], [[funk]] and [[hip hop music|hip hop]], while also encompassing [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[pop music|pop]].<ref name="EW">{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,216215~4~0~insearchof,00.html|title=Music Review - In Search Of... (2002) - N.E.R.D.|last=Browne|first=David|date=2002-03-11|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time]]|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref><ref name="The Guardian">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2004/mar/19/popandrock.nerd|title=CD: N*E*R*D, Fly or Die|last=Petridis|first=Alexis|date=2004-03-19|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref> They have been praised for their heavy use of [[electronic music|electronic]], [[Bass (sound)|bass]] and [[funk]] beats,<ref>{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|date=2008-06-13|title=Music Review - Seeing Sounds (2008) - N.E.R.D.|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Time|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20206316,00.html|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Farber|first=Jim|date=2008-06-08|title=N.E.R.D. gets its giddy up|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|publisher=[[Mortimer Zuckerman]]|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2008/06/08/2008-06-08_nerd_gets_its_giddy_up.html|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ruhi|first=Adrian|date=2008-06-09|title=N*E*R*D - Seeing Sounds|work=[[Okayplayer]]|url=http://www.okayplayer.com/reviews/june-2008/n*e*r*d-200806095866/|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref> while others have suggested that [[The Neptunes]] are unable to blend [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[rock music|rock]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Petridis|first=Alexis|date=2008-06-13|title=N*E*R*D, Seeing Sounds|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Media Group|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2008/jun/13/urban.shopping|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref>

N.E.R.D\'s lyrics have been criticized. Ian Cohen of [[Pitchfork Media]] called the band\'s writing ability "far down the list of what N.E.R.D is actually good at",<ref>{{cite web|last=Cohen|first=Ian|date=2008-06-13|title=N.E.R.D.: Seeing Sounds|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11610-seeing-sounds/|accessdate=2009-01-15}}</ref> where Williams is often criticized for being excessively sexual.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hoard|first=Christian|date=2008-06-12|title=Seeing Sounds - N.E.R.D. - Review|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/20949346/review/20961630/seeing_sounds|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/nerd/7357|title=N*E*R*D* - Fly Or Die - Album Reviews|last=Friel|first=Lance|date=2004-03-26|work=[[NME]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time]]|accessdate=2009-04-09}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> With the release of \'\'[[Fly or Die]]\'\', the album was advertised in \'\'[[Kerrang!]]\'\' magazine, which made Alexis Petridis of \'\'[[The Guardian]]\'\' feel that N.E.R.D\'s lyrics tried to "[[empathize]] with the alienated teenagers who make up \'\'Kerrang!\'\'{{\'}}s readership".<ref name="The Guardian"/>

==Band members==
* [[Pharrell Williams]] - [[singing#Lead and backing vocalists|lead vocals]], [[piano]]/[[keyboard instrument|keyboards]], [[drum kit|drums]], [[percussion instrument|percussion]]
* [[Chad Hugo]] - [[lead guitar]], piano/keyboards, [[saxophone]], [[bass guitar]], backing vocals
* [[Shae Haley]] - drums, percussion, [[backing vocalist|backing vocals]]

===Singles===
{|class="wikitable"

\'\'\'Notes\'\'\'
{{refbegin}}
*\'\'\'A.\'\'\' {{Note|UK}}"Lapdance" was re-released in the UK as a [[A-side and B-side|double A-side]] with "Provider".
*\'\'\'B.\'\'\' {{Note|SWTM}}"She Wants to Move" only peaked on the [[Hot Digital Tracks]] chart.
*\'\'\'C.\'\'\' {{Note|BU}}"Spaz" peaked outside of the US \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100 chart, therefore it is listed on the [[Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles|Bubbling Under Hot 100]] chart.
{{refend}}

 ****** The Neville Brothers

b'{{About|the American R&B and Soul group|the English football players sometimes called the Neville brothers|Gary Neville|and|Phil Neville}}

{{Infobox musical artist
| name             = The Neville Brothers
| image              =
| caption         = 
| background       = group_or_band
| origin           = 
| years_active     = 1977\xe2\x80\x93present
| genre            = [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[soul music|soul]], [[funk]] 
| label            = [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Black Top Records|Black Top]], [[A&M Records|A&M]], [[EMI]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], Back Porch
| current_members  = [[Art Neville]]<br />Charles Neville<br />[[Aaron Neville]]<br />[[Cyril Neville]]<br />[[Ivan Neville]]
| past_members     = 
| website              = [http://www.nevilles.com/ Nevilles.com]
}}
\'\'\'The Neville Brothers\'\'\', an [[United States|American]] [[rhythm and blues|R&B]]/[[soul music|soul]]/[[funk]] group, was formed in 1977 in [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]].

==History==
The group notion started in 1976, when the four brothers of the Neville family, [[Art Neville|Art]] (born 1937), Charles (b. 1938), [[Aaron Neville|Aaron]] (b. 1941), and [[Cyril Neville|Cyril]] (b. 1948) got together to take part in the recording session of [[The Wild Tchoupitoulas]], a [[Mardi Gras Indians|Mardi Gras Indian]] group led by their uncle, George Landry ("Big Chief Jolly").

[[Art Neville]] reached out to Paul Howrilla (personal manager for [[Dr. John]]) and told him that he always wanted to do something with his brothers. Paul Howrilla created Neville Productions, Inc., serving as president and CEO with all four Neville brothers as members of the board of directors. The newly formed business covered the entire Neville family, designed to protect them from the music business abuse they had previously endured in their individual careers.

This experience led them to form the group the following year. Their debut album was released from [[Capitol Records]] in 1978. It included \'\'"Bird on a Wire"\'\'. 

In 1988, the group released \'\'Uptown\'\' from [[EMI]] featuring guests including [[Branford Marsalis]], [[Keith Richards]], and [[Carlos Santana]]. The following year saw the release of \'\'[[Yellow Moon]]\'\' from [[A&M Records]] produced by [[Daniel Lanois]]. The track "Healing Chant" from that album won best pop instrumental performance of the [[Grammy Award]]s.<ref>[http://grammys.com/GRAMMY_Awards/Winners/ Grammy Award Winners]</ref> 

In 1990, the Neville Brothers contributed "[[In the Still of the Night (Cole Porter song)|In the Still of the Night]]" to the AIDS benefit album [[Red Hot + Blue]] produced by the [[Red Hot Organization]]. Also in 1990, they appeared on the bill at that year\'s [[Glastonbury Festival]].<ref name="NME Rock \'N\' Roll Years">{{cite book
| first= John
| last= Tobler
| year= 1992
| title= NME Rock \'N\' Roll Years
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Reed International Books Ltd 
| location= London
| page= 471
| id= CN 5585}}</ref> This also was the year they recorded [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDBUE7ASdNo \'\'"You Can\'t Stop Running Water"\'\'] <ref>Axel, Andy, [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDBUE7ASdNo \'\'You Can\'t Stop Running Water\'\'] </ref> and \'\'"Sons and Daughters"\'\' on their "Brother\'s Keeper" album. 

Their version of \'\'"Bird on a Wire"\'\' was played over the closing credits of the 1990 [[film]], \'\'[[Bird on a Wire (film)|Bird on a Wire]]\'\'.

Due to the health problems of Art Neville, the band kept low profile in the late 1990s onto the early 2000s.  They made a comeback in 2004, however, with the album, \'\'Walkin\' In The Shadow Of Life\'\', from Back Porch Records, their first newly recorded effort in five years.

All brothers except Charles, a Massachusetts resident, had been living in New Orleans, but following [[Hurricane Katrina]] in [[2005 in music|2005]] Cyril and Aaron moved out of the city. They had not been performing in New Orleans since Katrina hit the city, however, they finally returned to perform there at the [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]] in 2008, being given the closing spot which had been reserved for them for years.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/musicNews/idUSGOR58294620071117 Reuters:Neville Bros. return to New Orleans jazz festival]</ref><ref>[http://blog.nola.com/keithspera/2008/05/the_neville_brothers_triumphan.html nola.com:The Neville Brothers\' triumphant Jazzfest return]</ref>

Infrequently, [[Ivan Neville]], Aaron\'s son ([[keyboard instrument|keyboards]]) has played with the band in recent years.

===Studio albums===
* 1978: \'\'The Neville Brothers\'\' (Capitol)
* 1981: \'\'[[Fiyo on the Bayou]]\'\' (A&M)
* 1987: \'\'Uptown\'\' (EMI)
* 1989: \'\'[[Yellow Moon]]\'\' (A&M)
* 1990: \'\'Brother\'s Keeper\'\' (A&M)
* 1992: \'\'Family Groove\'\' (A&M)
* 1995: \'\'Mitakuye Oyasin Oyasin/All My Relations\'\' (A&M)
* 1997: \'\'[[The Carnival]]\'\' (Guest appearance, song "Mona Lisa")
* 1999: \'\'Valence Street\'\' (Columbia)
* 2004: \'\'Walkin\' in the Shadow of Life \'\' (Back Porch).

===Live albums===
* 1984: \'\'[[Neville-ization]]\'\' (Black Top)
* 1987: \'\'Nevillization 2 (Live at Tipitina\'s Volume 2)\'\' (Spindletop)
* 1994: \'\'Live on Planet Earth\'\' (A&M)
* 1998: \'\'Live at Tipitina\'s (1982)\'\' (Rhino)
* 2010: \'\'Authorized Bootleg: Warfield Theatre, San Francisco, CA, February 27, 1989\'\' (A&M)

===Compilation albums===
* 1986: \'\'Treacherous \xe2\x80\x93 A History of The Neville Brothers 1955\xe2\x80\x931985\'\' (Rhino)
* 1991: \'\'Treacherous Too! - A History of the Neville Brothers Volume Two 1955\xe2\x80\x931987\'\' (Rhino)
* 1997: \'\'The Very Best of the Neville Brothers\'\' (Rhino)
* 1999: \'\'Uptown Rulin\' \xe2\x80\x93 The Best of the Neville Brothers\'\' (A&M)
* 2004: \'\'20th Century Masters: The Best of The Neville Brothers\'\' (A&M)
* 2005: \'\'Gold\'\' (Hip-O)
