 ****** The Soul Rebels

b'{{About|the New Orleans band|the album by The Wailers|Soul Rebels}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name                = The Soul Rebels
| image               = Soul_Rebels_in_2012.png
| caption             = in 2012
| landscape           = yes
| background          = group_or_band
| genre               = [[Brass band]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[funk]], [[jazz]], [[R&B]], [[Hip Hop music|hip hop]] 
| origin              = New Orleans, Louisiana, United States 
| years_active        = {{Start date|1991}}\xe2\x80\x93present
| label               = [[Rounder Records]]
| website             = {{URL|thesoulrebels.com}}
| current_members     = Lumar LeBlanc<br/>Derrick Moss<br/>Julian Gosin<br/>Marcus Hubbard<br/>Corey Peyton<br/>Paul Robertson<br/>Erion Williams<br/>Edward Lee Jr.
}}
\'\'\'The Soul Rebels\'\'\' (also \'\'\'Soul Rebels Brass Band\'\'\', \'\'\'Soul Rebels\'\'\' or \'\'\'The Rebels\'\'\') are an eight-piece [[New Orleans]] based brass ensemble that incorporate elements of [[Soul music|soul]], [[jazz]], [[funk]], [[hip hop music|hip-hop]], [[rock music|rock]] and [[pop music]] within a contemporary brass band framework. The band grew from their New Orleans brass style out of original members Lumar LeBlanc and Derrick Moss\xe2\x80\x99s shared desire to play the music they heard on the radio but with respect to the New Orleans brass band tradition.

Starting out as a local New Orleans favorite, The Soul Rebels have evolved into collaborating live with artists including [[Metallica]], [[Green Day]], [[Rakim]], [[Slick Rick]], [[Joey Badass]], [[Trombone Shorty]], [[Pharoahe Monch]], [[Black Thought]] of [[The Roots]], [[Prodigy (rapper)]] of [[Mobb Deep]], [[Big Freedia]], [[The String Cheese Incident]], [[Styles P]] of [[The Lox]], [[Maceo Parker]], [[Galactic]], [[Suzanne Vega]], [[David A. Stewart]] of the [[Eurythmics]], [[Eric Krasno]] and [[John Medeski]] as well as being billed on shows with [[Kanye West]], [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Alabama Shakes]], [[Estelle (musician)|Estelle]], [[Cee Lo Green]], [[The Allman Brothers Band]], [[Arcade Fire]], [[Ice Cube]], [[George Clinton (musician)|George Clinton]], [[Shaggy (musician)]] and others. The band has built its career around an eclectic live show that harnesses the power of horns and percussion in a funky party-like atmosphere. The Soul Rebels have performed on [[CBS]], [[Discovery Channel]], [[HBO]], [[TBS (TV channel)|TBS]], [[NBC]], [[NPR]], [[ESPN]], [[BBC Two]], [[The CW]] and on many major national and international stages.<ref name="Soul Rebels main bio">{{cite web|url=http://soulrebelsbrassband.com/about/|title=Soul Rebels|publisher=Soulrebelsbrassband.com|accessdate=5 April 2012}}</ref>  The band routinely plays over 250 shows a year.

The Soul Rebels have been described by the \'\'[[Village Voice]]\'\' as \xe2\x80\x9cthe missing link between [[Public Enemy (group)|Public Enemy]] and [[Louis Armstrong]].\xe2\x80\x9d<ref name="Soul Rebels Brass Band">{{cite web|title=Soul Rebels Bio|url=http://soulrebelsbrassband.com/unlock-your-mind/|publisher=Soulrebelsbrassband.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

The Soul Rebels consist of percussionists and founding members Lumar LeBlanc and Derrick Moss, trumpet players Julian Gosin and Marcus Hubbard, trombonists Corey Peyton and Paul Robertson, saxophonist Erion Williams, and sousaphonist Edward Lee Jr.

==Early History==
The band first began when percussionists Derrick Moss and Lumar LeBlanc met as members of [[Harold Dejan]]\'s [[Young Olympia Brass Band]] and decided they wanted to play the music they were hearing on pop radio, but within the context and with respect to the long tradition of the New Orleans brass bands and marching bands they had grown up playing in. The Soul Rebels played around New Orleans without a proper band name until opening up for [[Cyril Neville]] at the legendary New Orleans venue [[Tipitina\'s]], where [[Cyril Neville]] dubbed them \xe2\x80\x9cSoul Rebels.\xe2\x80\x9d<ref name=Youtube.com>{{cite web|title=The Soul Rebels: Unlock Your Mind EPK (Extended)|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pIpQh571guA|publisher=Youtube.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>  The Soul Rebels built up their following in hometown New Orleans as the house band every Thursday night at local favorite bar Le Bon Temps Roule, a residency they still continue currently when the band isn\xe2\x80\x99t on tour.<ref name="Gonola.com">{{cite web|title=Soul Rebels at Le Bon Temps Roule|url=http://www.gonola.com/2010/07/05/the-names-says-it-all-at-le-bon-temps-roule.html|publisher=Gonola.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>  The band is still considered a main drawing point for people to come experience the venue.<ref name="Soul Rebels Brass Band">{{cite web|url=http://soulrebelsbrassband.com/unlock-your-mind/|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

Since 2009, The Soul Rebels have been managed by music industry heavyweight Ted Kurland, proprietor of the prestigious booking and management agency Ted Kurland Associates, Adam Shipley, president of Hep Cat Entertainment and Alex Kurland of the Blue Note Entertainment Group.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nola.com/music/index.ssf/2012/01/the_soul_rebels_seek_to_unlock.html |title= The Soul Rebels seek to \'Unlock Your Mind\' |accessdate=2012-07-08 |last= Spera |first= Keith |coauthors= |date= January 27, 2012|publisher=Nola.com}}</ref>

==Collaborations/Milestones==
[[File:The Soul Rebels Brass band playing with Metallica.jpg|thumb|right|The Soul Rebels playing with [[Metallica]] at the Fillmore West in December 2011]]
In December 2011, The Soul Rebels appeared and performed "[[Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)]]" on the [[BBC Two]]\xe2\x80\x99s \'\'[[Later with Jools Holland]]\'\'<ref name="BBC2 Later with Jools Holland">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0178n3x|title=Soul Rebels|publisher=Bbc.co.uk |accessdate=5 April 2012}}</ref>  on the same episode as [[Metallica]] and [[Lou Reed]]. [[Metallica]] was so impressed with the  Soul Rebels that they invited them to open and share the stage for all four of their 30th anniversary-week concerts at [[The Fillmore]] in San Francisco.<ref name="Rolling Stone">{{cite web|last=Fricke|first=David|title=Metallica\'s Star-Studded 30th Anniversary Residency Includes Rarities, Curve Balls|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/blogs/alternate-take/metallicas-star-studded-30th-anniversary-residency-includes-rarities-curve-balls-20111208#ixzz1fyHnsc6z|publisher=Rollinstone.com|accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

[[Metallica]] remain supporters of The Soul Rebels and featured them at both nights of their first [[Metallica]] [[Orion Music + More]] Festival in June 2012. The Soul Rebels are the only band to have played both nights.

When [[Green Day]] performed at the New Orleans Arena in 2009, lead singer [[Billie Joe Armstrong]] invited The Soul Rebels to perform with them.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nola.com/music/index.ssf/2010/02/the_soul_rebels_know_theres_no.html |title= The Soul Rebels know there\'s \'No Place Like Home\' |accessdate=2012-07-09 |last= Spera |first= Keith |coauthors= |date= February 26, 2010 |work= |publisher=Nola.com |pages= |quote= }}</ref>  
In December 2011 in San Francisco at a post-Metallica anniversary after party (The Soul Rebels had performed with Metallica that evening) at the Boom Boom Room, The Soul Rebels jammed once again with [[Green Day]]\xe2\x80\x99s lead singer [[Billie Joe Armstrong]].

On August 15, 2014 [[Joey Badass]] and [[Prodigy (rapper)]] of [[Mobb Deep]] among others, made appearances and performed with The Soul Rebels in New York City at the Brooklyn Bowl venue.

The Soul Rebels collaborated live at the 2014 [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]] with [[Big Freedia]] and [[The String Cheese Incident]].

On March 10, 2012, The Soul Rebels shared the stage with [[Kanye West]], [[Snoop Dogg]] and [[Seal (musician)|Seal]] at [[Brad Pitt]]\xe2\x80\x99s Night to [[Make It Right Foundation New Orleans]] after-party, hosted by comedian [[Aziz Ansari]].<ref name="Night To Make It Right Charity">{{cite web|last=To Make It Right|first=Night|title=Night To Make It Right After Party|url=http://www.nighttomakeitright.com/after-party/|publisher=Nighttomakeitright.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>  The charity event, hosted by [[Ellen DeGeneres]], raised money to build homes for victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nighttomakeitright.com/ |title= A Night To Make It Right |accessdate=2012-07-08 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |work=|publisher=Nighttomakeitright.com}}</ref>

[[Stella McCartney]] invited The Soul Rebels to perform at her 2013 spring fashion presentation hosted at the [[New York Marble Cemetery]] in New York City on June 11, 2012.  Other special guests invited to the very private and exclusive party included [[Anne Hathaway]], [[Jim Carrey]], [[Anna Wintour]], [[Annie Leibovitz]], [[Lauren Hutton]], [[Amy Poehler]] and [[Solange Knowles]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.papermag.com/party_snaps/2012/06/stella-mccartney-hosts-a-carnival-in-honor-of-her-ss-13-collection.php |title= Stella McCartney Hosts a Carnival In Honor of Her S/S \'13 Collection |accessdate=2012-07-09 |last= Schreiber |first= ABBY |coauthors= |date= June 12, 2012 |work= |publisher=Papermag.com}}</ref>

The Soul Rebels collaborated with [[Slick Rick]] and [[Rare Essence]] during a Tribute to [[Chuck Brown]] on June 21, 2012 in Washington DC at the historic [[Howard Theatre]].<ref name="Howard Theatre">{{cite web|title=Soul Rebels at the Howard Theatre|url=http://thehowardtheatre.com/show/2012/06/21/slick-rick/|publisher=Thehowardtheatre.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

On October 19, 2012, The Soul Rebels hosted a [[CMJ]] showcase at the [[Highline Ballroom]] in New York City billed as The Soul Rebels & Friends ft. [[Maceo Parker]], Moon Hooch, American Royalty and Billy Martin of [[Medeski Martin & Wood]].

The Soul Rebels have shared the stage with notable artists from many corners of the pop, hip hop and jazz worlds, including [[Arcade Fire]], [[Cee Lo Green]], [[The Roots]], [[Metallica]], [[Green Day]], [[Kanye West]], [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Seal (musician)|Seal]], [[Juvenile (rapper)|Juvenile]], [[Slick Rick]], [[Alabama Shakes]], [[Maceo Parker]], [[Irma Thomas]], [[Roy Hargrove]], [[Bootsy Collins]], [[Suzanne Vega]], [[Robert Plant]] & [[Jimmy Page]], [[Counting Crows]], [[Drive By Truckers]], Lance Herbstrong, [[Trombone Shorty]], [[Allen Toussaint]], [[David A. Stewart]], [[Chuck Brown]], [[Terence Blanchard]], [[The Gap Band]], [[George Clinton (musician)|George Clinton]], [[Dr. John]], [[Galactic]], [[Better than Ezra]], [[Marco Benevento]], [[Corey Glover]] of [[Living Color]], [[Rare Essence]], [[Leo Nocentelli]] of [[The Meters]], Billy Martin of [[Medeski Martin & Wood]], Moon Hooch, Joey Bada$$ and many others.<ref name="Soul Rebels Brass Band">{{cite web|title=Soul Rebels Bio|url=http://soulrebelsbrassband.com/about/|publisher=Soulrebelsbrassband.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

==Live==
[[File:Soul Rebel at Le Bon Temps Roule.jpg|left|thumb|When not on tour, the band\'s weekly gig at Le Bon Temps Roul\xc3\xa9 in [[Uptown New Orleans]] is a favorite local event]]
The Soul Rebels have toured extensively around the United States, Canada, Europe, South Africa and Brazil and have played at music festivals worldwide including in front of 50,000 people at the 2011 [[Montreal Jazz Festival]].

The Soul Rebels toured North America in 2012 with funk band [[Galactic]] and [[Corey Glover]] of [[Living Colour]] and on March 29, 2012 appeared on the [[Conan O\'Brien]] show on TBS with their tour mates.<ref name="The Social.com">{{cite web|title=Soul Rebels on Conan|url=http://www.thesocial.org/2012/03/27/soul-rebels-on-conan-this-thurs-329/|publisher=NThesocial.org|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

The band has played on stages and festivals all over the world including stops at [[Outside Lands Music and Arts Festival]], [[Austin City Limits]], [[Bonnaroo]], [[Electric Forest Festival]], [[The Fillmore]], [[Hollywood Bowl]], Brooklyn Bowl, [[Terminal 5 (venue)]], [[Jam Cruise]], [[Umbria Jazz Festival]], WOMAD Festival [[World of Music, Arts and Dance]], [[Antibes Jazz Festival]], the [[Wanee Festival]], [[New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival]], [[Playboy Jazz Festival]], [[Montreal Jazz Festival]]<ref name="Montreal Jazz Festival">{{cite web|title=Soul Rebels at Montreal Jazz|url=http://www.montrealjazzfest.com/artists/artist.aspx?id=7546|publisher=Montrealjazzfest.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>  and many others.

When not on tour, the Soul Rebels maintain a weekly residence at the legendary New Orleans club [[Le Bon Temps Roule]] on Thursday nights.<ref name="Gonola.com"/>

==Television/Film Appearances==
In 2014 The Soul Rebels appeared in [[The Originals (TV series)]] on the [[The CW]] network.

On May 12, 2013 The Soul Rebels were featured on [[The Andrew Marr Show]] [[BBC One]]. They performed Michael Jackson\'s "Off The Wall".<ref name="The Andre Marr Show">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22499893 |title=BBC News - Rebels off the wall |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2013-05-12 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

On February 22, 2013 The Soul Rebels were the official house band for the Annual [[NFL]] Honors Award show on [[CBS]] prime time, hosted by [[Alec Baldwin]].  The [[NFL Honors]] is a two-hour prime time awards show presented by the National Football League to salute the best players and plays from the 2012 NFL season. The event was held at the Mahalia Jackson Theater in New Orleans, Louisiana.<ref name="Conan O\'Brien show">{{cite web|last=NFL|first=|title=CELEBRITY PRESENTERS ANNOUNCED FOR "2ND ANNUAL NFL HONORS" |url=http://www.nflcommunications.com/2013/01/29/celebrity-presenters-announced-for-2nd-annual-nfl-honors/ |publisher=Nflcommunicatopns.com|date=7 April 2012}}</ref>

On March 29, 2012, The Soul Rebels appeared on the [[Conan O\'Brien]] show on TBS with tour mates [[Galactic]] and [[Corey Glover]] of [[Living Colour]].<ref name="Conan O\'Brien show">{{cite web|last=Megan|first=Braden-Perry|title=soul rebels conan url=http://www.bestofneworleans.com/blogofneworleans/archives/2012/03/25/galactic-and-soul-rebels-brass-band-to-perform-on-conan-this-thursday|publisher=Bestofneworleans.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

In December 2011, The Soul Rebels appeared on the [[BBC Two]]\'s \'\'[[Later with Jools Holland]]\'\' on the same episode as [[Metallica]] and [[Lou Reed]].

[[HBO]]\xe2\x80\x99s original series \'\'[[Treme (TV series)|Treme]]\'\' featured The Soul Rebels performing \xe2\x80\x9cDrink A Little Poison (4 U Die)\xe2\x80\x9d on the season one finale episode and in season 4 episode two with [[Galactic]] and [[Corey Glover]] of [[Living Colour]] performing "Hey Na Na".<ref name="Home Box Ofice">{{cite web|last=Treme|first=HBO|title=HBO Treme|url=http://www.hbo.com/treme/episodes/1/10-ep-10-ill-fly-away/article/inside-treme.html|publisher=Hbo.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

On October 7, 2012, The Soul Rebels had a featured performance on [[NBC Sunday Night Football]], performing the show\'s theme song.<ref>{{cite web|last=i|first=|title=The Soul Rebels on Sunday Night Football|url=http://madisonhouseinc.com/news/post/soul-rebels-sunday-night-football|publisher=Madisonhouseinc.com|accessdate=5 October 2012}}</ref>

The band performed a New Orleans style [[Jazz funeral]] for the late [[Phil Harris (fisherman)|Captain Phil Harris]] from [[Discovery Channel]]\xe2\x80\x99s show The [[Deadliest Catch]].<ref name="Pompo Bresciani Photagraphy">{{cite web|last=Bresciani|first=Pompo|title=Jazz Funeral|url=http://www.pompo.com/tag/blue-nile-deadliest-catch-filming/|publisher=Pompo.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

On February 24th, 2012, The Soul Rebels were the subject of an [[NPR]] national broadcast of their show with Galactic live from Washington DC\xe2\x80\x99s [[9:30 Club]]. The broadcast was syndicated on NPR and through other affiliates across the United States as well as webcast on NPR.org.<ref name=NPR.org>{{cite web|title=The Soul Rebels in Concert|url=http://www.npr.org/event/music/147352543/the-soul-rebels-in-concert|publisher=Npr.org|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

The band was interviewed and their music was featured in an [[ESPN]] video feature on [[LSU]] cornerback [[Tyrann Mathieu]] entitled Tyrann Mathieu Plays Jazz.<ref name=ESPN.com>{{cite web|title=Tyrann Mathieu Plays Jazz|url=http://search.espn.go.com/tyrann-mathieu/videos/6|publisher=Search.espn.go.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

The Soul Rebels were filmed in a scene for the [[Nicolas Cage]] movie \xe2\x80\x9c[[The Hungry Rabbit Jumps]].\xe2\x80\x9d

==Power = Power Mixtape (2013)==
On December 3, 2013, The Soul Rebels released their \'\'Power = Power\'\' free mixtape. The free download featured studio, live versions and remixes of original material as well as covers of modern day hits by such superstars as [[Jay-Z]], [[Daft Punk]], [[Kanye West]], [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Bruno Mars]]. The single on the mixtape was a remix of [[Daft Punk]]\'s "Get Lucky" featuring Queen of Bounce, [[Big Freedia]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.giantstep.net/index.php/2013/12/new-release-the-soul-rebels-power-power-mixtape/ |title=New Release: The Soul Rebels - \'Power = Power\' Mixtape - GIANT STEP\xe2\x84\xa2 |publisher=Giantstep.net |date=2013-12-03 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> The mixtape won [[OffBeat (music magazine)|Offbeat]]\'s 2013 Best Of The Beat Award for Best Hip-Hop Album/Mixtape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.offbeat.com/2014/01/18/best-of-the-beat-2013-music-awards-winners-announced/ |title=Best Of The Beat 2013 Music Awards Winners Announced |publisher=Offbeat.com |date=2014-01-18 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

"Hearing hip-hop and pop records transposed on live instruments is always a pleasure for avid music fans, and The Soul Rebels are giving the people exactly that on their new \'\'Power = Power\'\' mixtape." - [[Jay-Z]]\'s Life+Times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lifeandtimes.com/the-soul-rebels-discuss-new-power-power-mixtape |title=The Soul Rebels Discuss New "Power = Power" Mixtape &#124; Life+Times |publisher=Lifeandtimes.com |date=2013-12-23 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

"The Soul Rebels, New Orleans\' finest brass ensemble, just dropped their latest mixtape, Power = Power, which Noisey is happy to premiere...This isn\'t your standard wave, but the group\'s music is a funky new way to look some classic hits." -[[Vice]]/Noisey <ref>{{cite web|url=http://noisey.vice.com/blog/premiere-soul-rebels-power-mixtape-rick-ross-listen |title=Stream Soul Rebels New Mixtape \'Power = Power\' & Hang Out with Rick Ross &#124; NOISEY |publisher=Noisey.vice.com |date=2013-12-03 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>
 
"Brace yourselves folks, these men are quickly solidifying themselves amongst NOLA\'s proud big brass elite... and seem intent to sublimate the homogenous tones of the contemporary urban music landscape with the lush instrumentation of our culture\'s root." - [[Okayplayer]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.okayplayer.com/news/the-soul-rebels-power-mixtape-behind-the-scenes-video.html |title=The Soul Rebels Drop \'Power = Power\' Mixtape Okayplayer |publisher=Okayplayer.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>
 
"The Soul Rebels are rebelling against one, albeit detestable thing: starchy paint-by-numbers music. As the New Orleans collective gears up to release their eclectic \'\'Power = Power\'\' mixtape on December 3 as a free download, the eight-member band has dropped a few aural treats along the way...Somewhere between Cypress Hill, Brand Nubian and Miles Davis, The Soul Rebels are filling the gaps. Power = Power features studio recordings, live versions and remixes of original works, making for a colorful musical mishmash, in which a hint of NOLA brass flair can always be found." -[[Vibe (magazine)]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/premiere-download-soul-rebels-504-miim-remix |title=Premiere: Download The Soul Rebels "504" (MiiM Remix) |publisher=Vibe |date=2013-11-20 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

==Unlock Your Mind (Rounder Records 2012)==
[[File:Soul Rebels With Metallica at the Fillmore.jpg|thumb|Actor [[Seth Rogen]] holding up a copy of the "Unlock Your Mind" CD and hanging out with The Soul Rebels at Le Bon Temps Roule in 2012]]
The band released several albums under various independent record labels before signing with [[Rounder Records]] ([[Concord Records|Concord]]) in 2011. The band released their full length Rounder debut, Unlock Your Mind on January 31, 2012, produced by [[Scott Billington]]. The album features special guests [[Trombone Shorty]], [[Cyril Neville]], [[Ben Ellman]] of [[Galactic]] and others.  Unlock Your Mind was received to universally positive reviews. Elias Leight from [[Popmatters]] praised the album as \xe2\x80\x9ca testimony to the power of horns--in all their squawking, tooting, screaming glory--and a vibrant concoction of different types of music.\xe2\x80\x9d Daryl Easlea from [[BBC Music]] said in support, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is a full-on, joyous, positive album that makes you feel like celebrating.\xe2\x80\x9d

The album reached No.&nbsp;5 on [[iTunes]] Jazz charts and was the No.&nbsp;1 most added album on [[CMJ]] magazine\xe2\x80\x99s Hip-Hop playlists.<ref name=Nola.com>{{cite web|title=Soul Rebels Seek To Unlock Your Mind|url=http://www.nola.com/music/index.ssf/2012/01/the_soul_rebels_seek_to_unlock.html|publisher=Nola.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

==Critical Reception==
The Soul Rebels have been described by Village Voice as \xe2\x80\x9cthe missing link between Public Enemy and Louis Armstrong.\xe2\x80\x9d<ref name="Soul Rebels Brass Band"/>

[[Paste (magazine)]] ranked The Soul Rebels in the Top 10 Best Moments of [[Bonnaroo]] 2012. Other bands in the top 10 ranking included [[Phish]], [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], [[Radiohead]], [[The Roots]] with [[D\'Angelo]] and [[The Beach Boys]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/lists/2012/06/the-10-best-moments-of-bonnaroo-2012.html|title= The 10 Best Moments of Bonnaroo 2012 |accessdate=2012-07-08 |last= Hughes |first= Linda |coauthors= |date= June 11, 2012 |work= |publisher=Pastemagazine.com |pages= |quote= }}</ref>

The Soul Rebels catalog of albums has been received well by critics, their best-reviewed album being their latest, Unlock Your Mind. The album reached No.&nbsp;5 on [[iTunes]] Jazz charts and was the No.&nbsp;1 most added album on [[CMJ]] magazine\xe2\x80\x99s Hip-Hop playlists.

==Awards==
The Soul Rebels won Best Rap or Hip-Hop Album/Mixtape at the 2013 Off Beat Awards and nominated for Best Of The Beat: Off Beat Awards in 2013, 2012, 2011, 2010, 2009 and in 2008.

In 2012, The Soul Rebels were nominated for four 2012 Best Of The Beat Awards; Best Artist Of The Year, Best Album Of The Year, Best Brass Band Of The Year and Best Brass Band Album Of The Year.  They won Best Brass Band Album Of The Year.

The Soul Rebels won New Orleans\xe2\x80\x99 [[Big Easy award]] in 2010, 2008 and in 1999 as well as nominations in 2012, 2011 and in 2009.<ref name=Bestofneworleans.com>{{cite web|title=Big Easy Awards|url=http://www.bestofneworleans.com/gambit/2010-big-easy-entertainment-award-winners/Content?oid=1278624|publisher=Bestofneworleans.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>

==Discography==
*1995 \xe2\x80\x93 Let Your Mind Be Free [Mardi Gras Records]
*1998 \xe2\x80\x93 No More Parades  [Tuf America Records]
*1999 \xe2\x80\x93 More Jams from No More Parades [Tuf America Records]
*2004 \xe2\x80\x93 Rebelution [Barn Burner Music]
*2006 \xe2\x80\x93 Urban Legend [Barn Burner Music]
*2009 \xe2\x80\x93 No Place Like Home: Live in New Orleans [Independent]
*2012 \xe2\x80\x93 Unlock Your Mind [Rounder Records]

 ****** Sound Experience

b"'''Sound Experience''' was an [[United States|American]] [[funk]] ensemble, founded at [[Morgan State College]] in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] in 1970.<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p202142/biography|pure_url=yes}} Billboard], [[Allmusic]]</ref>

The group played locally and recorded with producer [[Stan Watson]], recording with him in [[Philadelphia]]. They recorded several singles and one full-length album in 1974, ''Don't Fight the Feeling''; this album reached #57 on the ''Billboard'' R&B Albums chart.<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p202142/charts-awards|pure_url=yes}} Billboard], [[Allmusic]]</ref> The title track was released as a single and reached #61 on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]].<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p202142/charts-awards/billboard-singles|pure_url=yes}} Singles], [[Allmusic]]</ref>

The ensemble recorded little thereafter, but have been [[sampling (music)|sampled]] by [[hip hop]] groups. [[Collectables Records]] issued a CD retrospective of the group's output in 1994.

==Members==
*Arthur Grant
*Linwood Fraling
*Leroy Fraling
*Melvin Miles
*Reginald Wright
*Johnny Foreman
*Gregory Holmes
*Albert Holmes
*James Lindsey
*Anton Scott
*Everett Harris
*Rodney Parks

==References==

[[Category:Musical groups from Maryland]]
[[Category:American funk musical groups]]"

 ****** The S.O.S. Band

b'{{Infobox musical artist
|name            = The S.O.S. Band
|background      = group_or_band
|image             =
|caption        =
|alias           = Santa Monica
|origin          = [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States|U.S.]]
|genre           = [[Disco]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Boogie (genre)|boogie]], [[Urban contemporary|urban]]
|years_active    = 1977\xe2\x80\x93present
|label           = [[Tabu Records|Tabu]]
|associated_acts = [[Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis]]<br>[[Alexander O\'Neal]]<br>[[Cherrelle]]<br>[[Kurupt]] 
|website             =
|current_members = Mary Davis<br/>Abdul Ra\'oof<br/>Jason Bryant
|past_members    = Billy Ellis<br/>James Earl Jones III<br/>Willie "Sonny" Killebrew<br/>John Simpson<br/>Bruno Speight<br/> [[Chandra Currelley-Young|Chandra Currelley]]
|notable_instruments = [[Roland TR-808]]
}}

\'\'\'The S.O.S. Band\'\'\' (sometimes written \'\'\'SOS Band\'\'\'; abbreviation for \'\'\'Sounds Of Success\'\'\') is an American [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[Boogie (genre)|electro-funk]] [[musical ensemble|group]] who gained fame in the 1980s. They are best known for the songs "[[Take Your Time (Do It Right)]]," "[[Just Be Good to Me]]," "Tell Me If You Still Care," and "[[The Finest (song)|The Finest]]."

==History==
The band was founded in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in 1977. The original group members included Willie "Sonny" Killebrew (saxophone), Billy Ellis (flute), Jason "T.C." Bryant (keyboards), Bruno Speight (guitar), John Simpson (bass), James Earl Jones III (drums), and Mary Davis (lead vocals, keyboards).<ref>{{cite web|title=The S.O.S. Band - Bio|url=http://artistecard.com/thesosband|website=artistecard.com|publisher=artistecard.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Evolution Of The SOS Band|url=http://www.bet.com/shows/bet-honors/2013/photos/performers/evolution-of-the-sos-band1.html#!010913-shows-bet-honors-the-evolution-of-SOS-Band-funk-a-palooza|website=bet.com|publisher=Black Entertainment Television|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref> It was originally known as Santa Monica,<ref>{{cite web|title=The S.O.S. Band - Bio|url=http://artistecard.com/thesosband|website=artistecard.com|publisher=artistecard.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref> but later changed its name to The S.O.S. Band- an [[acronym]] for Sounds of Success.<ref>{{cite web|title=The S.O.S. Band - Bio|url=http://artistecard.com/thesosband|website=artistecard.com|publisher=artistecard.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Evolution Of The SOS Band|url=http://www.bet.com/shows/bet-honors/2013/photos/performers/evolution-of-the-sos-band1.html#!010913-shows-bet-honors-the-evolution-of-SOS-Band-funk-a-palooza|website=bet.com|publisher=Black Entertainment Television|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Lindsey|first1=Craig D.|title=S.O.S. Band brings the funk to Raleigh|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/12/11/4393016/sos-band-brings-the-funk-to-raleigh.html|website=newsobserver.com|publisher=News Observer|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref> After listening to its demo and being impressed with their sound, [[Tabu Records]] founder [[Clarence Avant]] signed the group to its first recording contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=The S.O.S. Band - Bio|url=http://artistecard.com/thesosband|website=artistecard.com|publisher=artistecard.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref>

In 1980, the group released its first hit single, "[[Take Your Time (Do It Right)]]", which was certified [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] and sold over 2 million copies. Its debut album, \'\'[[S.O.S. (S.O.S. Band album)|S.O.S.]]\'\', went [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] and sold over 800,000 copies. Trumpeter, vocalist, and percussionist Abdul Ra\'oof joined the band while it was on a world tour.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Evolution Of The SOS Band|url=http://www.bet.com/shows/bet-honors/2013/photos/performers/evolution-of-the-sos-band1.html#!010913-shows-bet-honors-the-evolution-of-SOS-Band-funk-a-palooza|website=bet.com|publisher=Black Entertainment Television|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref>

In 1983, the band joined forces with then-new [[record producer|production]] team of [[Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis]], who went on to craft a string of [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] hits for the group, which included "[[Just Be Good to Me]]," "[[High Hopes (The SOS Band song)|High Hopes]]," "Tell Me If You Still Care," "Borrowed Love," "No One\'s Gonna Love You," "Just the Way You Like It," and "The Finest."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Evolution Of The SOS Band|url=http://www.bet.com/shows/bet-honors/2013/photos/performers/evolution-of-the-sos-band1.html#!010913-shows-bet-honors-the-evolution-of-SOS-Band-funk-a-palooza|website=bet.com|publisher=Black Entertainment Television|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref>

Lead vocalist Mary Davis left the group in 1987 to pursue a [[solo (music)|solo]] career, and was replaced by Chandra Currelley beginning with the band\'s 1989 \'\'Diamonds in the Raw\'\' album.<ref>{{cite web|title=The S.O.S. Band - Bio|url=http://artistecard.com/thesosband|website=artistecard.com|publisher=artistecard.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Evolution Of The SOS Band|url=http://www.bet.com/shows/bet-honors/2013/photos/performers/evolution-of-the-sos-band1.html#!010913-shows-bet-honors-the-evolution-of-SOS-Band-funk-a-palooza|website=bet.com|publisher=Black Entertainment Television|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref> They recorded another album with Currelley - 1991\'s \'\'One of Many Nights\'\', which featured a few songs with a guest appearance from a then-unknown [[Kurupt]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Weinstein|first1=Max|title=The Definition: Kurupt\xe2\x80\x99s 20 Best Guest Verses Ever|url=http://watchloud.com/the-definition-kurupts-20-best-guest-verses/|website=watchloud.com|publisher=Watch Loud|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref>

More recently, Currelley has been active as an [[actress]] and vocalist in [[Tyler Perry]] [[play (theatre)|plays]] and [[film]]s.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Townes|first1=Khalif|title=Interview: Chandra Currelley-Young Talks "Madea Gets A Job" Stageplay, Working w/ Tyler Perry, & Future Projects|url=http://ugospel.com/interview-chandra-currelley-young-talks-madea-gets-a-job-stageplay-working-w-tyler-perry-future-projects/|website=ugospel.com|publisher=uGospel|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref> When Davis\xe2\x80\x99s solo career was not as successful as she hoped, she reunited with the band in 1994. Since then, Davis spilt from the remaining members of The S.O.S. Band, with Davis and Speight both touring using the band\'s name with their versions of the current lineup.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lindsey|first1=Craig D.|title=S.O.S. Band brings the funk to Raleigh|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/12/11/4393016/sos-band-brings-the-funk-to-raleigh.html|website=newsobserver.com|publisher=News Observer|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref>

In 2013, The S.O.S. Band\'s entire Tabu Records catalog was reissued, as Tabu licensed their brand and trademark to British based record label [[Demon Music Group]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The S.O.S. Band|url=http://www.demonmusicgroup.co.uk/catalogue/artists/the-s-o-s-band-2/|website=demonmusicgroup.co.uk|publisher=Demon Music Group|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref>

==Discography==
\'\'All albums and singles listed below were issued on [[Tabu Records]].\'\'

 ****** Speak Low (band)

b'{{Infobox musical artist
    | name           = Speak Low
    | background     = group_or_band
    | origin         = [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]
    | genre          = [[Funk]], [[jazz-funk]]
    | years_active   = 2002&ndash;2011
    | label          = [[Acid Jazz Records|
                Acid Jazz]], [[Funkorama Records|
                               Funkorama]], {{nowrap| [[Lovemonk| Lovemonk (Mono)]]}}
    | website        = {{url| http://MySpace.com/SpeakLowFunk| MySpace.com/SpeakLowFunk}}
    | current_members= 
* Juli\xc3\xa1n Maeso
* Jose "Funko" Garc\xc3\xada
* Antonio "Pax" \xc3\x81lvarez
* David "el Indio" Garc\xc3\xada
* Mart\xc3\xadn Garc\xc3\xada
}}
\'\'\'Speak Low\'\'\' were a Spanish funk combo based in [[Madrid]], that formed in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://acidjazz.co.uk/artist/speak-low.html |title=Artists |publisher=Acid Jazz |date= |accessdate=2014-08-27}}</ref> The band was founded by Julian Maeso, Jose Garc\xc3\xada and Antonio Pax. They have released two albums, and five singles. The band was influenced by [[Lonnie Smith (jazz musician)|Lonnie Smith]], [[Brian Auger]], [[Georgie Fame]], [[Lou Donaldson]] and [[The Meters]]. The band split up in 2011, their farewell concert being only in 2012 on the Moe Black Music Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lovemonk.net/goodbye-speak-low-hello-dead-capo/ |title=Goodbye Speak Low. Hello Dead Capo |publisher=Lovemonk |date=2012-03-14 |accessdate=2014-08-27}}</ref>

== History ==
\'\'\'Speak Low\'\'\' was formed in late 2002 by Julian Maeso (of [[:es:The Sunday Drivers|The Sunday Drivers]]), Antonio Pax (of [[:es:La Vacazul|La Vacazul]]) and Jose Funko (of \'\'Mamafunko\'\') to play covers of classic jazz-funk, soul and boogaloo in local clubs. Later Mart\xc3\xadn and David Garc\xc3\xada would join and original compositions start to emerge. In 2003 they recorded a demo of three songs. Later, during the summer of 2004 the band recorded ten original songs, published in the spring of 2006 under the title \'\'I\'m Gonna Groove Ya\'\'.

==Discography==
===Albums===
* \'\'I\'m Gonna Groove Ya!!\'\' (2006, Lovemonk|Mono)
* \'\'Hands Up\'\' (2009)

===Singles and EPs===
* "Take Your Time" / "Papa Don\'t Take No Mess" (2005)
* \'\'Trouble Maker\'\' (2006)
* \'\'Thriller\'\' (2006)
* "I Want My Money Back" / "This Letter" (2009)
* "Soul Is What You Got" / "I Don\'t Need No What" (2009)

{{Spain-band-stub}}'

 ****** Stonefunkers

b'{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name            = The Stonefunkers
| background      = group_or_band
| alias           =
| origin          = [[Sweden]]
| genre           = [[Funk]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]]
| years_active    = 1987\xe2\x80\x932001<br />2009-
| label           =
| associated_acts = [[Papa Dee]]
| current_members = M-Rock<br />Top-Steen<br />ADL<br />Davono<br />Conan<br />Cheezo<br />[[Jean-Louis Huhta]]<br />Storm<br />Gonzo
| past_members    = [[Papa Dee]]<br />MC Cane<br />Frenzy Jay/Frans James<br />Gavin Smart<br />Peter Towers
}}

\'\'\'Stonefunkers\'\'\' is a [[Swedish people|Swedish]] [[funk]], [[go-go]] and live [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] band started by brothers Emrik and Torsten Larsson that was one of the first Swedish bands to play "urban"-style music.<ref name=SvD>[http://www.svd.se/kulturnoje/nyheter/stonefunkers-aterupptar-festandet_2676501.svd "Stonefunkers \xc3\xa5terupptar festandet",] \'\'SvD\'\' 31 March 2009. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref>

==Career==
Both Larssons spent a year in the USA studying American culture and also picking up on the Soul and funk scene.<ref name=Emrik>[http://www.emrik.nu/visa.lasso?mall=popupsangtext.lasso&kat_id=&ukat_id=&poster_id=8000000000030175 Emrik Larsson] at stonefunkers.com. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref>

Emrik went to high school in [[Rochester, New York]] and soon found out that a lot of the hot bands usually stopped to play in Rochester. During his year he got to see artists ranging from [[George Clinton (musician)|George Clinton]] with [[Parliament (band)|Parliament]], [[D Train (music group)|D-Train]], [[Tyrone Brunson (musician)|Tyrone Brunson]], to [[Slave (band)|Slave]] and [[Steve Arrington]] and also witnessed his first hip hop performance by [[Double Trouble (band)|Double Trouble]] (known through the hip hop movie \'\'[[Wild Style]]\'\').<ref name=Bio>[http://www.stonefunkers.com/visa.lasso?ukat_id=8000000000039991&kat_id=84500000000012190&kunder_id=8000000000000680&mall=1-spalt.lasso Stonefunkers biography - 1998] at stonefunkers.com. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref><ref name=Karas>Tatiana Karas, [http://www.musiklandet.se/ml/index.nsf/1?Open&a=kr&id=2357C7136A67F646C125736E00578CE3 "I\'m a Stonefunker, yes I am".] Interview with Emrik Larsson at musiklandet.se, 18 November 2007. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref>

Torsten went to [[Minneapolis]] and soon got into the rock scene but couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get away from [[Minneapolis sound|that cities movement powerful funk movement]] led by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[The Time (band)|The Time]], [[Andr\xc3\xa9 Cymone]] and others.<ref name=Emrik/>

Back in Sweden they both felt the urge to start a funk band. Torsten had previously played the bass in various [[Punk rock|punk]]/rock bands, and Emrik had done some singing in different choirs and also had a leading part in a musical.<ref name=Bio/>

They recruited their old [[skateboard]] pal Christian on drums, a neighbour on bass, Emrik\xe2\x80\x99s friend David on Moog and Prophet synthesizers, and Torsten switched to [[guitar]].
Torsten came up with the name during a skate session.<ref name=Emrik/><ref name=Karas/>

In 1987 they became the first Swedish band to be interviewed on the Swedish radio show Soul Corner, a radio program covering African-American music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sydsvenskan.se/kultur-och-nojen/article32259/Svart-musik-pa-skanska.html |title=Svart musik p\xc3\xa5 sk\xc3\xa5nska - Kultur & N\xc3\xb6jen - Sydsvenskan - Nyheter dygnet runt |publisher=Sydsvenskan.se |date=2005-04-22 |accessdate=2010-03-25}}</ref>

The early Stonefunk sound was guitar-driven rock funk influenced by [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Rose Royce]] and [[Sly Stone]]. In 1987 they were considered one of [[Gothenburg]]\xe2\x80\x99s most energetic and exciting live bands and they recorded their first single, "Turn it Up", released in May 1988 on small indie label Radium.<ref name=Bio/>

In autumn 1989 they started to work on their first full-length album, \'\'Hard as Kryptonite\'\', with producer [[Christian Falk]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Stefan Malmqvist |url=http://www.svd.se/kulturnoje/nyheter/christian-falk-tar-ton-pa-nya-skivan_359188.svd |title=Christian Falk tar ton p\xc3\xa5 nya skivan &#124; Kulturnyheter &#124; SvD |language=sv |publisher=Svd.se |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010-03-25}}</ref> (later known for his work with [[Neneh Cherry]], \'\'Blacknuss all-stars\'\' and [[Robyn]]). During the recording of the album, the group was joined by [[Deejay (Jamaican)|toasting]]style-rapper [[Papa Dee]], who brought in more evident [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] influences than there were on the two previous singles.<ref>"Inget Snack om Saken, nu \xc3\xa4r Papa Dee en av de Tunga!", \'\'Frontface magazine\'\' issue 3 2008, [http://www.frontface.se/2008_03/02sid/02a.htm p. 2a]. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref> Drummer & percussion player [[Jean-Louis Huhta]]<ref name="wordpress1">Fredrik Strage, [http://popviminns.wordpress.com/2010/01/04/jean-louis-huhta/ "Jean-Louis Huhta",] \'\'Tidskriften Pop Revisited\'\' 4 January 2010. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref> also joined the band at this time, which resulted in more inspirations from the [[go-go]] of [[Washington D.C.]] (groups like [[Trouble Funk]] and [[Experience Unlimited|E.U.]]).<ref name=Emrik/>

Stonefunkers lineup 1989:
*Vocals - Emrik (M-rock) Larsson,
*Guitar - Torsten (Topsteen) Larsson,
*Moog - David (Davono) Selvert
*Drums - Christian (Cheeze) Ekerfors
*Percussion - [[Jean-Louis Huhta]]
*Rap - Daniel ([[Papa Dee]]) Wahlgren
*Bass - Magnus (Conan) Corneliusson.

In 1990 the group switched labels to [[Warner Music Group|Warner]], who decided to [[remix]] \'\'Hard as Kryptonite\'\' for an international release entitled \'\'Harder than Kryptonite\'\'. This remixed version of the album had a jazz-hip hop/[[Native Tongues]] direction and new added rap verses. [[Papa Dee]] also left the band and embarked on a solo career. The band decided to recruit rapper \'\'MC Cane\'\' (Marc Eastmond), with whom they recorded a brand new [[De La Soul]]-inspired new single entitled "Can U Follow". The song became a huge dance-floor hit and the video was shown on [[MTV]] Europe on a regular basis. The album \'\'Harder than Kryptonite\'\' was released all around Europe in 1991 and Stonefunkers also embarked on their first European tour, visiting the Nordic countries and Germany.<ref name=Bio/>

With \'\'MC Cane\'\' still the main rapper the band recorded the  12" singel \'\'LPC ([[Lucky People Center]])\'\', a celebration of percussionist [[Jean-Louis Huhta]] club nights <ref name="wordpress1"/> of the same name. The actual [[Lucky People Center|club]] featured [[Ambient house]]/[[Trance music|Trance]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Lucky+People+Center |title=Lucky People Center Discography at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date=2002-10-30 |accessdate=2010-03-25}}</ref> genres of music but this single was yet another [[Native Tongues]] inspired [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] track. The single was a hit on Swedish radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.learning4sharing.nu/stonefunkers-189443.html |title=Vad \xc3\xa4r Stonefunkers? |publisher=Learning4sharing.nu |date=2009-05-26 |accessdate=2010-03-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://www.swedishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Stonefunkers |title=Discography Stonefunkers |publisher=swedishcharts.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-25}}</ref>

In 1992 they started to work on their next album with producer [[Henryk Lipp]]. By this time MC Cane had left for a career in [[graphic design]], and today works for one of Sweden\xe2\x80\x99s most prestigious and award winning advertising agencies, Forsman & Bodenfors.<ref name=Emrik/><ref>Fredrik Hansson, [http://www.resume.se/manadens_kampanj/manadens_print/oktober-2007/index.xml?_id=2016&_type=Print "M\xc3\xa5nadens print"], resume.se October 2007, 6 December 2007. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.fb.se/en/Pages/12 Forsman & Bodenfors Contact page]. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref> The band got a new rapper, [[ADL (rapper)|ADL]],<ref>[http://www.presskontakt.se/pressreleaser/visa/pressrelease/112083/ "Stonefunkers 2010 Nedr\xc3\xa4kningen har b\xc3\xb6rjat!"], presskontakt.se 12 May 2009. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref> brother of percussionist [[Jean-Louis Huhta]]. ADL had previously appeared in the videos for \'\'Bass Race\'\' and \'\'Can U Follow\'\' and added rap verses on two of the tracks on the \'\'Harder than Kryptonite\'\' remixes album. The album \'\'No problem \xe2\x80\x9994 (non-believers stand back!)\'\' was a huge hit in the spring of \xe2\x80\x9993 and spawned two big hit singles, "M-rock theory" and "Funkadeena".<ref name=Emrik/>

The recording stint with Warner came to an end in 1994 and Stonefunkers were signed to [[Stockholm Records]] subsidiary Breakin\xe2\x80\x99 Bread. They recorded the next album in [[Haarlem]], the [[Netherlands]] and also toured the [[Benelux]] countries extensively.<ref name=Bio/> The effort made in the Netherlands came out in the form of a \'\'Material\'\'-heavy [[P-funk]]-influenced album. The album contained the singles "Wreck the show" and "Individuality" but never made an impact in [[Sweden]]. The response to the album was greater abroad and Stonefunkers embarked on yet another tour that took them to [[Austria]], [[Switzerland]] and other countries.<ref name=Emrik/>

In 1996 ADL left the band to work on his solo project \'\'Absent Minded\'\',<ref>[http://www.shell.linux.se/popoga/a/a00023.html ADL, Absent-Minded]</ref> and the band decided to continue without a rapper and instead put more focus on the vocals of lead singer Emrik \xe2\x80\x9dM-rock\xe2\x80\x9d Larsson.<ref name=Bio/> In 1998 Stonefunkers signed a deal with Swedish label Independent Records and immediately began putting down tracks for the new album. Band member Torsten served as the project\'s producer and the album \'\'Outststanding\'\'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wwwc.aftonbladet.se/puls/musik/cd981016.html |title=Aftonbladet puls: Veckans cd-recensioner |publisher=.aftonbladet.se |date=1997-12-05 |accessdate=2010-03-25}}</ref> was finished in August 1998.<ref name=Bio/>

===Breakup and solo work===
Torsten Larsson says, "The Poland tour around 95-96 have been our absolute low point, just a guitar, a bassynt, drums and tons of alcohol!"<ref>[http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/view/pressrelease/stonefunkers-2010-281947 Stonefunkers 2010] at mynesdesk.com, Torsten Larsson Musik AB, 24 March 2009. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref> After a few key members left and a disastrous argument about the lack of sales, the group broke up. The band officially disbanded in 2001, but performed live for the last time in 1999.<ref name=SvD/><ref>Kal Str\xc3\xb6m, [http://dagensskiva.com/2001/03/21/stonefunkers-finns-inte-mer/ "Stonefunkers finns inte mer"] at dagensskiva.com, 21 March 2001, accessed 21 March 2010: "Efter n\xc3\xa4stan femton \xc3\xa5r l\xc3\xa4gger Sveriges mest k\xc3\xa4nda funkare, Stonefunkers, av som band". - "After almost fifteen years Sweden\'s best known funkers, Stonefunkers, are calling it quits as a band".</ref>

Guitar player and leader of the group, Torsten "Topsteen" Larsson, would go on and  become a successful sound engineer and producer and in following years would work with such acts as [[Roxette]], [[Olle Ljungstr\xc3\xb6m]],.<ref name="SvD"/> [[The Royal Beat Conspiracy]]<ref>H\xc3\xa5kan Steen, [http://wwwc.aftonbladet.se/puls/9906/11/royal.html "Vi f\xc3\xb6r facklan vidare: The Royal Beat Conspiracy v\xc3\xa5rdar rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll-arvet p\xc3\xa5 debutplattan",] \'\'Aftonbladet\'\' Puls 11 June 1999. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref> and [[The Soundtrack of our Lives]].

M-Rock/Emrik would record three solo albums experimenting with [[Punk rock|punk]], [[soul music]], [[Folk music|folk]] and [[singer songwriter]] styles of music.<ref>Malena Rydell, [http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/skivrecensioner/emrik-soul-swedish-man-1.749611 "Emrik: \'Soul Swedish Man\'"], DN Kultur & N\xc3\xb6je 21 May 2008. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.blaskan.nu/blaskan/Nummer69/Musik/emrik_friska_viljor.html Soul/blues/rock: Emrik \xe2\x80\x94 Soul Swedish Man; Friska Viljor \xe2\x80\x94 Tour de Hearts"], Blaskan 2, 2008. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref><ref>[http://dagensskiva.com/2008/05/10/emrik-soul-swedish-man/ "Soulblues f\xc3\xb6r medel\xc3\xa5ldern"], Review of Emrik\'s \'\'Soul Swedish Man\'\' at dagensskiva.com, 10 May 2008. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref>
In 2000, he and a few other members of the stonefunk crew contribute to the compilation album \'\'GAIS Rocks Da House\'\' in support of the football club [[GAIS]] under the name \'\'Stenkross\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dagensskiva.com/2000/05/23/gais-rocks-da-house/ |title=GAIS "Rocks Da House" |publisher=dagensskiva.com |date=1969-08-08 |accessdate=2010-03-25}}</ref>

===Reformation===
In 2009 the band reformed and embarked on a short [[Sweden|Swedish]] tour with yet another series of concerts lined up for the summer of 2010, starting with a gig [[Stockholm]], April 23.<ref>Kai Martin, [http://gt.expressen.se/nyheter/1.1511840/comeback-for-stonefunkers "Comeback f\xc3\xb6r Stonefunkers",] \'\'Expressen\'\' GT 26 March 2009. Retrieved 21 March 2010.</ref>
<ref>[http://www.fasching.se/program.php?visa=824 "Stonefunkers @ Fasching",] \'\'Fasching.se\'.\' Retrieved 25 March 2010.</ref>

The current members are:

*Vocals and rap - M-Rock(Emrik Larsson)
*Guitarr - Top-Steen (Torsten Larsson)
*Rap - ADL
*Keyboards - Davono
*Bass - Conan
*Percussion - Cheezo
*Percussion - [[Jean-Louis Huhta]]
*Percussion - Storm
*Percussion - Gonzo

==Trivia==
In 2010, Spanish band \'\'La calle del ritmo\'\' covered the track \'\'Can U Follow\'\'.
<ref>[http://www.diariodelaltoaragon.es/NoticiasDetalle.aspx?Id=621842" La calle del ritmo",] \'\'www.diariodelaltoaragon.es\'.\' Retrieved 25 March 2010.</ref>

==Albums==
* \'\'Hard as Kryptonite\'\' (1989)
* \'\'Harder than Kryptonite\'\' (1991)
* \'\'No problem 94 - Non-believers stand back!\'\' (1993)
* \'\'Material\'\' (1995)
* \'\'Outstanding\'\' (1998)

[[Category:Swedish rappers]]
