* [[Q-Tip (musician)|Q-Tip]]
* [[Kelis]]
* [[Daft Punk]]
}}
| website = {{URL|pharrellwilliams.com}}
}}

\'\'\'Pharrell Williams\'\'\' (born April 5, 1973), also known by his mononym \'\'\'Pharrell\'\'\' ({{IPAc-en|f|\xc9\x99|\xcb\x88|r|\xc9\x9b|l}}), is an American singer-songwriter, [[Rapping|rapper]], record producer, and fashion designer.  Williams and [[Chad Hugo]] make up the record production duo [[the Neptunes]], producing [[Soul music|soul]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] music. He is also the lead vocalist and drummer of rock, funk, and hip hop band [[N.E.R.D|N*E*R*D]], which he formed with Hugo and childhood friend [[Shay Haley]]. He released his first single "[[Frontin\']]" in 2003 and followed up with his debut solo album \'\'[[In My Mind (Pharrell album)|In My Mind]]\'\' in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/artists/149f91ef-1287-46da-9a8e-87fee02f1471|title=BBC|accessdate=December 11, 2011}}</ref> His second album, \'\'[[Girl (Pharrell Williams album)|Girl]]\'\', was released on March 3, 2014.<ref name="second album"/><ref name="iTunes GIRL US">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/g-i-r-l/id823593445 |title=G I R L by Pharrell Williams |publisher=[[iTunes]] |accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref>

As part of the Neptunes, Williams has produced numerous hit singles for [[The Neptunes production discography|various recording artists]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/music/la-et-nerd-01jun01,0,7745056.story|title=LA Times|accessdate=December 11, 2011 | work=Los Angeles Times|first=Chris|last=Lee|date=June 1, 2008}}</ref> Williams has earned eleven [[Grammy Award]]s including two with the Neptunes. He currently owns a media venture that encompasses entertainment, music, fashion, and art called [[i am OTHER]], a multimedia creative collective and record label that serves as an umbrella for all of Pharrell Williams\' endeavors, including [[Billionaire Boys Club (clothing retailer)|Billionaire Boys Club]] and [[Billionaire Boys Club (clothing retailer)|Ice Cream]] apparel, Billionaire Girls Club, textile company [[Return Textiles|Bionic Yarn]] and a dedicated YouTube channel launched in 2012. The channel was launched on May 12, 2012 as part of YouTube\'s $100 million [[YouTube Original Channel Initiative|original channel initiative]].

==Early life==
Pharrell Williams was born on April 5, 1973, in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]],<ref name="Allmusic">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p281403|pure_url=yes}}|title=Pharrell Williams \xe2\x80\x93 Overview|last=Kellman|first=Andy|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref><ref name="The Guardian">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2005/nov/06/popandrock.pharrellwilliams|title=Just Williams|last=Bainbridge|first=Luke|date=November 5, 2005|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=2008-12-13|location=London}}</ref> the oldest of three sons of {{sic|Pharaoh|hide=yes}} Williams, a handyman, and his wife Carolyn, a teacher.<ref>{{cite web|date=October 13, 2003|title=Pharrell Williams|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time]]|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20148349,00.html|accessdate=2008-11-28}}</ref> His roots extend for generations in Virginia and North Carolina, and one of his ancestors journeyed to West Africa in 1831, prompting other relatives to emigrate from America to Liberia in 1832.<ref>{{cite web|date=September 2014|title=Why Pharrell Almost Didn\'t Exist|work=Megan Smolenyak\'s Blog|url=http://megansmolenyak.com/pharrell/|accessdate=2014-09-08}}</ref> He met [[Chad Hugo]] in a seventh-grade summer band camp where Williams played the keyboards and drums and Hugo played [[tenor saxophone]]. They were also both members of a [[marching band]]; Williams played the [[snare drum]] while Hugo was drum major.<ref name="Age">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/05/12/1084289744331.html|title=Like the song? These guys wrote it|last=Campbell|first=Melissa|date=May 15, 2004|work=[[The Age]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=2007-05-22|location=Melbourne}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E7D9143BF93BA35751C0A9629C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all|title=Style; The Sound|last=Frere-Jones|first=Sasha|date=February 8, 2004|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> Williams attended [[Princess Anne High School]] where he played in the school band; there he got the name Skateboard P.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/feb/08/entertainment/ca-shiver8|title=Virginia is for hip-hop lovers|last=Shiver Jr.|first=Jube|date=February 8, 2004|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> Hugo attended Kempsville High School.

In the early 1990s, Hugo and Williams formed a four-piece "R&B-type" group, [[the Neptunes]], with friends [[Shay Haley]] and Mike Etheridge. They later entered a high school talent show where they were discovered by [[Teddy Riley (producer)|Teddy Riley]], whose studio was next to Princess Anne High School.<ref>[http://www.yolk.com/v092/chadhugo1.html] {{dead link|date=February 2015}}</ref> After graduating from high school, the group signed with Riley.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopgame.com/index2.php3?page=neptunes|title=Exclusive Hip Hop News, Audio, Lyrics, Videos, Honeys, Wear, Sneakers, Download Mixtapes|publisher=Hiphopgame.com|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

==Career==

===1992\xe2\x80\x9397: Early career===
Through working with Riley, Williams went on to write a verse and help produce for [[Wreckx-N-Effect]]\'s 1992 hit "[[Rump Shaker (song)|Rump Shaker]]".<ref>{{cite book|last=Kimpel|first=Dan|title=How They Made It|publisher=[[Hal Leonard Corporation]]|year=2006|pages=124\xe2\x80\x93125|isbn=0-634-07642-6|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wDyd16CHUu4C&pg=PA124&dq=pharrell+williams&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&as_brr=0&as_pt=BOOKS|accessdate=2009-03-21}}</ref> That same year, he also performed a small rap solo on [[SWV]]\'s second hit, "Right Here (UK Remix)". Williams and Hugo met rap duo [[Clipse]] in [[Virginia Beach]] in 1993, where they were signed to [[Arista Records]] through Williams\' [[Star Trak Entertainment]] imprint.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/clipse/articles/story/5938804/new_faces_the_clipse|title=New Faces: The Clipse |last=Brackett|first=Nathan|date=September 13, 2002|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|accessdate=2009-03-21}}</ref><ref name="Yale Daily News">{{cite web|url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/articles/view/19305|title=Rap duo \'Clipse\' rocks the gangsta hip-hop scene|last=Torbati|first=June|date=December 8, 2006|work=[[Yale Daily News]]|accessdate=2009-03-21}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> In 1994, Hugo and Williams had established themselves as a production duo under their old name "The Neptunes", and assistant-produced "Tonight\'s The Night" from [[Blackstreet]]\'s [[Blackstreet (album)|self-titled album]]. Over the next three years they continued to produce occasionally, and some of the results had little resemblance to the Neptunes\' sound later. However, some like [[Mase]]\'s 1997 song "Lookin\' at Me" from his album \'\'[[Harlem World]]\'\', and the most definite beginning of the distinctive "Neptunes sound", came with [[N.O.R.E]]\'s "Superthug" in 1998, reaching number 36 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]], and gaining them widespread attention for the first time. In 1999, a mutual friend introduced Williams to [[Kelis]], and their resulting collaboration produced her first album \'\'[[Kaleidoscope (Kelis album)|Kaleidoscope]]\'\'.

===1998\xe2\x80\x932004: The Neptunes===
[[File:PHARRELL WILLIAMS by foto di matti.jpg|thumb|left|Pharrell Williams in [[Berlin]], March 2005]]
At this point the Neptunes were gaining a wide fanbase and audience.
In 2001, the Neptunes produced [[Britney Spears]]\' single, "[[I\'m a Slave 4 U]]" gaining their first worldwide number one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1449404/20010928/nerd.jhtml|title=Neptunes\xe2\x80\x99 Pharrell Williams Rethinks R&B|work=MTV News|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref> The same year, [[N.E.R.D|N*E*R*D]], consisting of Williams, Hugo and Haley, released their first album, \'\'[[In Search Of... (N.E.R.D album)|In Search of...]]\'\', in Europe, where the first Kelis album was better received. The album sounded very much like their previous production work; the group decided that they should make their work as [[N.E.R.D|N*E*R*D]] sound different, and re-recorded the album with the rock band [[Spymob]].

Then in 2002 their re-produced album was released worldwide, and the Neptunes reached number one in the U.S. with Nelly\'s single, "[[Hot in Herre]]". In August of the same year, the Neptunes were named "Producers of the Year" at both [[The Source (magazine)|the Source Awards]] and the [[Billboard Music Award]]s. [[Clipse]] released their commercial debut album \'\'[[Lord Willin\']]\'\' in August 2002. The album started at number one on the \'\'Billboard\'\' [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] chart and number four on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], fueled by its first two singles, "[[Grindin\']]" and "[[When the Last Time]]", which peaked at number 34 and number 19 respectively on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100.

The Neptunes released a self-credited album called \'\'[[Clones (album)|The Neptunes Present... Clones]]\'\' in 2003, with songs and remixes from various artists. This topped the U.S. \'\'Billboard\'\' 200 Albums Chart. The Neptunes and Williams specifically were also kept in public eye largely due to ties with [[Jay-Z]], producing several hit singles for him and two tracks on his \'\'[[The Black Album (Jay-Z album)|The Black Album]]\'\'. The track "[[Frontin\']]" was a big hit (the 34th biggest of 2003 according to \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\'). A survey in August 2003 found the Neptunes produced almost 20 percent of songs played on British radio at the time, a survey in the US had them at 43 percent.<ref name=Age/> The same year, the Neptunes remixed the [[Daft Punk]] song "[[Harder, Better, Faster, Stronger]]" for the duo\'s poorly received remix album \'\'[[Daft Club]]\'\'.  The track also had a brief rap section performed by Williams.<ref name="Fekadu">{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-11-04-pharrell-williams_N.htm|title=USA Today: Rapper-producer Pharrell has new CD, big plans|last=Fekadu|first=Mesfin|date=April 11, 2010|accessdate=December 11, 2011}}</ref>

[[N.E.R.D|N*E*R*D]]\'s second [[funk rock]]-oriented album, \'\'[[Fly or Die]]\'\', released in March 2004. Williams\'s rock credentials were further bolstered by his appearance at the [[2004 Grammy Awards]], performing [[the Beatles]]\'s "[[Please Please Me#"I Saw Her Standing There"|I Saw Her Standing There]]" on drums with [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Dave Matthews]], and [[Vince Gill]]. Williams received two Grammy Awards that night, one for [[Grammy Award for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical|Producer of the Year, Non-Classical]], and another for [[Best Pop Vocal Album]] for his work on [[Justin Timberlake]]\'s hit album \'\'[[Justified (album)|Justified]]\'\'. They also gained their first UK number one, again with [[Nelly]], and "[[Flap Your Wings (song)|Flap Your Wings]]".

In September 2004, Williams was featured on the [[Snoop Dogg]] single "[[Drop It Like It\'s Hot]]." The song would eventually peak at number one on the [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]] two months later, marking Williams\'s first number one single in the United States. The song was named "Rap Song of the Decade" by \'\'Billboard\'\' in 2009.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/song/snoop-dogg-featuring-pharrell/drop-it-like-it-s-hot/6900789#/charts-decade-end/rap-songs?year=2009] {{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref>

===2005\xe2\x80\x9309: \'\'In My Mind\'\'===
[[File:Astronaut Leland Melvin, and Pharrell Williams present montage to Quincy Jones.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Williams and American astronaut [[Leland D. Melvin]] present a montage to record producer [[Quincy Jones]].]]
On September 9, 2005, Williams performed the opening single from his first solo album \'\'[[In My Mind (Pharrell album)|In My Mind]]\'\', "[[Can I Have It Like That]]", featuring [[Gwen Stefani]]. The single did poorly in the US, reaching only number 48. It fared better in the UK, reaching number three. Between then and the July 25, 2006 release of \'\'In My Mind\'\', he released "[[Angel (Pharrell Williams song)|Angel]]" (in Europe only), and later "[[Number One (Pharrell Williams song)|Number One]]" with [[Kanye West]]. Several songs leaked to the internet before the album release, most notably "[[In My Mind (Pharrell Williams album)|Mamacita]]" featuring [[Daddy Yankee]], which was subsequently cut from the final version. "[[In My Mind (Pharrell Williams album)|That Girl]]" featuring [[Snoop Dogg]] was the final single.

In 2006, the Neptunes produced [[Clipse]]\'s second album \'\'[[Hell Hath No Fury (Clipse album)|Hell Hath No Fury]]\'\'. Most critics labeled the album the Neptunes best production in years, and put the duo back in the charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/Hell-Hath-No-Fury-Clipse/dp/B0000TWMDY |title=Hell Hath No Fury: Clipse: Music: Reviews, Prices & more |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-05}}</ref> A year later, Williams collaborated with [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], on the song "[[Hey You (Madonna song)|Hey You]]", which was available for download on the [[MSN]] website. 25 cents for each of the first one million downloads was donated to the [[Alliance for Climate Protection]], in support of [[Live Earth]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://liveearth.msn.com/green/Madonnadownload |title=Retrieved on May 22, 2007 |publisher=Liveearth.msn.com |date=September 15, 2010 |accessdate=2010-11-05}}</ref> Later that year, Williams performed songs at the [[Concert for Diana]] on July 1, 2007. On July 7, he performed at the [[Live Earth concert, Rio de Janeiro|Brazilian leg]] of [[Live Earth (2007 concert)|Live Earth]] in Rio de Janeiro.

A remix album of Williams\'s solo debut, \'\'In My Mind\'\', titled \'\'Out of My Mind\'\', was recorded with his newly formed band "The Yessirs" featuring [[Questlove]] of [[the Roots]] and was produced by [[Questlove]] and keyboardist [[James Poyser]]. However, Williams\'s record label [[Interscope Records]] did not think that the album would sell well and subsequently was shelved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehiphopicon.com/pharrell.htm|title=Pharrell Williams goes Out of His Mind|author=TheHipHopIcon.com|date=September 14, 2007|publisher=TheHipHopIcon.com|accessdate=September 16, 2007}}</ref> The album has built up a strong fanbase asking for its release. The tracks started appearing on Questlove\'s MySpace, and with every 10,000 plays, a new song was made available. As of July 4, 2007, the full CD has leaked onto the internet along with two songs not featured on \'\'In My Mind\'\':  a remix of "Mamacita" and "Creamsickle".

Williams produced [[Beyonc\xc3\xa9]]\'s version of "[[Diamonds Are a Girl\'s Best Friend]]". He then wrote the Neptunes-produced "[[Blackout (Britney Spears album)|Why Should I Be Sad]]" on [[Britney Spears]]\' fifth studio album, \'\'[[Blackout (Britney Spears album)|Blackout]]\'\'. He also produced two songs from [[the Hives]]\' album, \'\'[[The Black and White Album]]\'\', titled "[[The Black and White Album|Well All Right!]]" and "[[The Black and White Album|T.H.E.H.I.V.E.S.]]".

In April 2008, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] released her eleventh album, \'\'[[Hard Candy (Madonna album)|Hard Candy]]\'\', which featured vocals from Williams and production from the Neptunes on several tracks. In June, an article in [[NME]] revealed that Williams was very interested in producing [[the Strokes]]\' fourth album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/pharrell-williams/37303|title=NME News Pharrell Williams: \'I want to produce The Strokes\' new album\' - NME.COM|date=June 13, 2008|work=NME.COM|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref> Later that year, Williams worked on a remix album for [[Maroon 5]]\'s \'\'[[Call and Response: The Remix Album|Call & Response]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cohen|first=Jonathan|date=October 31, 2008|title=Pharrell, Oakenfold, Of Montreal Remix Maroon 5|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Nielsen Company|Nielsen Business Media]]|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043620/pharrell-oakenfold-of-montreal-remix-maroon-5|accessdate=2008-11-02}}</ref>

Williams continued working with a variety of artists, including [[Shakira]] on the songs \'[[Did It Again (Shakira song)|Did It Again]]\', \'[[She Wolf (Shakira album)|Why Wait]]\', \'[[She Wolf (Shakira album)|Good Stuff]]\' and \'[[She Wolf (Shakira album)|Long Time]]\' for her sixth studio album, \'\'[[She Wolf (Shakira album)|She Wolf]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a181454/shakira-pharrell-taught-me-a-lot.html |title=Music \xe2\x80\x93 News \xe2\x80\x93 Shakira: \'Pharrell taught me a lot\' |publisher=Digital Spy |date=October 10, 2009 |accessdate=2010-11-05}}</ref> In September 2009, Williams was credited as a co-writer and producer of the song "[[Fresh Out the Oven]]" for [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/17842/102934 |title=Pink, Paramore, Death Cab, Katy Perry, Ne-Yo and More: VMAs Interviews You Didn\'t See on TV  |publisher=Rolling Stone |date= |accessdate=2010-11-05}}</ref> It was released as a [[buzz single]] from Lopez\'s seventh studio album \'\'[[Love? (album)|Love?]]\'\'. The following month, Williams made a guest appearance on French [[Independent music|indie]]/[[Electronic music|electronic]] rapper [[Uffie]]\'s first album, which arrived in early 2010.<ref name="Busy P Blog 10/03/2009">[http://busyp.coolcats.fr/2009/10/uffie-pop-the-lock-video/] {{dead link|date=February 2015}}</ref> In late 2009, Williams worked with the rapper [[Game (rapper)|Game]] on his fourth studio album, \'\'[[The R.E.D. Album]].\'\'

===2010\xe2\x80\x9312: \'\'Despicable Me\'\' and collaborations===
In July 2010, Williams composed the soundtrack to the movie \'\'[[Despicable Me]]\'\', produced by [[Hans Zimmer]] and recorded with the [[Hollywood Studio Symphony]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview: Pharrell Williams of N*E*R*D. talks his "Despicable Me" Soundtrack|url=http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/news/article/0,,7321764,00.html|publisher=ARTISTdirect|accessdate=July 5, 2010}}</ref> In October 2010, Williams and his group [[N.E.R.D|N*E*R*D]] supported [[Gorillaz]] on their \'\'[[Escape to Plastic Beach World Tour]]\'\'. On the tour, [[Damon Albarn]] recorded a song with Williams but this was not featured on Gorillaz\'s album, \'\'[[The Fall (Gorillaz album)|The Fall]]\'\'.<ref name="Fekadu"/> The following month, [[N.E.R.D|N*E*R*D]] released their fourth studio album \'\'[[Nothing (N.E.R.D. album)|Nothing]]\'\' through Williams\'s label [[Star Trak]]. In late 2011, Williams worked on three tracks for [[Mike Posner]]\'s second album \'\'[[Sky High (Mike Posner album)|Sky High]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mike Posner: From His Mother\xe2\x80\x99s Basement To Here|url=http://allhiphop.com/2011/12/07/mike-posner-from-his-mothers-basement-to-here/|work=[[AllHipHop]]|accessdate=February 21, 2012|author=JP DelaCuesta|date=December 7, 2011}}</ref>

In 2011, Williams collaborated with singer/composer [[Adam Lambert]], co-writing two tracks for Lambert\'s album \'\'[[Trespassing (album)|Trespassing]]\'\', which was released in May 2012, including the title track and "[[Trespassing (album)|Kickin\' In]]".
 
In 2012, it was announced on [[Lupe Fiasco]]\'s website that he and Lupe will work on a collaborative album and work on [[Waka Flocka Flame]]\'s album \'\'[[Triple F Life: Friends, Fans and Family]]\'\'.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}

He has also collaborated with Pittsburgh rapper [[Mac Miller]] on the \'\'Pink Slime\'\' EP. The first track, "Onaroll" was followed by "Glow". It was produced by Williams, with vocals from Mac Miller.

Williams composed and produced the music for the [[84th Academy Awards]] alongside composer [[Hans Zimmer]].<ref name="84th academy awards">{{cite news| url = http://articles.latimes.com/2012/feb/24/entertainment/la-ca-oscars-music-20120224| title =  The Oscars: Hans Zimmer and Pharrell Williams know the score for the telecast \xe2\x80\x93 they wrote it| publisher = Los Angeles Times| date = February 24, 2012| accessdate = 2012-03-06| first=August| last=Brown}}</ref> He collaborated with the singer [[Miley Cyrus]] on her album \'\'[[Bangerz (album)|Bangerz]]\'\' and composed the new intro music for \'\'[[Chelsea Lately]]\'\' in 2012. He later contributed four tracks to [[Game (rapper)|The Game]]\'s \'\'[[California Republic (mixtape)|California Republic]]\'\' mixtape called "[[California Republic (mixtape)|When My Niggas Come Home]]" and "[[California Republic (mixtape)|It Must be Tough]]"; produced two tracks on [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]]\'s 2012 seventh studio album, \'\'[[Looking 4 Myself]],\'\' titled "[[Looking 4 Myself|Twisted]]" and "[[Looking 4 Myself|Hot Thing]]";<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisisrnb.com/2011/11/usher-hits-the-studio-with-pharrell-jim-jonsin-diplo/|title=Usher Hits The Studio With Pharrell, Jim Jonsin & Diplo|work=This Is RnB|date=November 6, 2011|accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref> collaborated with [[Mika (singer)|Mika]] on his new track "Celebrate"; co-produced the tracks "[[Channel Orange|Sweet Life]]" and "[[Channel Orange|Golden Girl]]" from Frank Ocean\'s debut album \'\'[[Channel Orange]]\'\'; and is working with [[Solange Knowles]] on her third studio album.

===2013\xe2\x80\x93present: \'\'G I R L\'\' and \'\'The Voice\'\'===
Williams is featured on [[Daft Punk]]\'s fourth studio album \'\'[[Random Access Memories]]\'\' on the songs "[[Get Lucky (Daft Punk song)|Get Lucky]]" and "[[Lose Yourself to Dance]]". In addition, Williams contributed to [[Azealia Banks]]\'s debut studio album \'\'[[Broke with Expensive Taste]]\'\', featuring on the song "[[Broke with Expensive Taste|ATM Jam]]."<ref>{{cite web|last=Gore|first=Sydney|title=Azealia Banks Premieres Pharrell Williams-Assisted, \'ATM Jam\': Listen|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/1568853/azealia-banks-premieres-pharrell-williams-assisted-atm-jam-listen|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=July 5, 2013|date=July 3, 2013}}</ref> Williams penned three new original songs, included alongside composer [[Heitor Pereira]]\'s score, for the sequel \'\'[[Despicable Me 2]]\'\'. These were "[[Despicable Me: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|Just a Cloud Away]]", "[[Happy (Pharrell Williams song)|Happy]]", and "[[Despicable Me: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|Scream]]" (featuring [[CeeLo Green]]). His two original songs from the first film were also reprised on the soundtrack \xe2\x80\x93 "[[Despicable Me: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|Despicable Me]]" and "[[Despicable Me: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|Fun, Fun, Fun]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/pharrell-williams-gets-happy-on-despicable-me-2-soundtrack-song-premiere-20130521 |title=Pharrell Williams Gets \'Happy\' on \'Despicable Me 2\' Soundtrack |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=May 21, 2013 |accessdate=2013-07-27}}</ref> He also participated in the drummer sessions of the soundtrack of [[Man of Steel (soundtrack)|Man of Steel]] by [[Hans Zimmer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=QTOMIyynBPE |title=Man of Steel Soundtrack \xe2\x80\x93 Percussion \xe2\x80\x93 Hans Zimmer |publisher=YouTube |date=June 24, 2013 |accessdate=2013-07-27}}</ref>

In March 2013, [[Robin Thicke]]\'s hit single "[[Blurred Lines]]" was released, which was written and produced by Williams. The song has been a worldwide hit, has peaked at number one on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100, and has also reached number one in 13 more countries including the United Kingdom and Germany, making it Williams\'s third \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100 number one single.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1566519/robin-thickes-blurred-lines-hits-no-1-on-hot-100 | title=Robin Thicke\'s \'Blurred Lines\' Hits No. 1 on Hot 100 | publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=June 12, 2013 | accessdate=June 12, 2013 | author=Trust, Gary}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1568185/robin-thicke-still-atop-hot-100-miley-cyrus-bruno-mars-reach-top-10|work=Billboard|title=Robin Thicke Still Atop Hot 100; Miley Cyrus, Bruno Mars Reach Top 10|first=Gary|last=Trust|date=June 26, 2013|accessdate=2013-06-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1566519/robin-thickes-blurred-lines-hits-no-1-on-hot-100|title=Robin Thicke\'s \'Blurred Lines\' Hits No. 1 on Hot 100|work=Billboard|date=June 12, 2013|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> On June 29, 2013, Williams became the 12th artist in the chart\'s history to simultaneously hold the number one and two positions with "Blurred Lines" and "Get Lucky", respectively.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1567379/robin-thickes-blurred-lines-remains-atop-hot-100-chart|work=Billboard|title=Robin Thicke\'s \'Blurred Lines\' Remains Atop Hot 100 Chart|first=Gary|last=Trust|date=June 19, 2013|accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>
[[File:Pharrell Williams 2014 Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|Pharrell Williams performing at the 2014 [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]].]]
By July 2013 there had only been 137 singles in UK chart history to have sold 1 million copies in the UK; that month Williams scored two million-sellers with "Get Lucky" and "Blurred Lines".<ref>{{cite web|title=Blurred Lines gives Pharrell his second million seller in a month|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/blurred-lines-becomes-uks-latest-million-selling-single-2361/|work=OfficialCharts.com|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|accessdate=August 15, 2013}}</ref> In August 2013, [[Busta Rhymes]] talked about an unreleased "documentary album" by Williams where he talks about "inner-city strife and hardship".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/08/busta-rhymes-the-combat-jack-show-chris-lighty|title=Busta Rhymes Discusses "Scenario," A Tribe Called Quest & Chris Lighty - The Combat Jack Show Episode 3|author=Edwin Ortiz|work=Complex|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref> In November 2013, Williams released the [[first 24-hour music video]] to his \'\'[[Despicable Me 2]]\'\' collaboration song, "[[Happy (Pharrell Williams song)|Happy]]". Guest appearances included [[Magic Johnson]], [[Steve Carell]], [[Jimmy Kimmel]], [[Jamie Foxx]], [[Odd Future]], [[Miranda Cosgrove]], [[Janelle Mon\xc3\xa1e]], and many others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://24hoursofhappy.com/|title=Pharrell Williams \xe2\x80\x93 Happy: The World\'s First 24 Hour Music Video|accessdate=2013-11-21}}</ref> It has received approximately 5.5 million views as of Christmas Day, 2013.<ref name=melena>
{{cite news | last = Ryzik | first = Melena  | title =Round-the-Clock Giddiness in a 24-Hour Music Video | newspaper = New York Times | date = December 25, 2013 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/26/arts/music/round-the-clock-giddiness-in-a-24-hour-music-video.html?hp= | accessdate =2013-12-26}}</ref> The music video for the song is nominated for [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Male Video|Best Male Video]] and [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]] at The [[2014 MTV Video Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|title= Best Male Video 2014 MTV Video Awards |url= http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2014/best-male-video/ |publisher= MTV |date= August 24, 2014 |accessdate= August 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Video Of The Year 2014 MTV Video Music Awards|url= http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2014/video-of-the-year/ |publisher= MTV |date= August 24, 2014 |accessdate= August 24, 2014}}</ref>

It was announced in December 2013 that Williams had been nominated for seven Grammy Awards, including [[Grammy Award for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical|Producer of the Year]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://variety.com/2013/music/news/grammy-nominations-jay-z-leads-but-timberlake-other-stars-shut-out-of-top-categories-1200927905/ | work=Variety | title=Grammy Nominations: Jay Z Leads But Timberlake, Other Stars Shut Out of Top Categories \xe2\x80\x93 Variety}}</ref> In the same month, a press release from [[Columbia Records]] announced that Williams had signed a contract with the label and would be releasing an album in 2014, entitled \'\'[[Girl (Pharrell Williams album)|G I R L]]\'\', featuring the single "[[Happy (Pharrell Williams song)|Happy]]" from the \'\'Despicable Me 2\'\' [[Despicable Me: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|soundtrack]].<ref name="second album">{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/dec/18/pharrell-williams-solo-album|title=Pharrell Williams signs to Columbia|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=December 18, 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=December 22, 2013}}</ref> For "Happy", Williams was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]]. In February 2014 [[Major Lazer]] announced they would be releasing a five-track EP titled \'\'[[Apocalypse Soon]]\'\' on the 25th of that month. The EP, released via [[Mad Decent]] and [[Secretly Canadian]], will feature Williams and [[Sean Paul]], among others. The first single off the EP, which features Williams, is titled "[[Apocalypse Soon|Aerosol Can]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indieshuffle.com/major-lazer-aerosol-can-ft-pharrell/|title=Major Lazer \xe2\x80\x93 \'\'Apocalypse Soon\'\' EP|accessdate=2014-02-06}}</ref> Williams contributed a verse to [[Future (rapper)|Future]]\'s February 2014 single "[[Move That Dope]]", which also featured [[Pusha T]] and Casino over production from [[Mike Will Made It]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/future-move-that-dope-feat-pharrell-pusha-t-casino-prod-by-mike-will-made-it-new-song.1814367.html |title=Future \xe2\x80\x93 Move That Dope Feat. Pharrell, Pusha T & Casino (Prod. By Mike WiLL Made It) &#124; Stream & Listen [New Song&#93; |publisher=Hotnewhiphop.com |date=February 6, 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref>

On February 18, Williams announced via Twitter that his second album, \'\'[[Girl (Pharrell Williams album)|Girl]]\'\' would be released on March 3, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/pharrell-announces-new-album-g-i-r-l-reveals-cover-and-release-date-news.9416.html |title=Pharrell Announces New Album "G I R L"; Reveals Cover & Release Date |publisher=Hotnewhiphop.com |date=February 19, 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref> At the [[86th Academy Awards]] on March 2, 2014, Williams\'s song "Happy" lost to "[[Let It Go (Disney song)|Let It Go]]" from \'\'[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]\'\'.  Afterwards, when \'\'GQ\'\' magazine asked Williams "how badly" did he want the Oscar, he responded: "When they read the results, my face was...frozen. But then I thought about it, and I just decided just to...let it go."<ref>{{cite news|last=Baron|first=Zach|title=Pharrell Williams on Advanced Style Moves and That Oscar Snub: My Song Will "Be Here For 10 Years"|url=http://www.gq.com/entertainment/profiles/201404/pharrell-williams-oscar-snub|accessdate=March 31, 2014|newspaper=GQ|date=March 2014}}</ref>

The [[Dear Girl Tour|Dear G I R L tour]] is an ongoing European concert tour, in support of his second studio album, \'\'[[Girl (Pharrell Williams album)|G I R L]]\'\'. It is Williams\'s first solo tour since 2006.<ref name=mtv>{{cite news|last=MTV|first=Lisa|title=Dear Girl Tour|url= http://www.mtv.com/news/1829269/pharrell-dear-girl-tour-europe//|publisher=MTV}}</ref>

On March 31, 2014, Williams was announced as a new coach for the [[The Voice (U.S. season 7)|seventh season]] of \'\'[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]\'\', replacing [[CeeLo Green]].<ref name=respers>{{cite news|last=Respers|first=Lisa|title=Pharrell Williams joining \'The Voice\'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/31/showbiz/tv/pharrell-williams-the-voice/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=April 3, 2014|date=March 31, 2014}}</ref> In June 2014, it was announced that Williams would make a guest appearance on the docu-series \'\'[[Sisterhood of Hip Hop]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|last=Corry|first=Kristin|title=\'Sisterhood of Hip Hop\' to Debut on Oxygen This Summer|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/sisterhood-of-hip-hop-debut-oxygen-summer|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|publisher=Vibe.com|date=June 9, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}}</ref>

Pharrell Williams is the executive producer of Atlanta rapper [[T.I.]]\'s ninth studio album, \'\'[[Paperwork (T.I. album)|Paperwork]]\'\', which was released on October 21, 2014 by [[Grand Hustle Records|Grand Hustle]] and [[Columbia Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.power1049.com/index.php/79-muzic-category/news/71-t-i-talks-working-with-executive-producer-pharrell-williams-for-his-paperwork-album|title=T.I. Talks Working With Executive Producer Pharrell Williams For His "Paperwork" Album|author=Super User|publisher=Power1049.com|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

In May 2014, Williams curated an art show named after his album, "G I R L,"  at the [[Galerie Perrotin]] in Paris, France. The show included 37 artists including [[Takashi Murakami]], [[JR (artist)|JR]], [[Daniel Arsham]], and [[Marina Abramovic]] among others."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/05/27/pharrell-curated-exhibition-paris-girl-emmanuel-perrotin-marina-abramovic|title=Art and Fashion Stars Toast a Pharrell-Curated Exhibition in Paris |work=The New York Times|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

[[Comme des Gar\xc3\xa7ons]] developed a unisex fragrance with Williams scheduled for release in late 2014. Artist [[KAWS (artist)|KAWS]] designed the bottle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/beauty/2014/03/12/pharrell-williams-comme-des-garcons-fragrance-collaboration-girl|title=Pharrell Williams Comme Des Garcons Fragrance Collaboration GIRL (Vogue.co.uk)|work=Vogue UK|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

In January 2015, Williams and Al Gore announced that they are teaming up to create a 7-continent "Live Earth" concert on June 18 to raise awareness about and pressure governments to act on climate change. He is the musical director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/afp-pharrell-williams-to-head-up-live-earth-global-climate-concert-2015-1|title=Pharrell Announces \'Live Earth\' Global Climate Concert - Business Insider|date=January 21, 2015|work=Business Insider|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

On February 8, 2015, Williams made a cameo in an episode of \'\'[[The Simpsons]]\'\' entitled "[[Walking Big & Tall]]" where he comes to [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|Springfield]] to write a new anthem for the town.<ref>{{cite journal|url= http://insidetv.ew.com/2015/01/22/pharrell-simpsons/ |title= Pharrell to guest on \'The Simpsons\' -- exclusive |first= Dan |last= Snierson |date= January 22, 2015 |magazine= [[Entertainment Weekly]] |accessdate= January 22, 2015}}</ref>

Williams recently made three songs for the soundtrack to the [[The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water]] movie. He also recorded a song "Shine" with [[Gwen Stefani]] for the [[Paddington (film)|Paddington]] Movie.

At the 2015 [[Grammy Awards]] Williams performed an orchestral rendition of "Happy" with composer [[Hans Zimmer]] and pianist [[Lang Lang (pianist)|Lang Lang]] that included a tribute to the [[Black Lives Matter]] "Hands Up, Don\'t Shoot" movement inspired by [[Eric Garner]]\'s death and the events in [[Ferguson, Missouri]].

===\'\'Blurred Lines\'\' Lawsuit===
In 2015, a unanimous jury determined that Williams\'s 2013 hit song "Blurred Lines" was an infringement of the 1977 Marvin Gaye song "Got to Give It Up".<ref name="usatoday1">{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2015/03/10/blurred-lines-trial-verdict/24492431/ |title=\'Blurred Lines\' jury finds for Marvin Gaye |publisher=Usatoday.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-12}}</ref>  The jury awarded the Gaye family $7.4 million in damages for the copyright infringement based on profits generated.<ref name="usatoday1"/>

==Musical style==
Williams has stated that he does not have any direct influences,<ref name="VH1">{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/news/articles/1538022/story.jhtml|title=Pharrell Williams, Accidental Crooner|last=Kondo|first=Toshitaka|work=[[VH1]]|accessdate=2009-07-06}}</ref> but has expressed his admiration for several musicians, including [[Michael Jackson]], [[J Dilla]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Donny Hathaway]], [[Marvin Gaye]], [[Rakim]] and [[Q-Tip (rapper)|Q-Tip]].<ref name="VH1"/><ref name="Rolling Stone">{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/8798649/qa_pharrell_williams|title=Q&A: Pharrell Williams|last=Scaggs|first=Austin|date=November 17, 2005|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|accessdate=2009-07-06}}</ref> Williams explained that [[A Tribe Called Quest]]\'s 1990 album, \'\'[[People\'s Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm]]\'\', caused a "turning point" in his life, which "made him see that music was art".<ref name="Rolling Stone"/>

==Business ventures==

Williams launched a multimedia creative collective and record label called [[i am OTHER]] in May 2012 that serves as an umbrella for all of his business endeavors including a record label, apparel, textiles, and a dedicated YouTube channel.

Williams co-founded the clothing brands [[Billionaire Boys Club (clothing)|Billionaire Boys Club]] and [[Billionaire Boys Club (clothing)|Ice Cream]] Footwear. He has a boutique store in New York City on West Broadway.

In 2008, Williams co-designed a series of jewelry ("Blason") and glasses for [[Louis Vuitton]].<ref name="touchstone">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25111550-5013575,00.html|title=Hip-hop\'s glittering touchstone|date=February 27, 2009|work=[[The Australian]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=2009-03-11}}</ref> He has also worked on furniture with [[Emmanuel Perrotin]] and a French manufacturer, Domeau & P\xc3\xa9r\xc3\xa8s. One of his works, a molded plastic seat with human legs, was created because he "wanted to know what it was like to be in love." The chair depicts a sexual scene with a pair of female legs and male legs.

In 2009, Williams unveiled a collaborative sculpture with [[Takashi Murakami]] at [[Art Basel]], which spoke to the metaphor of value.<ref name="Interview with Pharrell Williams Art 40 Basel 2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vsKrADTeEuE|title=Interview with Pharrell Williams at Art Basel 2009|date=June 11, 2009|work=YouTube|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

In May 2011, it was announced that Williams would serve as Creative Director of [[KarmaloopTV]] alongside founder and CEO [[Greg Selkoe]] and former [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]] president Katie McEnroe.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/pharrell-williams-named-creative-director-186878 |title=Pharrell Williams Named Creative Director at Karmaloop TV |publisher=The Hollywood Reporter |date= May 9, 2011|accessdate=2012-03-28}}</ref>

On August 1, 2011, Williams launched his new YouTube channel, "[[i am OTHER]]" as part of YouTube\'s $100 million [[YouTube Original Channel Initiative|original channel initiative]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.16239/title.pharrell-williams-launches-his-new-label-i-am-other-records|title=Pharrell Williams Launches His New Label, i am Other Records|author=HipHopDX|date=August 1, 2011|work=HipHopDX|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

In August 2013, Williams created a line of sunglasses for [[Moncler]] called "Moncler Lunettes".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2013/08/30/first-look-pharrell-x-moncler-lunettes-sunglasses-collection/|title=First Look: Pharrell x Moncler Lunettes Sunglasses Collection|work=Highsnobiety|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

In 2014, Williams entered a long-term partnership with [[Adidas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwd.com/markets-news/intimates-activewear/pharrell-williams-to-collaborate-with-adidas-7618802?module=hp-markets/|title=Pharrell to Collaborate With Adidas|author=David Yi|work=WWD|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

In February 2014, Williams announced a collaboration between [[G-Star Raw]] and his textile company Bionic Yarn called "RAW for the Oceans," a collection of denim made from recycled plastic that is found in the ocean. The project was presented at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/fashion/pharrell-williams-g-star-launch-eco-friendly-denim-line-article-1.1608290|title=Pharrell Williams, G-Star to launch eco-friendly denim line|work=NY Daily News|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

Williams released a collection for retail giant [[Uniqlo]] in April 2014 entitled "[[i am OTHER]]". It was created with [[Nigo]], creative director of UT, the company\'s T-shirt division.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2014/04/02/pharrell-williams-collection-for-uniqlo-t-shirt-collaboration|title=Pharrell Williams Collection For Uniqlo T-shirt Collaboration  (Vogue.co.uk)|work=Vogue UK|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

In June 2014, artist collective Rizzoli published a book by [[FriendsWithYou]] called "We Are Friends With You" that featured contributions from Williams, [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]], and [[Peter Doroshenko]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rizzoliusa.com/book.php?isbn=9780847842377|title=We Are FriendsWithYou Written by FriendsWithYou, Contribution by Pharrell Williams and Alejandro Jodorowsky, Introduction by Peter Doroshenko - Rizzoli New York - Rizzoli New York|publisher=Rizzoliusa.com|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

Williams co-composed \'\'[[The Amazing Spider-Man 2]]\'\' with [[Hans Zimmer]], [[Johnny Marr]], [[Michael Einziger]] and [[David A. Stewart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/5770395/pharrell-williams-ebay-beyonce-album-scoring-spider-man|title=Pharrell Talks eBay Collab, Beyonce\'s Album, Scoring the \'Spider-Man\' Sequel and More|work=Billboard|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/marc-webb-hans-zimmer-form-652222|title=Marc Webb, Hans Zimmer Form Supergroup for \'Amazing Spider-Man 2\'|author=Rebecca Ford|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

Williams owns a non-profit organization called "From One Hand To AnOTHER" (FOHTA). FOHTA is an educational foundation. According to its website, its mission is to "change the world one kid at a time by giving them the tools and resources to meet their unique potential". FOHTA\'s vision is to modernize the community center concept by empowering kids to learn through new technologies, arts, media and motivation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/kellyphillipserb/2014/02/23/pharrell-williams-the-ultimate-charitable-hat-trick/|title=Pharrell Williams & The Ultimate Charitable Hat Trick |publisher=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Williams married his longtime girlfriend, model/designer Helen Lasichanh, on October 12, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/pharrell-williams-marries-helen-lasichanh-jay-z-and-justin-timberlake-attend-all-the-details-20131210|title=Pharrell Williams Marries Helen Lasichanh, Usher and Busta Rhymes Perform: All the Details! |work=Us Weekly|date=October 12, 2013 |accessdate=October 12, 2013|first=Stephanie|last=Webber}}</ref> They have a son, Rocket Williams, born in November 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popcrush.com/jay-z-glory-not-spontaneous-pharrell/ |title=Jay-Z\'s \'Glory\' Wasn\'t Spontaneous, According to Pharrell |publisher=Popcrush.com |date=February 29, 2012 |accessdate=2013-07-27}}</ref> The \'\'[[Despicable Me]]\'\' song "[[Despicable Me: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|Rocket\'s Theme]]" was written in honor of his son.<ref>{{cite web|author=imageplaybuttons |url=http://cluemagazine.wordpress.com/tag/pharrell-williams/ |title=Pharrell Williams &#124; Clue Mag |publisher=Cluemagazine.wordpress.com |date=April 5, 2012 |accessdate=2013-07-27}}</ref>

In 2005, Williams was voted "Best Dressed Man in the World" by \'\'[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1507427/20050811/williams_pharrell.jhtml|title=Pharrell Is The World\xe2\x80\x99s Best-Dressed Man (According To Esquire, Anyway)|work=MTV News|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref> He is a fan of the science fiction series \'\'[[Star Trek]]\'\',<ref>{{Wayback |date=20070311094953 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2004/06/07/bmpharr07.xml |title=The nerd who inherited the earth}}. Retrieved on May 22, 2007.</ref> as indicated by his consistent use of the [[Vulcan salute]] to signify his label name, [[Star Trak]]. He also enjoys the works of the late [[astronomer]] and science lecturer [[Carl Sagan]], whom he calls "a genius".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blender.com/guide/articles.aspx?id=2003|title=Maxim|publisher=Blender.com|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref> Williams is a skateboarder and has a [[half-pipe]] inside his home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.askmen.com/toys/interview_200/210_pharrell_interview.html|title=13 Questions With Pharrell|author=AskMen Editors|work=AskMen|accessdate=February 13, 2015}}</ref>

Williams is building a $35 million afterschool center in his hometown [[Virginia Beach]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcodesign.com/1664105/not-a-joke-pharrell-builds-a-stunning-35m-afterschool-space-for-kids |title=Not A Joke: Pharrell Builds A Stunning, $35M Afterschool Space For Kids &#124; Co.Design: business + innovation + design |publisher=Fastcodesign.com |date=June 20, 2011 |accessdate=2013-07-27}}</ref> His charity "From One Hand To AnOTHER\'" is a foundation developed for youth between the ages of 7 and 20 in at-risk communities throughout the country.

In an interview for the magazine [[GQ|GQ Style]] (Autumn/Winter 2013), Williams described his religious views: "On paper I\'m a Christian, but really I\'m a Universalist." With regard to "those who have concluded that God simply doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exist", Pharrell Williams has stated: "It\xe2\x80\x99s so incredibly arrogant and pompous. It\xe2\x80\x99s amazing that there are people who really believe that".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2014/09/17/which-famed-singer-just-said-its-incredibly-arrogant-and-pompous-to-reject-gods-existence/|title=Famed Singer Has a Message About the Rejection of God\xe2\x80\x99s Existence: \xe2\x80\x98So Incredibly Arrogant and Pompous\xe2\x80\x99|last=Hallowell|first=Billy|date=17 September 2014|publisher=[[The Blaze]]|accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref>

In 2014, Williams was made into a cartoon in a video called "Jellyfish" by [[Takashi Murakami]].<ref name="4music">{{cite episode|title=This Week\'s Fresh Music|airdate=May 17, 2014|network=[[4Music]]}}</ref>

 ****** The Winstons

b'{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = The Winstons
| image           = The Winstons.png
| image_size      = 250px
| landscape       = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->
| alt             = 
| caption         = The Winstons in 1969
| background      = group_or_band
| alias           = 
| origin          = [[Washington, D.C.]]
| genre           = [[Funk]], [[soul music|soul]]
| years_active    = <!-- {{start date|YYYY}}\xe2\x80\x93{{end date|YYYY}} (or \xe2\x80\x93present) -->
| label           = 
| associated_acts = 
| website         = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} -->
| current_members = 
| past_members    = 
}}
\'\'\'The Winstons\'\'\' were a 1960s [[funk]] and [[soul music]] group, based in [[Washington, D.C.]]. They are known for their [[1969 in music|1969]] [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] of an [[Extended play|EP]] featuring a song entitled "[[Color Him Father]]" on the [[A-side and B-side|A-side]], and a song entitled "Amen, Brother" on the [[A-side and B-side|B-side]]. Half-way into "Amen, Brother", there is a [[drum]] [[solo (music)|solo]] (performed by [[Gregory C. Coleman|G.C. Coleman]]) which would cause The Winston\'s EP to become one of the most widely-[[sampling (music)|sampled]] [[gramaphone record|records]] in the history of [[electronic music]]. Sampled [[audio clips]] of the drum solo became known as the [[Amen Break]], which has been used in thousands of tracks in a large number of musical genres, including [[drum and bass]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Nottingham|first=Kevin|title=Top 10 Most Sampled Songs in Hip Hop|url=http://kevinnottingham.com/2009/03/16/top-10-most-sampled-songs-in-hip-hop/|accessdate=28 September 2011|date=16 March 2009}}</ref> [[oldschool jungle|jungle]], [[big beat]], [[Industrial (music)|industrial]] and [[electronica]].<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5SaFTm2bcac The Amen break\'s impact on history]</ref>

The "Color Him Father" record sold over one million copies, and received a [[music recording sales certification|gold record]] awarded by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] on 24 July 1969.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs"/>

==Members==
The Winstons line-up included:<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs"/>
*[[Gregory C. Coleman]] ([[singing|vocals]], [[drum]]s)
*Ray Maritano (vocals, [[alto saxophone]])
*Quincy Mattison (vocals, [[lead guitar]])
*Sonny Pekerol (vocals, [[bass guitar]])
*[[Richard Lewis Spencer]] (lead vocals, [[tenor saxophone]])
*Phil Tolotta (second lead, [[organ (music)|organ]])

The Winstons toured as backup for [[The Impressions]].<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs">{{cite book
| first= Joseph
| last= Murrells
| year= 1978
| title= The Book of Golden Discs
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd
| location= London
| page= 270
| isbn= 0-214-20512-6}}</ref>

==Notable songs==
*"[[Color Him Father]]" &mdash; (1969, [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]] # 7)
*"[[Amen, Brother]]" &mdash; (1969)
*"Love of The Common People" &mdash; (1969, [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]] # 54)

==See also==
*[[Amen Break]]
*[[Breakbeat]]

{{US-R&B-band-stub}}'

 ****** Womack %26 Womack

b'{{refimprove|date=February 2013}}{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name                = Womack & Womack
| image               = Womack_&_Womack,_Feb._2013.jpg
| caption             = Cecil & Linda Womack
| image_size          =
| background          = group_or_band
| alias = The House of Zekkariyas
| genre               = [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[soul music|soul]], [[funk]], [[dance music|dance]]
| years_active        = {{start date|1983}}\xe2\x80\x93{{end date|2004}}
| label               = [[Elektra Records|Elektra]], [[Manhattan Records|Manhattan]], [[Fourth & Broadway Records|Fourth & Broadway]], [[RCA]], [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], Spectrum/[[PolyGram]], Z Life Grooves, S.A.R. Starship
| past_members        = [[Cecil Womack]]<br>[[Linda Womack]]
}}
\'\'\'Womack & Womack\'\'\' was the singing and songwriting partnership of [[Americans|American]] musicians [[Cecil Womack]] and his wife, [[Linda Womack]]. The duo were successful as songwriters for other artists, and had several international hits as a singing duo in the 1980s and 1990s. Later recordings, with other members of their family, were credited to \'\'\'The House of Zekkariyas\'\'\'.

==Background==
[[Cecil Womack]] was born in 1947 in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], and performed with his older brothers [[Bobby Womack|Bobby]] (1944\xe2\x80\x932014), [[Harry Womack|Harry]] (1945\xe2\x80\x931974), Friendly and Curtis, as a [[gospel music|gospel]] [[musical group|group]]. After meeting [[Sam Cooke]], they changed their name to [[The Valentinos]] and in 1961 began to sing and record "the devil\'s music" for secular audiences, to the horror of their religious father.<ref name="independent.co.uk">{{cite web|author=Pierre Perrone |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/cecil-womack-half-of-the-husbandandwife-duo-known-for-their-soul-hits-of-the-1980s-8489040.html |title=Cecil Womack: Half of the husband-and-wife duo known for their soul hits of the 1980s - Obituaries - News |publisher=The Independent |date=2013-02-10 |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref> The Valentinos had a hit record with "[[Lookin\' for a Love]]," selling two million copies, later becoming a no. 39 U.S. hit for [[The J. Geils Band]] in 1971.<ref name="independent.co.uk"/> They toured with  [[James Brown]] and scored another crossover hit with \xe2\x80\x9c[[It\'s All Over Now]]\xe2\x80\x9d, a song which subsequently reached no. 1 in the UK when [[cover version|covered]] by [[The Rolling Stones]] in 1964.<ref>[http://www.soultracks.com/womack_and_womack.htm Soultracks.com: Womack and Womack biography].  Retrieved 5 February 2013</ref> But the fall-out from Cooke\'s death \xe2\x80\x93 he was shot by a motel manager in Los Angeles in December 1964 \xe2\x80\x93 and Bobby Womack\'s marriage halted their progress.<ref name=allmusic>[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/womack-amp-womack-mn0000680374  Biography by William Ruhlmann at Allmusic.com]. Retrieved 5 February 2013</ref>

In the 1960s, Cecil Womack worked primarily as a songwriter and producer. He first met Linda, who is Sam Cooke\'s daughter, born in 1953, when he was thirteen and she was eight.<ref name="soulwalking.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.soulwalking.co.uk/Womack%20&%20Womack.html |title=Womack & Womack Page |publisher=Soulwalking.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref> Although Linda and Cecil were close, particularly after her father\'s death in 1964, he married singer  [[Mary Wells]] in 1967 and wrote material for her, including the hit "[[The Doctor (Mary Wells song)|The Doctor]]", released on Jubilee Records. They had three children, and he managed her career until their break-up in 1977.<ref name="soulwalking.co.uk"/> Linda Cooke also worked as a songwriter, co-writing Bobby Womack\'s "[[Woman\'s Gotta Have It (song)|Woman\'s Gotta Have It]]."<ref>[http://www.noise11.com/news/cecil-womack-dies-at-age-65-20130204  VVN Music, \'\'Cecil Womack Dies At Age 65\'\', Noise 11, 4 February 2013].  Retrieved 6 February 2013</ref> Bobby Womack was her stepfather, having married Sam Cooke\'s widow, Barbara. Cecil Womack and Mary Wells divorced in 1977, and he and Linda married shortly afterwards.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/how-we-met--womack-and-womack-1403513.html  The Independent, \'\'How we met: Womack & Womack\'\', 30 January 1994].  Retrieved 5 February 2013</ref>

==Performers==
In 1983, Cecil and Linda began performing and recording together as Womack & Womack, and released a successful album, \'\'[[Love Wars]]\'\' produced by [[Stewart Levine]] on [[Elektra Records]]. The first single from the album, "T.K.O.", reached the  \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[R&B chart]]; the next single, "Love Wars", reached no.14 on the [[UK singles chart]] in early 1984, and the third single from the album, "Baby I\'m Scared Of You", was successful in both the US (no. 25, R&B chart) and the UK (no. 72).<ref name="whitburnr&b">{{cite book |title= Top R&B/Hip-Hop Singles: 1942-1995|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=1996 |publisher=Record Research |page=491}}</ref><ref name="betts">{{cite book| first= Graham| last= Betts| year=2004| title= Complete UK Hit Singles 1952-2004| edition= 1st|publisher= Collins| location= London| isbn= 0-00-717931-6| page=856}}</ref> As with most of the tracks they recorded together, the songs were written by the pair. Drawing from their own, convoluted, personal experiences, Cecil and Linda, knowing each other since childhood, were experts at capturing the trials, travails and tribulations of love.<ref name="independent.co.uk"/> Their next album, the self-produced  \'\'Radio M.U.S.C. Man,\'\' released in 1986, included songs which Sam Cooke had started to write and which Cecil and Linda completed, along with a cover of the [[Beatles]]\' "[[Here Comes The Sun]]". The album only produced one hit, "Strange & Funny", the pair\'s last chart entry in the US, and they left Elektra to record for the  [[Manhattan Records|Manhattan]] label.<ref name="whitburnr&b"/> Their only release for the label, 1986\'s "\'\'Starbright,\'\'" an ill-fated stab at the charts with little of their past sound, was barely released in the U.S., but produced a single, "Soul Love/Soul Man" that reached no. 58 in the U.K. Always popular in England, they headlined at the  [[Royal Albert Hall]] in 1987.<ref name="independent.co.uk"/>

Their success in the UK and other parts of the world was rekindled in 1988 with the "naggingly catchy"<ref name="independent.co.uk"/> single "[[Teardrops (Womack & Womack song)|Teardrops]]", taken from their fourth album (and first for the [[Fourth & Broadway Records|Fourth & Broadway]] label), \'\'[[Conscience (Womack & Womack album)|Conscience]]\'\'. The single reached no. 3 in the U.K., no. 1 in [[The Netherlands]], [[Australia]], and [[New Zealand]]; and no. 2 in [[Germany]] and [[Switzerland]].<ref>[http://tsort.info/music/yr1988.htm  The World\'s Music Chart: Songs from the year 1988].  retrieved 4 February 2013</ref> Two other album tracks charted in England, "Life\'s Just A Ballgame" (U.K. no. 32) and "Celebrate The World" (U.K. no. 19).<ref name="betts"/> The album itself went gold in ten countries and platinum in three.<ref>Liner Notes "Womack & Womack: Live In Conceet" DVD</ref> An eleven song  [[DVD]], \'\'Womack & Womack: Live In Concert\'\' was released in 1989, filmed during their "Celebrate The World" tour in Australia, America, England, Spain and France. It was re-released in 2009 by Cherry Red Films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cherryred.co.uk |title=Cherry Red Records |publisher=Cherryred.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref>

Their next album, 1991\'s \'\'Family Spirit\'\' was released on [[RCA]] in the U.S., and [[BMG]]/[[Arista Records|Arista]] in the rest of the world. It didn\'t chart, but the single "Uptown" was a club hit. After traveling to [[Nigeria]], they discovered ancestral ties to the Zekkariyas tribe, and adopted African names. Now recording for  [[Warner Bros. Records]], in 1993 they released what was to be their last album of new material under the name of Womack & Womack, \'\'Transformation To The House Of Zekkariyas\'\'.<ref name=allmusic>[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/womack-womack-mn0000680374  Biography by William Ruhlmann at Allmusic.com]. Retrieved 3 February 2013</ref> It produced their last charting single, "Secret Star," which reached no. 46 in the U.K. A compilation,  \'\'Tear Drops: Greatest Hits,\'\' was released in 1993 in the U.K. on the \'\'Spectrum\'\'/\'\'[[PolyGram]]\'\' label, and re-released on [[CD]] in 1998 as \'\'Greatest Hits\'\'.<ref name="discogs.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com |title=Database and Marketplace for Music on Vinyl, CD, Cassette and More |publisher=Discogs |date= |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref> Rather than being career-spanning retrospectives, the compilations contain single/remix versions taken from the singles off  \'\'Conscience\'\', and live versions of "Love Wars," [[John Denver]]\'s "[[Take Me Home Country Roads]]," "Family" and "Rejoice", taken from the concert film. \'\'Strange & Funny (The Best Of 1984-1993)\'\', an Australian compilation released on Raven Records, does a much better job at documenting the career of Womack & Womack - although all tracks are the album versions.

The Womacks, now using their adopted African name Zekkariyas, began recording as a family. Zek (Cecil) and Zeriiya (Linda), along with their children Zeumoja, Zeniya, Zeimani, and Zeapree, Lil Squal, and long-time backing group \'\'Sly, Slick & Wicked\'\', released \'\'Sub Conscience\'\' aka \'\'Subconscience\'\' as \'\'ZEK\'\' in 2001 on their own \'\'Z Life Grooves\'\' label. ZEK is short for Zekkariyas Enlightenment Kingdom. Basically a re-working of various tracks from throughout their career, a companion remix album, \'\'Circular Motion\'\' was released in 2004 on their \'\'S.A.R. Starship\'\' imprint, not 2007 as erroneously listed in many references.<ref>[http://www.allmusic.com/album/circular-motion-mw0001706255  \'\'Circular Motion\'\' at Allmusic.com].  Retrieved 3 February 2013</ref> The original [[SAR Records]] was [[Sam Cooke]]\'s record label.

==Songwriters==
Linda commenced a songwriting career in 1964 at the age of 11, composing "I Need A Woman", and would also co-write "I\'m In Love" for [[Wilson Pickett]] and "A Woman\'s Gotta Have It" in 1972 for [[Bobby Womack]]. It was also recorded by  [[James Taylor]], along with many others.<ref name="soulwalking.co.uk"/> Cecil had also written numerous songs, sometimes collaborating with then wife [[Mary Wells]]. After beginning her personal and professional relationship with Cecil, the pair started their career working as a writing team for  [[Philadelphia International Records]]. They composed tracks for artists such as  [[Teddy Pendergrass]], [[The Dramatics]], [[The O\'Jays]] ("I Just Want To Satisfy") and [[Patti LaBelle]] ("Love Symphony").<ref name="soulwalking.co.uk"/> The pair\'s "[[Love TKO]]" was a major hit for [[Teddy Pendergrass]], and was later recorded by several artists, including [[Debbie Harry]], [[Hall & Oates]], [[Boz Scaggs]] and [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]].<ref name="independent.co.uk"/> On their own they hit a creative purple patch, composing material that went on to be recorded by [[George Benson]] ("New Day"), [[Eric Clapton]] ("Lead Me On"), [[Bonnie Raitt]] ("Good Man, Good Woman") and "I Wish I Had Someone To Go Home To" for brother Bobby Womack.. The title track of their first album, "Love Wars," was covered by  [[The Beautiful South]] for the 1990 [[Elektra Records]] anniversary compilation \'\'[[Rub\xc3\xa1iy\xc3\xa1t]]\'\', and "[[Teardrops (Womack & Womack song)|Teardrops]]" has been recorded by [[k.d. lang]], [[Elton John]] and [[Joss Stone]].<ref name="soulwalking.co.uk"/> The Womacks also wrote and produced for [[Culture Club]] and [[Bryan Ferry]] backup vocalist turned solo artist [[Ruby Turner]]. Her album  \'\'Paradise\'\' featured their songs "Sexy" and "See Me," while they wrote and produced four cuts on her next album \'\'The Other Side\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|author=Alex Henderson |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-other-side-mw0000263692 |title=The Other Side - Ruby Turner &#124; Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref>

==Death==
Cecil Womack died February 1, 2013 at the age of 65 in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vintagevinylnews.com/2013/02/passings-cecil-womack-1947-2013.html |title=Passings: Cecil Womack (1947 - 2013) ~ VVN Music |publisher=Vintagevinylnews.com |date=2013-02-03 |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref>

 ****** Victor Wooten

b'{{multiple issues|
{{BLP sources|date=November 2013}}
{{BLP primary sources|date=November 2013}}
{{More footnotes|date=November 2013}}
}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name         = Victor Wooten
| image        = Victor Wooten 2.jpg
| caption      = Wooten playing at the Belly Up in 2006.
| landscape    = Yes
| background   = non_vocal_instrumentalist
| birth_name   = Victor Lemonte Wooten
| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1964|9|11}}
| birth_place  = [[Mountain Home, Idaho]], United States
| instrument   = [[Bass guitar]], [[upright bass]], [[fiddle]], [[cello]], tenor bass, [[fretless bass]], [[Kora (instrument)|kora]], [[drums]], [[keyboards]], [[guitar]]
| genre        = [[Jazz]], [[jazz fusion]], [[funk]], [[funk rock]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]]
| occupation   = Musician, songwriter, producer, author
| years_active = 1980\xe2\x80\x93present
| associated_acts = [[B\xc3\xa9la Fleck and the Flecktones]], [[Steve Bailey]], [[Vital Tech Tones]], [[SMV (band)|SMV]], [[Greg Howe]], [[Chick Corea Elektric Band]]
| website      = {{URL|http://www.victorwooten.com/}}
| notable_instruments = [[Fodera]] Monarch<br />Fodera Monarch Yin-Yang (4 string)<br />[[Steinberger]] bass guitars
}}

\'\'\'Victor Lemonte Wooten\'\'\' (born September 11, 1964) is an American [[Bass (guitar)|bass]] player, composer, author, producer, and recipient of five [[Grammy Award]]s.<ref name="official bio/Wooten">{{cite web|url=http://www.victorwooten.com/bio.html|title=Victor Wooten official website/biography|year=2010|work=Official website|publisher=VixLix Music|accessdate=May 27, 2010}}</ref>

Wooten has won the "Bass Player of the Year" award from \'\'[[Bass Player (magazine)|Bass Player]]\'\' magazine three times in a row, and was the first person to win the award more than once.<ref name="official bio/Wooten"/> In 2011, he was named #10 in the "Top 10 Bassists of All Time" by \'\'[[Rolling Stone]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/rolling-stone-readers-pick-the-top-ten-bassists-of-all-time-20110331|title=Rolling Stone Readers Pick the Top Ten Bassists of All Time|date=2011-03-31|publisher=rollingstone.com|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> In addition to a solo career and collaborations with various artists, Wooten has been the bassist for [[B\xc3\xa9la Fleck and the Flecktones]] since the group\'s formation in 1988.

In 2008, Wooten joined [[Stanley Clarke]] and [[Marcus Miller]] to record an album. The trio of bassists, under the name [[SMV (band)|SMV]], released \'\'[[Thunder (SMV album)|Thunder]]\'\' in August 2008 and began a supporting tour the same month.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marcusmiller.com/news_entry.html?newsid=275&color=0 |title=Marcus Miller News|publisher=Marcusmiller.com |accessdate=2008-06-19}}</ref>

Wooten has also written a novel titled "The Music Lesson: A Spiritual Search for Growth Through Music".<ref>Salina Journal (2010)</ref>  On his website he has stated that he is currently writing a sequel and intends to release at least three more books.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.victorwooten.com/bio.html |title=Biography |publisher=Victorwooten.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref>

Wooten also operates his own record label, Vix Records, on which he releases his own music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antimusic.com/news/11/feb/08Victor_Wooten_Announces_A_Show_of_Hands_15.shtml|title=Victor Wooten Announces A Show of Hands 15|date=2011-02-08|publisher=antimusic.com|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>

==Early life==
Born to Dorothy and Elijah Wooten, Victor is the youngest of the five Wooten Brothers; Regi, [[Roy Wooten|Roy]], Rudy and Joseph Wooten, all of whom are musicians. Regi began to teach Victor to play bass when he was two, and by the age of six, Victor was performing with his brothers in their family band, The Wooten Brothers Band.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brodkin|first=Fran|url=http://www.montgomerynews.com/articles/2013/11/29/entertainment/doc529619829c4fb272076613.txt|title=The Wootens: Band of brothers grow up with music and values|date=2013-11-29|publisher=montgomerynews.com|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> As an United States Air Force family, they moved around a lot when Victor was very young, finally settling in the Warwick Lawns neighborhood of [[Newport News, Virginia]] in 1972. He graduated from [[Denbigh High School (Newport News, Virginia)|Denbigh High School]] in 1982. While in high school, Victor and his brothers played in the country music revue at [[Busch Gardens Williamsburg|Busch Gardens]] theme park in [[Williamsburg, Virginia]]. In 1987, he traveled to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to visit friends that he made at the theme park, one of whom was a studio engineer that introduced him to [[B\xc3\xa9la Fleck]], with whom he still collaborates musically.<ref>McDonald, Sam (February 21, 2000) [http://articles.dailypress.com/2000-02-21/news/0002210015_1_regi-victor-wooten-bass-player "High Profile: Victor Wooten"], [[Daily Press (Virginia)|Daily Press]]</ref>

==Instruments==
[[File:Victor Wooten.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Wooten playing his [[Steinberger]] headless bass guitar at the \'\'[[Belly Up]]\'\' in 2006.]]
Wooten is most often seen playing [[Fodera]] basses, of which he has a signature model. His most famous Fodera, a 1983 Monarch Deluxe he refers to as "number 1," sports a [[Kahler Tremolo System]] model 2400 bridge. Fodera\'s "Yin Yang" basses (co-designed by and created for Wooten) incorporates the [[Yin and yang|Yin Yang symbol]]\xe2\x80\x94which Wooten uses in various media\xe2\x80\x94as a focal point of the top\'s design and construction. The symbol is created from two pieces of naturally finished wood (Ebony and Holly, for example), fitted together to create the Yin-Yang pattern.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306035134/http://www.fodera.com/vw_yy_4.html|title=Victor Wooten Yin Yang 4 String|publisher=fodera.com|accessdate=2013-12-25}}</ref> As well as playing electric bass (both fretted and fretless) and the double bass, Victor also played the cello in high school. He still plays cello occasionally with the Flecktones as well as in the 2012 Sword and Stone/Words and Tones tour.<ref>{{cite web|title=Playing with Words and Music|url=http://www.notreble.com/buzz/2012/10/04/playing-with-words-and-music-an-interview-with-victor-wooten-part-3/|website=NoTreble|accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref> This is the instrument to which he attributes his musical training.

Wooten has also experimented with backward vocals, chanting, and Asian percussion.

==Workshops==
In 2000 Wooten created a Bass/Nature camp that has since expanded into Victor Wooten\'s Center for Music and Nature, located in [[Only, Tennessee]], outside of [[Nashville]]. He holds the classes in spring and summer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2011/04/07/victor-wooten-chosen-in-rolling-stone-greatest-bass-players-of-all-time-poll/|title=Victor Wooten chosen in \xe2\x80\x98Rolling Stone\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Greatest Bass Players of All Time\xe2\x80\x99 poll|date=2011-04-07|publisher=tennesseean.com|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> Wooten also leads the "Victor Wooten/Berklee Summer Bass Workshop" for summer programs at Berklee College of Music in Boston, MA. At Berklee, Wooten incorporates his educational concepts from the Victor Wooten Center for Music into his collaborations with Berklee Bass Department chair, Steve Bailey.<ref>http://www.berklee.edu/summer/victor-wooten-berklee-summer-bass</ref> In 2013 and 2014 he appeared - among others like [[John Patitucci]], [[Leland Sklar|Lee Sklar]], [[Stuart Hamm]] and [[Alphonso Johnson]] - on an annual Bass Camp of the German bass manufacturer [[Warwick (bass guitar)|Warwick]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Herrera, Jonathan|title=Warwick Bass Camp 2013: The Best of the Bass|url=http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/19723-warwick-bass-camp-2013-the-best-of-the-bass|accessdate=December 4, 2014|newspaper=[[Premier Guitar]]|date=September 30, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Wetzel, Michael|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ln9H3y71L8|title=Video: German Warwick Bass Guitars|newspaper=
[[Deutsche Welle|Deutsche Welle TV]]|date=September 11, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://forbassplayersonly.com/feature-our-week-at-warwick-bass-camp/|title=Our Week in Germany|website=ForBassPlayersOnly|accessdate=December 4, 2014|date=September 29, 2014}}</ref>

He was featured on the May/June 2014 cover of [[Making Music Magazine]]<ref>[http://makingmusicmag.com/victor-wootens/]</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Victot Wooten Music and Nature Camps|url=http://makingmusicmag.com/victor-wootens/}}</ref> to discuss the music nature camps.
